   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading">Afghanistan</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="vector-body"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="contentSub2"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav"></div> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>

      <p><b>Afghanistan</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Ã¦/: 'a' in 'bad'">Ã¦</span><span title="'f' in 'find'">f</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="/É¡/: 'g' in 'guy'">É¡</span><span title="/Ã¦/: 'a' in 'bad'">Ã¦</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span><span title="/Éª/: 'i' in 'kit'">Éª</span><span title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</span><span title="'t' in 'tie'">t</span><span title="/Ã¦/: 'a' in 'bad'">Ã¦</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>,<span class="wrap"> </span><span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Ã¦/: 'a' in 'bad'">Ã¦</span><span title="'f' in 'find'">f</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="/É¡/: 'g' in 'guy'">É¡</span><span title="/ÉË/: 'a' in 'father'">ÉË</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span><span title="/Éª/: 'i' in 'kit'">Éª</span><span title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</span><span title="'t' in 'tie'">t</span><span title="/ÉË/: 'a' in 'father'">ÉË</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Afghanistan.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/ff/En-us-Afghanistan.ogg" class="internal" title="En-us-Afghanistan.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span></span>;<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[14]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pashto" title="Pashto">Pashto</a>/<a href="/wiki/Dari_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Dari language">Dari</a>: <span lang="ps" dir="rtl" title="Pashto-language text">Ø§ÙØºØ§ÙØ³ØªØ§Ù</span>, Pashto: <i lang="ps-Latn" title="Pashto-language text">AfÄ¡ÄnistÄn</i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA" title="Help:IPA">[avÉ£ÉnisËtÉn, ab-]</a></span>,<sup id="cite_ref-fn1_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fn1-16">[b]</a></sup> Dari: <i lang="prs-Latn" title="Dari-language text">AfÄ¡ÄnestÄn</i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Persian" title="Help:IPA/Persian">[avÉ£ÉnesËtÉn]</a></span>), officially the <b>Islamic Republic of Afghanistan</b>, is a mountainous <a href="/wiki/Landlocked_country" title="Landlocked country">landlocked country</a> at the crossroads of <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South Asia</a>. Afghanistan is bordered by <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> to the east and south; <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a> to the west; <a href="/wiki/Turkmenistan" title="Turkmenistan">Turkmenistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uzbekistan" title="Uzbekistan">Uzbekistan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tajikistan" title="Tajikistan">Tajikistan</a> to the north; and <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> to the northeast. Occupying 652,000 square kilometers (252,000&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), it is a mountainous country with plains in the north and southwest. <a href="/wiki/Kabul" title="Kabul">Kabul</a> is the capital and largest city. Its population is around 32&nbsp;million, composed mostly of ethnic <a href="/wiki/Pashtuns" title="Pashtuns">Pashtuns</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tajiks" title="Tajiks">Tajiks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hazaras" title="Hazaras">Hazaras</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Uzbeks" title="Uzbeks">Uzbeks</a>. </p>
      <p>Humans lived in what is now Afghanistan at least 50,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-JFS_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JFS-17">[15]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Settled life</a> emerged in the region 9,000 years ago, evolving gradually into the <a href="/wiki/Indus_civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Indus civilization">Indus civilization</a> (<a href="/wiki/Shortugai" title="Shortugai">Shortugai</a> site), the <a href="/wiki/Oxus_civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Oxus civilization">Oxus civilization</a> (Dashlyji site), and the <a href="/wiki/Helmand_civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Helmand civilization">Helmand civilization</a> (<a href="/wiki/Mundigak" title="Mundigak">Mundigak</a> site) of the 3rd millennium BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-Combined-2_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Combined-2-18">[16]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_peoples" title="Indo-Aryan peoples">Indo-Aryans</a> migrated through <a href="/wiki/Bactria" title="Bactria">Bactria</a>-<a href="/wiki/Margiana" title="Margiana">Margiana</a> area to <a href="/wiki/Gandhara" title="Gandhara">Gandhara</a>, followed by the rise of the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">Iron Age</a> <a href="/wiki/Yaz_culture" title="Yaz culture">Yaz I culture</a> (ca. 1500â1100 BCE),<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[17]</a></sup> which has been closely associated with the culture depicted in the <a href="/wiki/Avesta" title="Avesta">Avesta</a>, the ancient religious texts of <a href="/wiki/Zoroastrianism" title="Zoroastrianism">Zoroastrianism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[18]</a></sup> The region, then known as "<a href="/wiki/Ariana" title="Ariana">Ariana</a>", fell to <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid" class="mw-redirect" title="Achaemenid">Achaemenid</a> Persians in the 6th century BCE, who conquered the areas to their east <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_conquest_of_the_Indus_Valley" title="Achaemenid conquest of the Indus Valley">as far as the Indus River</a>. <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a> invaded the region in the 4th century BCE, who married <a href="/wiki/Roxana" title="Roxana">Roxana</a> in Bactria before his <a href="/wiki/Cophen_campaign" title="Cophen campaign">Kabul Valley campaign</a>, where he faced resistance from <a href="/wiki/Aspasioi" class="mw-redirect" title="Aspasioi">Aspasioi</a> and Assakan tribes. The <a href="/wiki/Greco-Bactrian_Kingdom" title="Greco-Bactrian Kingdom">Greco-Bactrian Kingdom</a> became the eastern end of the <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_world" class="mw-redirect" title="Hellenistic world">Hellenistic world</a>. Following the conquest by <a href="/wiki/Mauryan" class="mw-redirect" title="Mauryan">Mauryan</a> Indians, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Afghanistan" title="Buddhism in Afghanistan">Buddhism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Afghanistan" title="Hinduism in Afghanistan">Hinduism</a> flourished in the region for centuries. The <a href="/wiki/Kushan" class="mw-redirect" title="Kushan">Kushan</a> emperor <a href="/wiki/Kanishka" title="Kanishka">Kanishka</a>, who ruled from his twin capitals of <a href="/wiki/Kapisi" title="Kapisi">Kapisi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Puru%E1%B9%A3apura" class="mw-redirect" title="Puruá¹£apura">Puruá¹£apura</a>, played an important role in the spread of <a href="/wiki/Mahayana" title="Mahayana">Mahayana</a> Buddhism to China and Central Asia. Various other Buddhist dynasties originated from this region as well, including the <a href="/wiki/Kidarites" title="Kidarites">Kidarites</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hephthalites" title="Hephthalites">Hephthalites</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alkhons" class="mw-redirect" title="Alkhons">Alkhons</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nezak" title="Nezak">Nezaks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zunbils" title="Zunbils">Zunbils</a> and <a href="/wiki/Turk_Shahi" class="mw-redirect" title="Turk Shahi">Turk Shahis</a>. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquests_of_Afghanistan" title="Muslim conquests of Afghanistan">Muslims brought Islam</a> to <a href="/wiki/Sassanian" class="mw-redirect" title="Sassanian">Sassanian</a>-held <a href="/wiki/Herat" title="Herat">Herat</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zaranj" title="Zaranj">Zaranj</a> in the mid-7th century, while fuller Islamization was achieved between the 9th and 12th centuries under the <a href="/wiki/Saffarid" class="mw-redirect" title="Saffarid">Saffarid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samanid" class="mw-redirect" title="Samanid">Samanid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ghaznavid" class="mw-redirect" title="Ghaznavid">Ghaznavid</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ghurid" class="mw-redirect" title="Ghurid">Ghurid</a> dynasties. Parts of the region were later ruled by the <a href="/wiki/Khwarazmian_Empire" title="Khwarazmian Empire">Khwarazmian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khalji" class="mw-redirect" title="Khalji">Khalji</a>, <a href="/wiki/Timurid_Empire" title="Timurid Empire">Timurid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lodi_dynasty" title="Lodi dynasty">Lodi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sur_Empire" title="Sur Empire">Sur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Safavid" class="mw-redirect" title="Safavid">Safavid</a> empires.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[19]</a></sup> The political history of the modern state of Afghanistan began with the <a href="/wiki/Hotak_dynasty" title="Hotak dynasty">Hotak dynasty</a>, whose founder <a href="/wiki/Mirwais_Hotak" title="Mirwais Hotak">Mirwais Hotak</a> declared southern Afghanistan independent in 1709. In 1747, <a href="/wiki/Ahmad_Shah_Durrani" title="Ahmad Shah Durrani">Ahmad Shah Durrani</a> established the <a href="/wiki/Durrani_Empire" title="Durrani Empire">Durrani Empire</a> with its capital at <a href="/wiki/Kandahar" title="Kandahar">Kandahar</a>. In 1776, the Durrani capital was moved to Kabul while <a href="/wiki/Peshawar" title="Peshawar">Peshawar</a> became the winter capital;<sup id="cite_ref-cap1_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cap1-22">[20]</a></sup> the latter was <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Nowshera" title="Battle of Nowshera">lost to Sikhs in 1823</a>. In the late 19th century, Afghanistan became a <a href="/wiki/Buffer_state" title="Buffer state">buffer state</a> in the "<a href="/wiki/Great_Game" class="mw-redirect" title="Great Game">Great Game</a>" between British India and the Russian Empire.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[21]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[22]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/First_Anglo-Afghan_War" title="First Anglo-Afghan War">First Anglo-Afghan War</a>, the <a href="/wiki/British_East_India_Company" class="mw-redirect" title="British East India Company">British East India Company</a> seized control of Afghanistan briefly, but following the <a href="/wiki/Third_Anglo-Afghan_War" title="Third Anglo-Afghan War">Third Anglo-Afghan War</a> in 1919 the country was free of foreign influence, eventually becoming a monarchy under <a href="/wiki/Amanullah_Khan" title="Amanullah Khan">Amanullah Khan</a>, until almost 50 years later when <a href="/wiki/Zahir_Shah" class="mw-redirect" title="Zahir Shah">Zahir Shah</a> was overthrown and a republic was established. In 1978, after a second coup, Afghanistan first became a socialist state, evoking the <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Afghan_War" title="SovietâAfghan War">SovietâAfghan War</a> in the 1980s against <a href="/wiki/Mujahideen#Afghanistan" title="Mujahideen">mujahideen</a> rebels. By 1996, most of the country was captured by the Islamic fundamentalist <a href="/wiki/Taliban" title="Taliban">Taliban</a>, who ruled as a totalitarian regime for over five years; they were removed from power after the <a href="/wiki/United_States_invasion_of_Afghanistan" title="United States invasion of Afghanistan">US invasion</a> in 2001 but still control a significant portion of the country. The <a href="/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001-present)" class="mw-redirect" title="War in Afghanistan (2001-present)">ongoing war</a> between the government and the Taliban has contributed to the perpetuation of Afghanistan's problematic <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Afghanistan" title="Human rights in Afghanistan">human rights record</a> including complications of <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_rights_in_Afghanistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Women's rights in Afghanistan">women's rights</a>, with numerous abuses committed by both sides, such as the killing of civilians, kidnapping, torture. </p>
      <p>Afghanistan is a unitary presidential <a href="/wiki/Islamic_republic" title="Islamic republic">Islamic republic</a>. The country has high levels of <a href="/wiki/Terrorism" title="Terrorism">terrorism</a>, poverty, child malnutrition, and corruption. It is a member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">Organisation of Islamic Cooperation</a>, the <a href="/wiki/South_Asian_Association_for_Regional_Cooperation" title="South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation">South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_77" title="Group of 77">Group of 77</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Economic_Cooperation_Organization" title="Economic Cooperation Organization">Economic Cooperation Organization</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a>. Afghanistan's economy is the world's 96th largest, with a gross domestic product (GDP) of $72.9&nbsp;billion by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a>; the country fares much worse in terms of per-capita GDP (PPP), ranking 169th out of 186 countries as of 2018. </p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading">

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Afghanistan" title="Name of Afghanistan">Name of Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Root_(linguistics)" title="Root (linguistics)">root</a> name "<a href="/wiki/Afghan_(ethnonym)" title="Afghan (ethnonym)"><i>AfghÄn</i></a>" is, according to some scholars, derived from the name of the <i><a href="/wiki/A%C5%9Bvaka" title="AÅvaka">AÅvakan</a></i> or <i>Assakan</i>, ancient inhabitants of the <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Kush" title="Hindu Kush">Hindu Kush</a> region.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[27]</a></sup> <i>AÅvakan</i> literally means "horsemen", "horse breeders", or "<a href="/wiki/Cavalry" title="Cavalry">cavalrymen</a>" (from <i><a href="/wiki/A%C5%9Bva" class="mw-redirect" title="AÅva">aÅva</a></i> or <i>aspa</i>, the <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> and <a href="/wiki/Avestan" title="Avestan">Avestan</a> words for "<a href="/wiki/Horse" title="Horse">horse</a>").<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[28]</a></sup> Historically, the ethnonym <i>AfghÄn</i> was used to refer to ethnic <a href="/wiki/Pashtuns" title="Pashtuns">Pashtuns</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Afghan_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Afghan-31">[29]</a></sup> The Arabic and Persian form of the name, <i>AfÄ¡Än</i> was first attested in the 10th-century geography book <i><a href="/wiki/Hudud_al-%27Alam" title="Hudud al-'Alam">Hudud al-'Alam</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[30]</a></sup> The last part of the name, "<i><a href="/wiki/-stan" title="-stan">-stan</a></i>" is a Persian suffix for "place of". Therefore, "Afghanistan" translates to "land of the Afghans", or "land of the Pashtuns" in a historical sense. According to the third edition of the <i><a href="/wiki/Encyclopedia_of_Islam" class="mw-redirect" title="Encyclopedia of Islam">Encyclopedia of Islam</a></i>:<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[31]</a></sup> </p> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style>
      <blockquote class="templatequote">
       <p>The name Afghanistan (AfghÄnistÄn, land of the Afghans/Pashtuns, <i>afÄghina</i>, sing. <i>afghÄn</i>) can be traced to the early eighth/fourteenth century, when it designated the easternmost part of the <a href="/wiki/Kartid" class="mw-redirect" title="Kartid">Kartid</a> realm. This name was later used for certain regions in the á¹¢afavid and Mughal empires that were inhabited by Afghans. While based on a state-supporting elite of <a href="/wiki/Durrani" title="Durrani">AbdÄlÄ«/DurrÄnÄ«</a> Afghans, the <a href="/wiki/Durrani_Empire" title="Durrani Empire">SadÅ«zÄÊ¾Ä« DurrÄnÄ« polity</a> that came into being in 1160/1747 was not called Afghanistan in its own day. The name became a state designation only during the colonial intervention of the nineteenth century.</p>
      </blockquote> 
      <p>The modern <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Afghanistan" title="Constitution of Afghanistan">Constitution of Afghanistan</a> states that the word "Afghan" shall apply to every <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Afghanistan" title="Demographics of Afghanistan">citizen of Afghanistan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarfield2012159_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarfield2012159-34">[32]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Constitution_of_Afghanistan_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitution_of_Afghanistan-8">[7]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Afghanistan" title="History of Afghanistan">History of Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1013635363">.mw-parser-output .sidebar{width:22em;float:right;clear:right;margin:0.5em 0 1em 1em;background:#f8f9fa;border:1px solid .sidebar-list-title-c{text-align:center;margin:0 3.3em}@media(max-width:720px){body.mediawiki .mw-parser-output .sidebar{width:100%!important;clear:both;float:none!important;margin-left:0!important;margin-right:0!important}}</style>
      <table class="sidebar sidebar-collapse nomobile sidebar-wraplinks vcard plainlist">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <th class="sidebar-title">
          <div style="margin: -0.2em 0; font-size:70%; font-weight:normal;">
           Part of <a href="/wiki/Category:History_of_Afghanistan" title="Category:History of Afghanistan"><b>a series</b></a> on the
          </div></th> 
        </tr>
        <tr> 
         <th class="vcard navbox-title" style="background: none; font-size: 145%;padding: 0.15em 0.1em;line-height: 1.2em;"><a href="/wiki/History_of_Afghanistan" title="History of Afghanistan">History of <span class="fn org label">Afghanistan</span></a></th> 
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td style="padding: 0.2em; border-bottom: 1px solid #ccc;"><a href="/wiki/File:Shuja_Shah_Durrani_of_Afghanistan_in_1839.jpg" class="image"><img alt="&quot;Interior of the palace of Shauh Shujah Ool Moolk, Late King of Cabul&quot;" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Shuja_Shah_Durrani_of_Afghanistan_in_1839.jpg/200px-Shuja_Shah_Durrani_of_Afghanistan_in_1839.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="147" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Shuja_Shah_Durrani_of_Afghanistan_in_1839.jpg/300px-Shuja_Shah_Durrani_of_Afghanistan_in_1839.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Shuja_Shah_Durrani_of_Afghanistan_in_1839.jpg/400px-Shuja_Shah_Durrani_of_Afghanistan_in_1839.jpg 2x" data-file-width="968" data-file-height="712"></a></td>
        </tr>

         <td class="sidebar-navbar"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r992953826">.mw-parser-output .navbar{display:inline;font-size:88%;font-weight:normal}.mw-parser-output .navbar-collapse{float:left;text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .navbar-boxtext{word-spacing:0}.mw-parser-output .navbar ul{display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap;line-height:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::before{margin-right:-0.125em;content:"[ "}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::after{margin-left:-0.125em;content:" ]"}.mw-parser-output .navbar li{word-spacing:-0.125em}.mw-parser-output .navbar-mini abbr{font-variant:small-caps;border-bottom:none;text-decoration:none;cursor:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-full{font-size:114%;margin:0 7em}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-mini{font-size:114%;margin:0 4em}.mw-parser-output .infobox .navbar{font-size:100%}.mw-parser-output .navbox .navbar{display:block;font-size:100%}.mw-parser-output .navbox-title .navbar{float:left;text-align:left;margin-right:0.5em}</style>
          <div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini">
           <ul>
            <li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:History_of_Afghanistan" title="Template:History of Afghanistan"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li>
            <li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:History_of_Afghanistan" title="Template talk:History of Afghanistan"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li>
            <li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:History_of_Afghanistan&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li>
           </ul>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Nomads_in_Badghis_Province.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Nomads_in_Badghis_Province.jpg/220px-Nomads_in_Badghis_Province.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="144" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Nomads_in_Badghis_Province.jpg/330px-Nomads_in_Badghis_Province.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Nomads_in_Badghis_Province.jpg/440px-Nomads_in_Badghis_Province.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3059" data-file-height="2007"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Nomads_in_Badghis_Province.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Tents of <a href="/wiki/Afghan" title="Afghan">Afghan</a> <a href="/wiki/Nomad" title="Nomad">nomads</a> in the northern <a href="/wiki/Badghis_Province" title="Badghis Province">Badghis province</a> of Afghanistan. Early peasant farming villages came into existence in Afghanistan about 7,000 years ago.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Many empires and kingdoms have also risen to power in Afghanistan, such as the <a href="/wiki/Greco-Bactrians" class="mw-redirect" title="Greco-Bactrians">Greco-Bactrians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indo-Scythians" title="Indo-Scythians">Indo-Scythians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kushan" class="mw-redirect" title="Kushan">Kushans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kidarites" title="Kidarites">Kidarites</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hephthalites" title="Hephthalites">Hephthalites</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alkhons" class="mw-redirect" title="Alkhons">Alkhons</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nezaks" class="mw-redirect" title="Nezaks">Nezaks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zunbils" title="Zunbils">Zunbils</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turk_Shahi" class="mw-redirect" title="Turk Shahi">Turk Shahis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Shahi" title="Hindu Shahi">Hindu Shahis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lawiks" class="mw-redirect" title="Lawiks">Lawiks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saffarids" class="mw-redirect" title="Saffarids">Saffarids</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samanids" class="mw-redirect" title="Samanids">Samanids</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ghaznavids" title="Ghaznavids">Ghaznavids</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ghurids" class="mw-redirect" title="Ghurids">Ghurids</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khwarazmians" class="mw-redirect" title="Khwarazmians">Khwarazmians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khalji" class="mw-redirect" title="Khalji">Khaljis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kartids" class="mw-redirect" title="Kartids">Kartids</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lodi_dynasty" title="Lodi dynasty">Lodis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sur_Empire" title="Sur Empire">Surs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mughals" class="mw-redirect" title="Mughals">Mughals</a>, and finally, the <a href="/wiki/Hotak_dynasty" title="Hotak dynasty">Hotak</a> and <a href="/wiki/Durrani_dynasty" title="Durrani dynasty">Durrani</a> dynasties, which marked the political origins of the modern state.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERunion200744-49_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERunion200744-49-35">[33]</a></sup> Throughout millennia several cities within the modern day Afghanistan served as capitals of various empires, namely Bactra (<a href="/wiki/Balkh" title="Balkh">Balkh</a>), Alexandria on the Oxus (<a href="/wiki/Ai-Khanoum" title="Ai-Khanoum">Ai-Khanoum</a>), <a href="/wiki/Kapisi" title="Kapisi">Kapisi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sigal,_Sakastan" title="Sigal, Sakastan">Sigal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kabul" title="Kabul">Kabul</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kunduz" title="Kunduz">Kunduz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zaranj" title="Zaranj">Zaranj</a>, <a href="/wiki/Firozkoh" title="Firozkoh">Firozkoh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Herat" title="Herat">Herat</a>, Ghazna (<a href="/wiki/Ghazni" title="Ghazni">Ghazni</a>), Binban (<a href="/wiki/Bamyan" title="Bamyan">Bamyan</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Kandahar" title="Kandahar">Kandahar</a>. </p>
      <p>The country sits at a unique nexus point where numerous civilizations have interacted and often fought. It has been home to various peoples through the ages, among them the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Iranian_peoples" class="mw-redirect" title="Ancient Iranian peoples">ancient Iranian peoples</a> who established the dominant role of <a href="/wiki/Indo-Iranian_languages" title="Indo-Iranian languages">Indo-Iranian languages</a> in the region. At multiple points, the land has been incorporated within vast regional empires, among them the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Macedonian_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Macedonian Empire">Macedonian Empire</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Maurya_Empire" title="Maurya Empire">Maurya Empire</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamic Empire">Islamic Empire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[34]</a></sup> For its success in resisting foreign occupation during the 19th and 20th centuries, Afghanistan has been called the "graveyard of empires",<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarfield2012255_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarfield2012255-37">[35]</a></sup> though it is unknown who coined the phrase.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[36]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory_and_antiquity">Prehistory and antiquity</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Pre-Islamic_period_of_Afghanistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Pre-Islamic period of Afghanistan">Pre-Islamic period of Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Excavations" class="mw-redirect" title="Excavations">Excavations</a> of prehistoric sites suggest that humans were living in what is now Afghanistan at least 50,000 years ago, and that farming communities in the area were among the earliest in the world. An important site of early historical activities, many believe that Afghanistan compares to <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a> in terms of the historical value of its archaeological sites.<sup id="cite_ref-JFS_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JFS-17">[15]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[37]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Indus_Valley_Civilization,_Mature_Phase_(2600-1900_BCE).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Indus_Valley_Civilization%2C_Mature_Phase_%282600-1900_BCE%29.png/260px-Indus_Valley_Civilization%2C_Mature_Phase_%282600-1900_BCE%29.png" decoding="async" width="260" height="212" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Indus_Valley_Civilization%2C_Mature_Phase_%282600-1900_BCE%29.png/390px-Indus_Valley_Civilization%2C_Mature_Phase_%282600-1900_BCE%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Indus_Valley_Civilization%2C_Mature_Phase_%282600-1900_BCE%29.png/520px-Indus_Valley_Civilization%2C_Mature_Phase_%282600-1900_BCE%29.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="733"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Indus_Valley_Civilization,_Mature_Phase_(2600-1900_BCE).png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>the extent of the <a href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Indus Valley civilization">Indus Valley civilization</a> during its mature phase
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Archaeological" class="mw-redirect" title="Archaeological">Archaeological</a> exploration done in the 20th century suggests that the geographical area of Afghanistan has been closely connected by culture and trade with its neighbors to the east, west, and north. Artifacts typical of the <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">Paleolithic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mesolithic" title="Mesolithic">Mesolithic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">Iron Ages</a> have been found in Afghanistan. Urban civilization is believed to have begun as early as 3000 BCE, and the early city of <a href="/wiki/Mundigak" title="Mundigak">Mundigak</a> (near <a href="/wiki/Kandahar" title="Kandahar">Kandahar</a> in the south of the country) was a center of the <a href="/wiki/Helmand_culture" title="Helmand culture">Helmand culture</a>. More recent findings established that the <a href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Indus Valley Civilization">Indus Valley Civilization</a> stretched up towards modern-day Afghanistan, making the ancient civilization today part of Pakistan, Afghanistan, and India. In more detail, it extended from what today is northwest <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> to northwest India and northeast Afghanistan. An Indus Valley site has been found on the <a href="/wiki/Oxus_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Oxus River">Oxus River</a> at <a href="/wiki/Shortugai" title="Shortugai">Shortugai</a> in northern Afghanistan.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Ancient_Indus_pp.1_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Ancient_Indus_pp.1-40">[38]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[39]</a></sup> There are several smaller IVC colonies to be found in Afghanistan as well. </p>
      <p>After 2000 BCE, successive waves of semi-nomadic people from Central Asia began moving south into Afghanistan; among them were many <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_languages" title="Indo-European languages">Indo-European</a>-speaking <a href="/wiki/Indo-Iranians" title="Indo-Iranians">Indo-Iranians</a>. These tribes later migrated further into South Asia, Western Asia, and toward Europe via the area north of the <a href="/wiki/Caspian_Sea" title="Caspian Sea">Caspian Sea</a>. The region at the time was referred to as <a href="/wiki/Ariana" title="Ariana">Ariana</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-JFS_17-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JFS-17">[15]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[40]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Zoroastrianism_and_Hellenic_era">Zoroastrianism and Hellenic era</span></h4> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:ScythianBelt.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/ScythianBelt.jpg/240px-ScythianBelt.jpg" decoding="async" width="240" height="193" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/ScythianBelt.jpg/360px-ScythianBelt.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/ScythianBelt.jpg/480px-ScythianBelt.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1136" data-file-height="914"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:ScythianBelt.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A "Bactrian gold" <a href="/wiki/Scythian" class="mw-redirect" title="Scythian">Scythian</a> belt depicing <a href="/wiki/Dionysus" title="Dionysus">Dionysus</a>, from <a href="/wiki/Tillya_Tepe" title="Tillya Tepe">Tillya Tepe</a> in the ancient region of <a href="/wiki/Bactria" title="Bactria">Bactria</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The religion <a href="/wiki/Zoroastrianism" title="Zoroastrianism">Zoroastrianism</a> is believed by some to have originated in what is now Afghanistan between 1800 and 800 BCE, as its founder <a href="/wiki/Zoroaster" title="Zoroaster">Zoroaster</a> is thought to have lived and died in <a href="/wiki/Balkh" title="Balkh">Balkh</a>. Ancient <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Iranian_languages" title="Eastern Iranian languages">Eastern Iranian languages</a> may have been spoken in the region around the time of the rise of Zoroastrianism. By the middle of the 6th century BCE, the Achaemenids overthrew the <a href="/wiki/Medes" title="Medes">Medes</a> and incorporated <a href="/wiki/Arachosia" title="Arachosia">Arachosia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aria_(satrapy)" class="mw-redirect" title="Aria (satrapy)">Aria</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bactria" title="Bactria">Bactria</a> within its eastern boundaries. An <a href="/wiki/Epigraphy" title="Epigraphy">inscription</a> on the tombstone of <a href="/wiki/Darius_I_of_Persia" class="mw-redirect" title="Darius I of Persia">Darius I of Persia</a> mentions the <a href="/wiki/Kabulistan" title="Kabulistan">Kabul Valley</a> in a list of the 29 countries that he had conquered.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[41]</a></sup> The region of <a href="/wiki/Arachosia" title="Arachosia">Arachosia</a>, around Kandahar in modern-day southern Afghanistan, used to be primarily Zoroastrian and played a key role in the transfer of the Avesta to <a href="/wiki/Persis" title="Persis">Persia</a> and is thus considered by some to be the "second homeland of Zoroastriansm".<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[42]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[43]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[44]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a> and his Macedonian forces arrived in Afghanistan in 330 BCE after defeating <a href="/wiki/Darius_III_of_Persia" class="mw-redirect" title="Darius III of Persia">Darius III of Persia</a> a year earlier in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Gaugamela" title="Battle of Gaugamela">Battle of Gaugamela</a>. Following Alexander's brief occupation, the successor state of the <a href="/wiki/Seleucid_Empire" title="Seleucid Empire">Seleucid Empire</a> controlled the region until 305 BCE when they gave much of it to the <a href="/wiki/Maurya_Empire" title="Maurya Empire">Maurya Empire</a> as part of an alliance treaty. The Mauryans controlled the area south of the <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Kush" title="Hindu Kush">Hindu Kush</a> until they were overthrown in about 185 BCE. Their decline began 60 years after <a href="/wiki/Ashoka" title="Ashoka">Ashoka</a>'s rule ended, leading to the <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic" class="mw-redirect" title="Hellenistic">Hellenistic</a> reconquest by the <a href="/wiki/Greco-Bactrians" class="mw-redirect" title="Greco-Bactrians">Greco-Bactrians</a>. Much of it soon broke away from them and became part of the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Greek_Kingdom" title="Indo-Greek Kingdom">Indo-Greek Kingdom</a>. They were defeated and expelled by the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Scythians" title="Indo-Scythians">Indo-Scythians</a> in the late 2nd century BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-LoC-pdf_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LoC-pdf-4">[4]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERunion200744_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERunion200744-47">[45]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Hindu_and_Buddhist_era">Hindu and Buddhist era</span></h4> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Rome-Seleucia-Parthia_200bc.jpg" class="image"><img alt="A map centered on the Mediterranean and Middle East showing the extent of the Roman Republic (Purple), Selucid Empire (Blue), and Parthia (Yellow) around 200&nbsp;BCE." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Rome-Seleucia-Parthia_200bc.jpg/310px-Rome-Seleucia-Parthia_200bc.jpg" decoding="async" width="310" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Rome-Seleucia-Parthia_200bc.jpg/465px-Rome-Seleucia-Parthia_200bc.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Rome-Seleucia-Parthia_200bc.jpg/620px-Rome-Seleucia-Parthia_200bc.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1205" data-file-height="567"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Rome-Seleucia-Parthia_200bc.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Parthia" title="Parthia">Parthia</a>, shaded yellow, alongside the <a href="/wiki/Seleucid_Empire" title="Seleucid Empire">Seleucid Empire</a> (blue) and the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">Roman Republic</a> (purple) around 200&nbsp;BCE
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road" title="Silk Road">Silk Road</a> appeared during the first century BCE, and Afghanistan flourished with trade, with routes to China, India, Persia and north to the cities of <a href="/wiki/Bukhara" title="Bukhara">Bukhara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samarkand" title="Samarkand">Samarkand</a> and <a href="/wiki/Khiva" title="Khiva">Khiva</a> in present-day Uzbekistan.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[46]</a></sup> Goods and ideas were exchanged at this center point, such as Chinese silk, Persian silver and Roman gold, while the region of present Afghanistan was mining and trading <a href="/wiki/Lapis_lazuli" title="Lapis lazuli">lapis lazuli</a> stones<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[47]</a></sup> mainly from the <a href="/wiki/Badakhshan" title="Badakhshan">Badakhshan</a> region. </p>
      <p>During the first century BCE, the <a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">Parthian Empire</a> subjugated the region but lost it to their <a href="/wiki/Indo-Parthian" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-Parthian">Indo-Parthian</a> vassals. In the mid-to-late first century CE the vast <a href="/wiki/Kushan_Empire" title="Kushan Empire">Kushan Empire</a>, centered in Afghanistan, became great patrons of Buddhist culture, making <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a> flourish throughout the region. The Kushans were overthrown by the <a href="/wiki/Sassanids" class="mw-redirect" title="Sassanids">Sassanids</a> in the 3rd century CE, though the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Sassanids" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-Sassanids">Indo-Sassanids</a> continued to rule at least parts of the region. They were followed by the <a href="/wiki/Kidarite" class="mw-redirect" title="Kidarite">Kidarites</a> who, in turn, were replaced by the <a href="/wiki/Hephthalites" title="Hephthalites">Hephthalites</a>. They were replaced by the <a href="/wiki/Turk_Shahi" class="mw-redirect" title="Turk Shahi">Turk Shahi</a> in the 7th century. The Buddhist Turk Shahi of Kabul was replaced by a Hindu dynasty before the Saffarids conquered the area in 870, this Hindu dynasty was called <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Shahi" title="Hindu Shahi">Hindu Shahi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[48]</a></sup> Much of the northeastern and southern areas of the country remained dominated by <a href="/wiki/Buddhist" class="mw-redirect" title="Buddhist">Buddhist</a> culture.<sup id="cite_ref-Habibi_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Habibi-51">[49]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[50]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Medieval_history">Medieval history</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Islamic_conquest_of_Afghanistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamic conquest of Afghanistan">Islamic conquest of Afghanistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasion_of_Central_Asia" class="mw-redirect" title="Mongol invasion of Central Asia">Mongol invasion of Central Asia</a>
      </div> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Islamic_conquest">Islamic conquest</span></h4> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Saffarid_dynasty_861-1003.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Saffarid_dynasty_861-1003.png/240px-Saffarid_dynasty_861-1003.png" decoding="async" width="240" height="166" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Saffarid_dynasty_861-1003.png/360px-Saffarid_dynasty_861-1003.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Saffarid_dynasty_861-1003.png/480px-Saffarid_dynasty_861-1003.png 2x" data-file-width="620" data-file-height="429"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Saffarid_dynasty_861-1003.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Saffarid rule at its greatest extent under Ya'qub b. al-Layth al-Saffar
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Arab" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab">Arab</a> <a href="/wiki/Muslim" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim">Muslims</a> brought Islam to <a href="/wiki/Herat" title="Herat">Herat</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zaranj" title="Zaranj">Zaranj</a> in 642&nbsp;CE and began spreading eastward; some of the native inhabitants they encountered accepted it while others revolted. Before Islam was introduced, people of the region were mostly Buddhists and Zoroastrians, but there were also <a href="/wiki/Surya" title="Surya">Surya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nana_(Afghan_goddess)" class="mw-redirect" title="Nana (Afghan goddess)">Nana</a> worshipers, <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Afghanistan" title="History of the Jews in Afghanistan">Jews</a>, and others. The <a href="/wiki/Zunbils" title="Zunbils">Zunbils</a> and Kabul Shahi were first conquered in 870&nbsp;CE by the <a href="/wiki/Saffarid" class="mw-redirect" title="Saffarid">Saffarid</a> Muslims of Zaranj. Later, the <a href="/wiki/Samanids" class="mw-redirect" title="Samanids">Samanids</a> extended their Islamic influence south of the <a href="/wiki/Hindu" class="mw-redirect" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> Kush. It is reported that Muslims and non-Muslims still lived side by side in Kabul before the <a href="/wiki/Ghaznavids" title="Ghaznavids">Ghaznavids</a> rose to power in the 10th century.<sup id="cite_ref-Elliot-2_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Elliot-2-53">[51]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Mustawfi_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mustawfi-54">[52]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Elliot-3_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Elliot-3-55">[53]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>By the 11th century, <a href="/wiki/Mahmud_of_Ghazni" title="Mahmud of Ghazni">Mahmud of Ghazni</a> defeated the remaining Hindu rulers and effectively <a href="/wiki/Islamized" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamized">Islamized</a> the wider region,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEwans200222-23_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEwans200222-23-56">[54]</a></sup> with the exception of <a href="/wiki/Kafiristan" title="Kafiristan">Kafiristan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nuristan.info_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nuristan.info-57">[55]</a></sup> Mahmud made <a href="/wiki/Ghazni" title="Ghazni">Ghazni</a> into an important city and patronized intellectuals such as the historian <a href="/wiki/Al-Biruni" title="Al-Biruni">Al-Biruni</a> and the poet <a href="/wiki/Ferdowsi" title="Ferdowsi">Ferdowsi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[56]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ghaznavid_dynasty" class="mw-redirect" title="Ghaznavid dynasty">Ghaznavid dynasty</a> was overthrown by the <a href="/wiki/Ghurids" class="mw-redirect" title="Ghurids">Ghurids</a>, whose architectural achievements included the remote <a href="/wiki/Minaret_of_Jam" title="Minaret of Jam">Minaret of Jam</a>. The Ghurids controlled Afghanistan for less than a century before being conquered by the <a href="/wiki/Khwarazmian_dynasty" class="mw-redirect" title="Khwarazmian dynasty">Khwarazmian dynasty</a> in 1215.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEwans200223_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEwans200223-59">[57]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Mongols_and_Babur">Mongols and Babur</span></h4> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Mazar-e_sharif_-_Steve_Evans.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Mazar-e_sharif_-_Steve_Evans.jpg/220px-Mazar-e_sharif_-_Steve_Evans.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="158" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Mazar-e_sharif_-_Steve_Evans.jpg/330px-Mazar-e_sharif_-_Steve_Evans.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Mazar-e_sharif_-_Steve_Evans.jpg/440px-Mazar-e_sharif_-_Steve_Evans.jpg 2x" data-file-width="965" data-file-height="695"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Mazar-e_sharif_-_Steve_Evans.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Blue_Mosque_(Mazar-i-Sharif)" title="Blue Mosque (Mazar-i-Sharif)">Blue Mosque</a> in Mazar-i-Sharif was built in the 15th century
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1219&nbsp;AD, <a href="/wiki/Genghis_Khan" title="Genghis Khan">Genghis Khan</a> and his <a href="/wiki/Mongol_conquest_of_the_Khwarazmian_Empire" title="Mongol conquest of the Khwarazmian Empire">Mongol army overran the region</a>. His troops are said to have annihilated the Khwarazmian cities of <a href="/wiki/Herat" title="Herat">Herat</a> and <a href="/wiki/Balkh" title="Balkh">Balkh</a> as well as <a href="/wiki/Bamyan,_Afghanistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Bamyan, Afghanistan">Bamyan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[58]</a></sup> The destruction caused by the Mongols forced many locals to return to an agrarian rural society.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[59]</a></sup> Mongol rule continued with the <a href="/wiki/Ilkhanate" title="Ilkhanate">Ilkhanate</a> in the northwest while the <a href="/wiki/Khalji_dynasty" title="Khalji dynasty">Khalji dynasty</a> administered the Afghan tribal areas south of the Hindu Kush until the invasion of <a href="/wiki/Timur" title="Timur">Timur</a> (aka Tamerlane), who established the <a href="/wiki/Timurid_Empire" title="Timurid Empire">Timurid Empire</a> in 1370. Under the rule of <a href="/wiki/Shah_Rukh" title="Shah Rukh">Shah Rukh</a> the city served as the focal point of the <a href="/wiki/Timurid_Renaissance" title="Timurid Renaissance">Timurid Renaissance</a>, whose glory matched <a href="/wiki/Florence" title="Florence">Florence</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Renaissance" title="Italian Renaissance">Italian Renaissance</a> as the center of a cultural rebirth.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[60]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[61]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the early 16th century, <a href="/wiki/Babur" title="Babur">Babur</a> arrived from <a href="/wiki/Ferghana" class="mw-redirect" title="Ferghana">Ferghana</a> and captured Kabul from the <a href="/wiki/Arghun_dynasty" title="Arghun dynasty">Arghun dynasty</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarfield201292â93_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarfield201292â93-64">[62]</a></sup> Between the 16th and 18th century, the Uzbek <a href="/wiki/Khanate_of_Bukhara" title="Khanate of Bukhara">Khanate of Bukhara</a>, Iranian <a href="/wiki/Safavids" class="mw-redirect" title="Safavids">Safavids</a>, and Indian <a href="/wiki/Mughals" class="mw-redirect" title="Mughals">Mughals</a> ruled parts of the territory.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDupree1997319,_321_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDupree1997319,_321-65">[63]</a></sup> During the Medieval Period, the northwestern area of Afghanistan was referred to by the regional name <a href="/wiki/Greater_Khorasan" title="Greater Khorasan">Khorasan</a>. Two of the four capitals of Khorasan (<a href="/wiki/Herat" title="Herat">Herat</a> and <a href="/wiki/Balkh" title="Balkh">Balkh</a>) are now located in Afghanistan, while the regions of <a href="/wiki/Kandahar_Province" title="Kandahar Province">Kandahar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zabulistan" title="Zabulistan">Zabulistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ghazni" title="Ghazni">Ghazni</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kabulistan" title="Kabulistan">Kabulistan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Afghanistan" title="Name of Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a> formed the <a href="/wiki/Frontier" title="Frontier">frontier</a> between Khorasan and <a href="/wiki/Hindustan" title="Hindustan">Hindustan</a>. However, up to the 19th century the term Khorasan was commonly used among natives to describe their country; <a href="/wiki/Sir_George_Elphinstone" class="mw-redirect" title="Sir George Elphinstone">Sir George Elphinstone</a> wrote with amazement that the country known to outsiders as "Afghanistan" was referred to by its own inhabitants as "Khorasan" and that the first Afghan official whom he met at the border welcomed him to Khorasan.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[64]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-EI_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EI-67">[65]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Routledge_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Routledge-68">[66]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Firishta_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Firishta-69">[67]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_history">Modern history</span></h3> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Hotak_and_Durrani_dynasties">Hotak and Durrani dynasties</span></h4> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Portrait_of_Ahmad-Shah_Durrani._Mughal_miniature._ca._1757,_Biblioth%C3%A8que_nationale_de_France.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Portrait_of_Ahmad-Shah_Durrani._Mughal_miniature._ca._1757%2C_Biblioth%C3%A8que_nationale_de_France.jpg/220px-Portrait_of_Ahmad-Shah_Durrani._Mughal_miniature._ca._1757%2C_Biblioth%C3%A8que_nationale_de_France.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="297" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Portrait_of_Ahmad-Shah_Durrani._Mughal_miniature._ca._1757%2C_Biblioth%C3%A8que_nationale_de_France.jpg/330px-Portrait_of_Ahmad-Shah_Durrani._Mughal_miniature._ca._1757%2C_Biblioth%C3%A8que_nationale_de_France.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Portrait_of_Ahmad-Shah_Durrani._Mughal_miniature._ca._1757%2C_Biblioth%C3%A8que_nationale_de_France.jpg/440px-Portrait_of_Ahmad-Shah_Durrani._Mughal_miniature._ca._1757%2C_Biblioth%C3%A8que_nationale_de_France.jpg 2x" data-file-width="933" data-file-height="1259"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Portrait_of_Ahmad-Shah_Durrani._Mughal_miniature._ca._1757,_Biblioth%C3%A8que_nationale_de_France.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Portrait of Ahmad Shah Durrani, c. 1757
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Hotak_dynasty" title="Hotak dynasty">Hotak dynasty</a> and <a href="/wiki/Durrani_Empire" title="Durrani Empire">Durrani Empire</a>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1709, <a href="/wiki/Mirwais_Hotak" title="Mirwais Hotak">Mirwais Hotak</a>, a local <a href="/wiki/Ghilzai" class="mw-redirect" title="Ghilzai">Ghilzai</a> tribal leader, successfully rebelled against the Safavids. He defeated <a href="/wiki/Gurgin_Khan" class="mw-redirect" title="Gurgin Khan">Gurgin Khan</a> and established his own kingdom.<sup id="cite_ref-Browne_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Browne-70">[68]</a></sup> Mirwais died of natural causes in 1715 and was succeeded by his brother <a href="/wiki/Abdul_Aziz_Hotak" title="Abdul Aziz Hotak">Abdul Aziz</a>, who was soon killed by Mirwais' son <a href="/wiki/Mahmud_Hotak" title="Mahmud Hotak">Mahmud</a> for treason. Mahmud led the Afghan army in 1722 to the Persian capital of <a href="/wiki/Isfahan" title="Isfahan">Isfahan</a>, captured the city after the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Gulnabad" title="Battle of Gulnabad">Battle of Gulnabad</a> and proclaimed himself King of Persia.<sup id="cite_ref-Browne_70-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Browne-70">[68]</a></sup> The Afghan dynasty was ousted from Persia by <a href="/wiki/Nader_Shah" title="Nader Shah">Nader Shah</a> after the 1729 <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Damghan_(1729)" title="Battle of Damghan (1729)">Battle of Damghan</a>. </p>
      <p>In 1738, Nader Shah and his <a href="/wiki/Afsharid_dynasty" title="Afsharid dynasty">forces</a> captured Kandahar, the last Hotak stronghold, from Shah <a href="/wiki/Hussain_Hotak" title="Hussain Hotak">Hussain Hotak</a>, at which point the incarcerated 16-year-old <a href="/wiki/Ahmad_Shah_Durrani" title="Ahmad Shah Durrani">Ahmad Shah Durrani</a> was freed and made the commander of an Afghan regiment. Soon after, the Persian and Afghan forces <a href="/wiki/Nader_Shah%27s_invasion_of_India" title="Nader Shah's invasion of India">invaded India</a>. By 1747, the <a href="/wiki/Afghans" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghans">Afghans</a> chose Durrani as their head of state.<sup id="cite_ref-Brit-Durrani_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brit-Durrani-71">[69]</a></sup> Durrani and his Afghan army conquered much of present-day Afghanistan, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Khorasan_Province" title="Khorasan Province">Khorasan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Quhistan" title="Quhistan">Kohistan</a> provinces of Iran, and Delhi in India.<sup id="cite_ref-Engels_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Engels-72">[70]</a></sup> He defeated the Indian <a href="/wiki/Maratha_Empire" title="Maratha Empire">Maratha Empire</a>, and one of his biggest victories was the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Panipat_(1761)" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Panipat (1761)">1761 Battle of Panipat</a>. </p>
      <p>In October 1772, Durrani died of natural causes and was buried at a site now adjacent to the <a href="/wiki/Shrine_of_the_Cloak" class="mw-redirect" title="Shrine of the Cloak">Shrine of the Cloak</a> in Kandahar. He was succeeded by his son, <a href="/wiki/Timur_Shah" class="mw-redirect" title="Timur Shah">Timur Shah</a>, who transferred the capital of his kingdom from Kandahar to Kabul in 1776, with <a href="/wiki/Peshawar" title="Peshawar">Peshawar</a> becoming the <a href="/wiki/Winter_capital" class="mw-redirect" title="Winter capital">winter capital</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cap1_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cap1-22">[20]</a></sup> After Timur's death in 1793, the Durrani throne passed down to his son <a href="/wiki/Zaman_Shah" class="mw-redirect" title="Zaman Shah">Zaman Shah</a>, followed by <a href="/wiki/Mahmud_Shah_Durrani" title="Mahmud Shah Durrani">Mahmud Shah</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shuja_Shah" class="mw-redirect" title="Shuja Shah">Shuja Shah</a> and others.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[71]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Barakzai_dynasty_and_British_wars">Barakzai dynasty and British wars</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/European_influence_in_Afghanistan" title="European influence in Afghanistan">European influence in Afghanistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Afghan_Wars" class="mw-redirect" title="Anglo-Afghan Wars">Anglo-Afghan Wars</a>, <a href="/wiki/Durand_Line" title="Durand Line">Durand Line</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Civil_War_(1928%E2%80%931929)" title="Afghan Civil War (1928â1929)">Afghan Civil War (1928â1929)</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Afghan_foot_soldiers_in_1841.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Afghan_foot_soldiers_in_1841.jpg/220px-Afghan_foot_soldiers_in_1841.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="167" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Afghan_foot_soldiers_in_1841.jpg/330px-Afghan_foot_soldiers_in_1841.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Afghan_foot_soldiers_in_1841.jpg/440px-Afghan_foot_soldiers_in_1841.jpg 2x" data-file-width="940" data-file-height="712"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Afghan_foot_soldiers_in_1841.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Afghan tribesmen in 1841, painted by British officer <a href="/wiki/James_Rattray" title="James Rattray">James Rattray</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Forces_from_British_India_camping_at_Kandahar.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Forces_from_British_India_camping_at_Kandahar.jpg/220px-Forces_from_British_India_camping_at_Kandahar.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="172" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Forces_from_British_India_camping_at_Kandahar.jpg/330px-Forces_from_British_India_camping_at_Kandahar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Forces_from_British_India_camping_at_Kandahar.jpg/440px-Forces_from_British_India_camping_at_Kandahar.jpg 2x" data-file-width="881" data-file-height="687"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kandahar-1881.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British</a> and <a href="/wiki/Afghan_National_Army" title="Afghan National Army">allied forces</a> at Kandahar after the 1880 <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kandahar" title="Battle of Kandahar">Battle of Kandahar</a>, during the <a href="/wiki/Second_Anglo-Afghan_War" title="Second Anglo-Afghan War">Second Anglo-Afghan War</a>. The large defensive wall around the city was removed in the early 1930s by order of <a href="/wiki/Mohammed_Nadir_Shah" title="Mohammed Nadir Shah">King Nadir</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>By the early 19th century, the Afghan empire was under threat from the <a href="/wiki/Qajar_dynasty" title="Qajar dynasty">Persians</a> in the west and the <a href="/wiki/Sikh_Empire" title="Sikh Empire">Sikh Empire</a> in the east. Fateh Khan, leader of the <a href="/wiki/Barakzai_dynasty" title="Barakzai dynasty">Barakzai tribe</a>, had installed 21 of his brothers in positions of power throughout the empire. After his death, they rebelled and divided up the provinces of the empire between themselves. During this turbulent period, Afghanistan had many temporary rulers until <a href="/wiki/Dost_Mohammad_Khan" title="Dost Mohammad Khan">Dost Mohammad Khan</a> declared himself emir in 1823.<sup id="cite_ref-Tanner_2009_126_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tanner_2009_126-74">[72]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Punjab" title="Punjab">Punjab</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kashmir" title="Kashmir">Kashmir</a> were lost to <a href="/wiki/Ranjit_Singh" title="Ranjit Singh">Ranjit Singh</a>, who invaded <a href="/wiki/Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa" title="Khyber Pakhtunkhwa">Khyber Pakhtunkhwa</a> in March 1823 and captured the city of <a href="/wiki/Peshawar" title="Peshawar">Peshawar</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Nowshera" title="Battle of Nowshera">Battle of Nowshera</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Nalwa_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nalwa-75">[73]</a></sup> In 1837, during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Jamrud" title="Battle of Jamrud">Battle of Jamrud</a> near the <a href="/wiki/Khyber_Pass" title="Khyber Pass">Khyber Pass</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wazir_Akbar_Khan" title="Wazir Akbar Khan">Akbar Khan</a> and the Afghan army failed to capture the <a href="/wiki/Jamrud_Fort" title="Jamrud Fort">Jamrud Fort</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Sikh_Khalsa_Army" title="Sikh Khalsa Army">Sikh Khalsa Army</a>, but killed Sikh Commander <a href="/wiki/Hari_Singh_Nalwa" title="Hari Singh Nalwa">Hari Singh Nalwa</a>, thus ending the <a href="/wiki/Afghan-Sikh_Wars" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan-Sikh Wars">Afghan-Sikh Wars</a>. By this time the British were advancing from the east and the <a href="/wiki/First_Anglo-Afghan_War" title="First Anglo-Afghan War">first major conflict</a> during "<a href="/wiki/The_Great_Game" title="The Great Game">The Great Game</a>" was initiated.<sup id="cite_ref-Chahryar_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chahryar-76">[74]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1838, the British marched into Afghanistan and arrested <a href="/wiki/Dost_Mohammad_Khan_(Emir_of_Afghanistan)" class="mw-redirect" title="Dost Mohammad Khan (Emir of Afghanistan)">Dost Mohammad</a>, sent him into exile in India and replaced him with the previous ruler, <a href="/wiki/Shah_Shuja_Durrani" class="mw-redirect" title="Shah Shuja Durrani">Shah Shuja</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ingram1980_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ingram1980-77">[75]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ingram1984_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ingram1984-78">[76]</a></sup> Following an uprising, the <a href="/wiki/1842_retreat_from_Kabul" title="1842 retreat from Kabul">1842 retreat from Kabul</a> of British-Indian forces and the annihilation of <a href="/wiki/William_George_Keith_Elphinstone" title="William George Keith Elphinstone">Elphinstone</a>'s army, and the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kabul_(1842)" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Kabul (1842)">Battle of Kabul</a> that led to its recapture, the British placed Dost Mohammad Khan back into power and withdrew their military forces from Afghanistan. In 1878, the <a href="/wiki/Second_Anglo-Afghan_War" title="Second Anglo-Afghan War">Second Anglo-Afghan War</a> was fought over perceived Russian influence, <a href="/wiki/Abdur_Rahman_Khan" title="Abdur Rahman Khan">Abdur Rahman Khan</a> replaced <a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Ayub_Khan_(Emir_of_Afghanistan)" class="mw-redirect" title="Mohammad Ayub Khan (Emir of Afghanistan)">Ayub Khan</a>, and Britain gained control of Afghanistan's foreign relations as part of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Gandamak" title="Treaty of Gandamak">Treaty of Gandamak</a> of 1879. In 1893, Amir Abdur Rahman signed an agreement in which the ethnic <a href="/wiki/Pashtun" class="mw-redirect" title="Pashtun">Pashtun</a> and <a href="/wiki/Baloch_people" title="Baloch people">Baloch</a> territories were divided by the <a href="/wiki/Durand_Line" title="Durand Line">Durand Line</a>. This was a standard <a href="/wiki/Divide_and_rule" title="Divide and rule">divide and rule</a> policy of the British and woul, especially with newly-formed state of Pakistan. <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam_in_Afghanistan" title="Shia Islam in Afghanistan">Shia</a>-dominated <a href="/wiki/Hazarajat" title="Hazarajat">Hazarajat</a> and pagan <a href="/wiki/Kafiristan" title="Kafiristan">Kafiristan</a> remained politically independent until being <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquests_of_Afghanistan" title="Muslim conquests of Afghanistan">conquered</a> by Abdur Rahman Khan in 1891â1896. He was known as the "Iron Amir" for his features and his ruthless methods against tribes.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[77]</a></sup> The <i>Iron Amir</i> viewed railway and telegraph lines coming from the Russian and British empires as "<a href="/wiki/Trojan_horse" class="mw-redirect" title="Trojan horse">trojan horses</a>" and therefore prevented railway development in Afghanistan.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[78]</a></sup> He died in 1901, replaced by his son <a href="/wiki/Habibullah_Khan" title="Habibullah Khan">Habibullah Khan</a>. </p>
      <p>During <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>, when Afghanistan was neutral, Habibullah Khan was met by officials of the Central Powers in the <a href="/wiki/Niedermayer%E2%80%93Hentig_Expedition" title="NiedermayerâHentig Expedition">NiedermayerâHentig Expedition</a>, to declare full independence from the United Kingdom, join them and attack British India, as part of the <a href="/wiki/Hindu%E2%80%93German_Conspiracy" title="HinduâGerman Conspiracy">HinduâGerman Conspiracy</a>. Their efforts to bring Afghanistan into the Central Powers failed, but it caused discontent among the population for keeping neutrality against the British. Habibullah was assassinated during a hunting trip in 1919, and <a href="/wiki/Amanullah_Khan" title="Amanullah Khan">Amanullah Khan</a> eventually assumed power. A staunch supporter of the 1915â1916 expeditions, Amanullah Khan evoked the <a href="/wiki/Third_Anglo-Afghan_War" title="Third Anglo-Afghan War">Third Anglo-Afghan War</a>, entering British India via the <a href="/wiki/Khyber_Pass" title="Khyber Pass">Khyber Pass</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[79]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:King_Amanullah_standing.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/King_Amanullah_standing.jpg/170px-King_Amanullah_standing.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="277" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/King_Amanullah_standing.jpg/255px-King_Amanullah_standing.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/King_Amanullah_standing.jpg/340px-King_Amanullah_standing.jpg 2x" data-file-width="399" data-file-height="651"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:King_Amanullah_standing.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>King <a href="/wiki/Amanullah_Khan" title="Amanullah Khan">Amanullah Khan</a> invaded British India in 1919 and proclaimed Afghanistan's full independence thereafter.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>After the end Third Anglo-Afghan War and the signing of the <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Afghan_Treaty_of_1919" title="Anglo-Afghan Treaty of 1919">Treaty of Rawalpindi</a> on 19 August 1919, King Amanullah Khan declared Afghanistan a <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state">sovereign</a> and fully <a href="/wiki/Independent_state" class="mw-redirect" title="Independent state">independent state</a>. He moved to end his country's traditional isolation by establishing diplomatic relations with the international community, particularly with the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Weimar_Republic" title="Weimar Republic">Weimar Republic</a> of Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[80]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[81]</a></sup> Following a 1927â28 tour of Europe and <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a>, he introduced several reforms intended to modernize his nation. A key force behind these reforms was <a href="/wiki/Mahmud_Tarzi" title="Mahmud Tarzi">Mahmud Tarzi</a>, an ardent supporter of the education of women. He fought for Article 68 of Afghanistan's 1923 <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Afghanistan" title="Constitution of Afghanistan">constitution</a>, which made elementary education compulsory. The institution of <a href="/wiki/Slavery" title="Slavery">slavery</a> was abolished in 1923.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[82]</a></sup> Khan's wife Queen <a href="/wiki/Soraya_Tarzi" title="Soraya Tarzi">Soraya Tarzi</a> was a figure during this period. </p>
      <p>Some of the reforms that were put in place, such as the abolition of the traditional <a href="/wiki/Burqa" title="Burqa">burqa</a> for women and the opening of several co-educational schools, quickly alienated many tribal and religious leaders, and this led to the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Civil_War_(1928%E2%80%931929)" title="Afghan Civil War (1928â1929)">Afghan Civil War (1928â1929)</a>. Faced with the overwhelming armed opposition, Amanullah Khan abdicated in January 1929, and soon after Kabul fell to <a href="/wiki/Saqqawist" class="mw-redirect" title="Saqqawist">Saqqawist</a> forces led by <a href="/wiki/Habibullah_Kalakani" class="mw-redirect" title="Habibullah Kalakani">Habibullah Kalakani</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[83]</a></sup> Prince <a href="/wiki/Mohammed_Nadir_Shah" title="Mohammed Nadir Shah">Mohammed Nadir Shah</a>, Amanullah's cousin, in turn defeated and killed Kalakani in October 1929, and was declared King Nadir Shah.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[84]</a></sup> He abandoned the reforms of Amanullah Khan in favor of a more gradual approach to modernization but was assassinated in 1933 by <a href="/wiki/Abdul_Khaliq_Hazara_(assassin)" title="Abdul Khaliq Hazara (assassin)">Abdul Khaliq</a>, a fifteen-year-old <a href="/wiki/Hazara_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Hazara people">Hazara</a> student who was an <a href="/wiki/Amanullah_loyalist" class="mw-redirect" title="Amanullah loyalist">Amanullah loyalist</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[85]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Mohammed_Zahir_Shah" title="Mohammed Zahir Shah">Mohammed Zahir Shah</a>, Nadir Shah's 19-year-old son, succeeded to the throne and reigned from 1933 to 1973. The <a href="/wiki/Afghan_tribal_revolts_of_1944%E2%80%931947" title="Afghan tribal revolts of 1944â1947">tribal revolts of 1944â1947</a> saw Zahir Shah's reign being challenged by <a href="/wiki/Zadran_(Pashtun_tribe)" title="Zadran (Pashtun tribe)">Zadran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Safi_(Pashtun_tribe)" title="Safi (Pashtun tribe)">Safi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mangal_(Pashtun_tribe)" title="Mangal (Pashtun tribe)">Mangal</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wazir_(Pashtun_tribe)" title="Wazir (Pashtun tribe)">Wazir</a> tribesmen led by <a href="/wiki/Mazrak_Zadran" title="Mazrak Zadran">Mazrak Zadran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salemai" title="Salemai">Salemai</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Faqir_Ipi" title="Faqir Ipi">Mirzali Khan</a>, among others, many of whom were <a href="/wiki/Amanullah_loyalist" class="mw-redirect" title="Amanullah loyalist">Amanullah loyalists</a>. Close relations with the Muslim states <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Iraq" title="Kingdom of Iraq">Kingdom of Iraq</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pahlavi_dynasty" title="Pahlavi dynasty">Iran/Persia</a> were also pursued, while further international relations were sought by joining the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> in 1934. The 1930s saw the development of roads, infrastructure, the founding of a <a href="/wiki/Da_Afghanistan_Bank" title="Da Afghanistan Bank">national bank</a>, and increased education. Road links in the north played a large part in a growing cotton and textile industry.<sup id="cite_ref-Eur2002_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eur2002-88">[86]</a></sup> The country built close relationships with the <a href="/wiki/Axis_powers" title="Axis powers">Axis powers</a>, with Germany having the largest share in Afghan development at the time, along with <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan-Italy_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghanistan-Italy relations">Italy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan-Japan_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghanistan-Japan relations">Japan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Hyman2016_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hyman2016-89">[87]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Contemporary_history">Contemporary history</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Zahir_Shah_of_Afghanistan_in_1930s-cropped.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Zahir_Shah_of_Afghanistan_in_1930s-cropped.jpg/170px-Zahir_Shah_of_Afghanistan_in_1930s-cropped.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="255" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Zahir_Shah_of_Afghanistan_in_1930s-cropped.jpg/255px-Zahir_Shah_of_Afghanistan_in_1930s-cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/ad/Zahir_Shah_of_Afghanistan_in_1930s-cropped.jpg 2x" data-file-width="320" data-file-height="480"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Zahir_Shah_of_Afghanistan_in_1930s-cropped.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Mohammed_Zahir_Shah" title="Mohammed Zahir Shah">Zahir Shah</a>, the last king of Afghanistan, who reigned from 1933 to 1973.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Until 1946, Zahir Shah ruled with the assistance of his uncle, who held the post of <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Afghanistan" title="Prime Minister of Afghanistan">Prime Minister</a> and continued the policies of Nadir Shah. Another of Zahir Shah's uncles, <a href="/wiki/Shah_Mahmud_Khan" title="Shah Mahmud Khan">Shah Mahmud Khan</a>, became Prime Minister in 1946 and began an experiment allowing greater political freedom, but reversed the policy when it went further than he expected. He was replaced in 1953 by <a href="/wiki/Mohammed_Daoud_Khan" title="Mohammed Daoud Khan">Mohammed Daoud Khan</a>, the king's cousin and brother-in-law, and a <a href="/wiki/Pashtun" class="mw-redirect" title="Pashtun">Pashtun</a> nationalist who sought the creation of a <a href="/wiki/Pashtunistan" title="Pashtunistan">Pashtunistan</a>, leading to highly tense relations with Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[88]</a></sup> During his ten years at the post until 1963, Daoud Khan pressed for social modernization reforms and sought a closer relationship with the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>. Afterward, the <a href="/wiki/1964_Constitution_of_Afghanistan" title="1964 Constitution of Afghanistan">1964 constitution</a> was formed, and the first non-royal Prime Minister was sworn in.<sup id="cite_ref-Eur2002_88-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eur2002-88">[86]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>King Zahir Shah, like his father Nadir Shah, had a policy of maintaining national independence while pursuing gradual modernization, creating nationalist feeling, and improving relations with the United Kingdom. However, Afghanistan remained neutral and was neither a participant in <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> nor aligned with either power bloc in the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> thereafter. However, it was a beneficiary of the latter rivalry as both the Soviet Union and the United States vied for influence by building Afghanistan's main highways, airports, and other vital infrastructure in the post-period. On a per capita basis, Afghanistan received more Soviet <a href="/wiki/Development_aid" title="Development aid">development aid</a> than any other country. Afghanistan had, therefore, good relations with both Cold War enemies. In 1973, while the King was in Italy, Daoud Khan launched a <a href="/wiki/1973_Afghan_coup" class="mw-redirect" title="1973 Afghan coup">bloodless coup</a> and became the first <a href="/wiki/President_of_Afghanistan" title="President of Afghanistan">President of Afghanistan</a>, abolishing the monarchy. </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Democratic_Republic_regime_and_Soviet_war">Democratic Republic regime and Soviet war</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_Afghanistan" title="Democratic Republic of Afghanistan">Democratic Republic of Afghanistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Afghan_War" title="SovietâAfghan War">SovietâAfghan War</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Civil_War_(1989%E2%80%9392)" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan Civil War (1989â92)">Afghan Civil War (1989â92)</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Afghanistan_(1978%E2%80%9392)" class="mw-redirect" title="History of Afghanistan (1978â92)">History of Afghanistan (1978â92)</a>
      </div>
