      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:358px;max-width:358px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Afgan1987_Gardez_UAZ469.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Afgan1987_Gardez_UAZ469.jpg/200px-Afgan1987_Gardez_UAZ469.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="138" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Afgan1987_Gardez_UAZ469.jpg/300px-Afgan1987_Gardez_UAZ469.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Afgan1987_Gardez_UAZ469.jpg/400px-Afgan1987_Gardez_UAZ469.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5328" data-file-height="3663"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Soviet troops in <a href="/wiki/Gardez" title="Gardez">Gardez</a>, Afghanistan in 1987
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:152px;max-width:152px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Jamiat_e-Islami_in_Shultan_Valley_1987_with_Dashaka.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Jamiat_e-Islami_in_Shultan_Valley_1987_with_Dashaka.jpg/150px-Jamiat_e-Islami_in_Shultan_Valley_1987_with_Dashaka.jpg" decoding="async" width="150" height="167" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Jamiat_e-Islami_in_Shultan_Valley_1987_with_Dashaka.jpg/225px-Jamiat_e-Islami_in_Shultan_Valley_1987_with_Dashaka.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Jamiat_e-Islami_in_Shultan_Valley_1987_with_Dashaka.jpg/300px-Jamiat_e-Islami_in_Shultan_Valley_1987_with_Dashaka.jpg 2x" data-file-width="720" data-file-height="801"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Hezb-i_Islami_Khalis" title="Hezb-i Islami Khalis">Hezb-i Islami Khalis</a> fighters in the Sultan Valley of <a href="/wiki/Kunar_Province" title="Kunar Province">Kunar Province</a>, 1987
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In April 1978, the communist <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Democratic_Party_of_Afghanistan" title="People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan">People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan</a> (PDPA) seized power in a bloody coup d'Ã©tat against then-President <a href="/wiki/Mohammed_Daoud_Khan" title="Mohammed Daoud Khan">Mohammed Daoud Khan</a>, in what is called the <a href="/wiki/Saur_Revolution" title="Saur Revolution">Saur Revolution</a>. The PDPA declared the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_Afghanistan" title="Democratic Republic of Afghanistan">Democratic Republic of Afghanistan</a>, with its first leader named as <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Democratic_Party_of_Afghanistan" title="People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan">People's Democratic Party</a> general secretary <a href="/wiki/Nur_Muhammad_Taraki" title="Nur Muhammad Taraki">Nur Muhammad Taraki</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEwans2002186-88_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEwans2002186-88-91">[89]</a></sup> This would trigger a series of events that would dramatically turn Afghanistan from a poor and secluded (albeit peaceful) country to a hotbed of international terrorism.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[90]</a></sup> The PDPA initiated various social, symbolic and land distribution reforms that provoked strong opposition, while also brutally oppressing political dissidents. This caused unrest and quickly expanded into a state of <a href="/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(1978%E2%80%93present)" class="mw-redirect" title="War in Afghanistan (1978âpresent)">civil war</a> by 1979, waged by guerrilla <i><a href="/wiki/Mujahideen" title="Mujahideen">mujahideen</a></i> (and smaller <a href="/wiki/Maoist" class="mw-redirect" title="Maoist">Maoist</a> guerillas) against regime forces countrywide. It quickly turned into a <a href="/wiki/Proxy_war" title="Proxy war">proxy war</a> as the Pakistani government provided these rebels with covert training centers, the United States <a href="/wiki/Operation_Cyclone" title="Operation Cyclone">supported</a> them through Pakistan's <a href="/wiki/Inter-Services_Intelligence" title="Inter-Services Intelligence">Inter-Services Intelligence</a> (ISI),<sup id="cite_ref-Meher_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Meher-93">[91]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> sent thousands of military advisers to support the PDPA regime.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[92]</a></sup> Meanwhile, there was increasingly hostile friction between the competing factions of the PDPA&nbsp;â the dominant <a href="/wiki/Khalq" title="Khalq">Khalq</a> and the more moderate <a href="/wiki/Parcham" title="Parcham">Parcham</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[93]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In September 1979, PDPA General Secretary Taraki was assassinated in an internal coup orchestrated by fellow Khalq member, then-Prime minister <a href="/wiki/Hafizullah_Amin" title="Hafizullah Amin">Hafizullah Amin</a>, who assumed the new general secretary of the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Democratic_Party_of_Afghanistan" title="People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan">People's Democratic Party</a>. The situation in the country deteriorated under Amin and thousands of people went missing.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[94]</a></sup> Displeased with Amin's government, the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Army" title="Soviet Army">Soviet Army</a> invaded the country in December 1979, heading for Kabul and killing Amin just 3 days later.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarfield2012234_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarfield2012234-97">[95]</a></sup> A Soviet-organized regime, led by Parcham's <a href="/wiki/Babrak_Karmal" title="Babrak Karmal">Babrak Karmal</a> but inclusive of both factions (Parcham and Khalq), filled the vacuum. Soviet troops in more substantial numbers were deployed to stabilize Afghanistan under Karmal, marking the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Afghan_War" title="SovietâAfghan War">SovietâAfghan War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[96]</a></sup> The United States and Pakistan,<sup id="cite_ref-Meher_93-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Meher-93">[91]</a></sup> along with smaller actors like <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a> and <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, continued supporting the rebels, delivering billions of dollars in cash and weapons including two thousand <a href="/wiki/FIM-92_Stinger" title="FIM-92 Stinger">FIM-92 Stinger</a> <a href="/wiki/Surface-to-air_missiles" class="mw-redirect" title="Surface-to-air missiles">surface-to-air missiles</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Brunei_Times_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Brunei_Times-99">[97]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_Nation_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Nation-100">[98]</a></sup> Lasting nine years, the war caused the deaths of between 562,000<sup id="cite_ref-562k_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-562k-101">[99]</a></sup> and 2&nbsp;million Afghans,<sup id="cite_ref-Kakar_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kakar-102">[100]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[101]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Reisman_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reisman-104">[102]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[103]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Soviet-war-video_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Soviet-war-video-106">[104]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-landmines_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-landmines-107">[105]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[106]</a></sup> and displaced about 6&nbsp;million people who subsequently fled Afghanistan, mainly to <a href="/wiki/Afghans_in_Pakistan" title="Afghans in Pakistan">Pakistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Afghans_in_Iran" title="Afghans in Iran">Iran</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[107]</a></sup> Heavy air bombardment destroyed many countryside villages, millions of <a href="/wiki/Landmine" class="mw-redirect" title="Landmine">landmines</a> were planted,<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[108]</a></sup> and some cities such as <a href="/wiki/Herat" title="Herat">Herat</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kandahar" title="Kandahar">Kandahar</a> were also damaged from bombardment. Pakistan's <a href="/wiki/Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa" title="Khyber Pakhtunkhwa">North-West Frontier Province</a> functioned as an organisational and networking base for the anti-Soviet Afghan resistance, with the province's influential <a href="/wiki/Deobandi" title="Deobandi">Deobandi</a> ulama playing a major supporting role in promoting the 'jihad'.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[109]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_withdrawal_from_Afghanistan" title="Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan">Soviet withdrawal</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Civil_War_(1989-92)" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan Civil War (1989-92)">civil war ensued</a> until the communist regime under People's Democratic Party leader <a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Najibullah" title="Mohammad Najibullah">Mohammad Najibullah</a> collapsed in 1992.<sup id="cite_ref-Columbia:Afghanistan:History_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Columbia:Afghanistan:History-112">[110]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Stenersen_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stenersen-113">[111]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarfield2012239,_244_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarfield2012239,_244-114">[112]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-Cold_War_conflict_and_Taliban_regime">Post-Cold War conflict and Taliban regime</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Civil_War_(1992%E2%80%9396)" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan Civil War (1992â96)">Afghan Civil War (1992â96)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Civil_War_(1996%E2%80%932001)" title="Afghan Civil War (1996â2001)">Afghan Civil War (1996â2001)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taliban" title="Taliban">Taliban</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Northern_Alliance" title="Northern Alliance">Northern Alliance</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:War_in_Afganistan_(1992%E2%80%932001).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/War_in_Afganistan_%281992%E2%80%932001%29.png/330px-War_in_Afganistan_%281992%E2%80%932001%29.png" decoding="async" width="330" height="268" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/War_in_Afganistan_%281992%E2%80%932001%29.png/495px-War_in_Afganistan_%281992%E2%80%932001%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/War_in_Afganistan_%281992%E2%80%932001%29.png/660px-War_in_Afganistan_%281992%E2%80%932001%29.png 2x" data-file-width="1489" data-file-height="1207"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:War_in_Afganistan_(1992%E2%80%932001).png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Development of the civil war from 1992 to late 2001
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Another civil war broke out after the <a href="/wiki/Peshawar_Accords" class="mw-redirect" title="Peshawar Accords">creation</a> of a dysfunctional coalition <a href="/wiki/Islamic_State_of_Afghanistan" title="Islamic State of Afghanistan">government</a> between leaders of various <i>mujahideen</i> factions. Amid a state of <a href="/wiki/Anarchy" title="Anarchy">anarchy</a> and factional infighting,<sup id="cite_ref-Amin_Saikal_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Amin_Saikal-115">[113]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Human_Rights_Watch_(4)_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Human_Rights_Watch_(4)-116">[114]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Roy_Gutman_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Roy_Gutman-117">[115]</a></sup> various <i>mujahideen</i> factions committed widespread rape, murder and extortion,<sup id="cite_ref-Human_Rights_Watch_(4)_116-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Human_Rights_Watch_(4)-116">[114]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Afghanistan_Justice_Project_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Afghanistan_Justice_Project-118">[116]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Human_Rights_Watch_(5)_119-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Human_Rights_Watch_(5)-119">[117]</a></sup> while Kabul was heavily bombarded and partially destroyed by the fighting.<sup id="cite_ref-Human_Rights_Watch_(5)_119-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Human_Rights_Watch_(5)-119">[117]</a></sup> Several failed reconciliations and alliances occurred between different leaders.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[118]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Taliban" title="Taliban">Taliban</a> emerged in September 1994 as a movement and militia of students (<i>talib</i>) from Islamic <a href="/wiki/Madrassas_in_Pakistan" title="Madrassas in Pakistan">madrassas (schools) in Pakistan</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Human_Rights_Watch_(5)_119-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Human_Rights_Watch_(5)-119">[117]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Matinuddin,_Kamal_1999_pp.25_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Matinuddin,_Kamal_1999_pp.25-121">[119]</a></sup> who soon had military support from Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-George_Washington_University_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-George_Washington_University-122">[120]</a></sup> Taking control of <a href="/wiki/Kandahar" title="Kandahar">Kandahar</a> city that year,<sup id="cite_ref-Human_Rights_Watch_(5)_119-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Human_Rights_Watch_(5)-119">[117]</a></sup> they conquered more territories until finally driving out the government of <a href="/wiki/Burhanuddin_Rabbani" title="Burhanuddin Rabbani">Rabbani</a> from Kabul in 1996,<sup id="cite_ref-IRB,_Can.,1997_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IRB,_Can.,1997-123">[121]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[122]</a></sup> where they established an <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Emirate_of_Afghanistan" title="Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan">emirate</a> that gained international recognition from only three countries.<sup id="cite_ref-c-profile_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-c-profile-125">[123]</a></sup> The Taliban were condemned internationally for the harsh enforcement of their interpretation of Islamic <a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">sharia</a> law, which resulted in the brutal treatment of many Afghans, especially <a href="/wiki/Taliban_treatment_of_women" title="Taliban treatment of women">women</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Skain_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Skain-126">[124]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[125]</a></sup> During their rule, the Taliban and their allies committed massacres against Afghan civilians, denied UN food supplies to starving civilians and conducted a policy of <a href="/wiki/Scorched_earth" title="Scorched earth">scorched earth</a>, burning vast areas of fertile land and destroying tens of thousands of homes.<sup id="cite_ref-Rashid2_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rashid2-128">[126]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Newsday_2001_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Newsday_2001-129">[127]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-papillonsartpalace.com_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-papillonsartpalace.com-130">[128]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[129]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[130]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NPR_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NPR-133">[131]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kabul_(1992%E2%80%9396)" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Kabul (1992â96)">After the fall of Kabul</a> to the Taliban, <a href="/wiki/Ahmad_Shah_Massoud" title="Ahmad Shah Massoud">Ahmad Shah Massoud</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abdul_Rashid_Dostum" title="Abdul Rashid Dostum">Abdul Rashid Dostum</a> formed the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Alliance" title="Northern Alliance">Northern Alliance</a>, later joined by others, to resist the Taliban. Dostum's forces were defeated by the Taliban during the <a href="/wiki/Battles_of_Mazar-i-Sharif_(1997%E2%80%9398)" title="Battles of Mazar-i-Sharif (1997â98)">Battles of Mazar-i-Sharif (1997â98)</a>; Pakistan's Chief of Army Staff, <a href="/wiki/Pervez_Musharraf" title="Pervez Musharraf">Pervez Musharraf</a>, began sending thousands of Pakistanis to help the Taliban defeat the Northern Alliance.<sup id="cite_ref-Webster_University_Press_Book_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Webster_University_Press_Book-134">[132]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-George_Washington_University_122-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-George_Washington_University-122">[120]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-History_Commons_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-History_Commons-135">[133]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Maley_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Maley-136">[134]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ahmed_Rashid/The_Telegraph_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ahmed_Rashid/The_Telegraph-137">[135]</a></sup> By 2000 the Northern Alliance only controlled 10% of territory, cornered in the north-east. On 9 September 2001, Massoud was assassinated by two Arab <a href="/wiki/Suicide_attack" title="Suicide attack">suicide attackers</a> in <a href="/wiki/Panjshir_Valley" title="Panjshir Valley">Panjshir Valley</a>. Around 400,000 Afghans died in internal conflicts between 1990 and 2001.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[136]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In October 2001, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_invasion_of_Afghanistan" title="United States invasion of Afghanistan">United States invaded Afghanistan</a> to remove the Taliban from power after they refused to hand over <a href="/wiki/Osama_Bin_Laden" class="mw-redirect" title="Osama Bin Laden">Osama Bin Laden</a>, the prime suspect of the <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11 attacks</a>, who was a "guest" of the Taliban and was operating his <a href="/wiki/Al-Qaeda" title="Al-Qaeda">al-Qaeda</a> network in Afghanistan.<sup id="cite_ref-CNN_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNN-139">[137]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[138]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[139]</a></sup> The majority of Afghans supported the American invasion of their country.<sup id="cite_ref-Rejects_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rejects-142">[140]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Public_Opinion_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Public_Opinion-143">[141]</a></sup> During the initial invasion, US and UK forces bombed al-Qaeda training camps, and later working with the Northern Alliance, the Taliban regime came to an end.<sup id="cite_ref-NYTOct8_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTOct8-144">[142]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-2001">Post-2001</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%93present)" title="War in Afghanistan (2001âpresent)">War in Afghanistan (2001âpresent)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taliban_insurgency" title="Taliban insurgency">Taliban insurgency</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Reconstruction_in_Afghanistan" title="Reconstruction in Afghanistan">Reconstruction in Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Hamid_Karzai_2006-09-26.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Hamid_Karzai_2006-09-26.jpg/200px-Hamid_Karzai_2006-09-26.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="180" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Hamid_Karzai_2006-09-26.jpg/300px-Hamid_Karzai_2006-09-26.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c2/Hamid_Karzai_2006-09-26.jpg 2x" data-file-width="400" data-file-height="360"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Hamid_Karzai_2006-09-26.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Hamid_Karzai" title="Hamid Karzai">Hamid Karzai</a> was the leader of the country from 2001 to 2014
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Inbound_Choppers_in_Afghanistan_2008.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Inbound_Choppers_in_Afghanistan_2008.jpg/220px-Inbound_Choppers_in_Afghanistan_2008.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Inbound_Choppers_in_Afghanistan_2008.jpg/330px-Inbound_Choppers_in_Afghanistan_2008.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Inbound_Choppers_in_Afghanistan_2008.jpg/440px-Inbound_Choppers_in_Afghanistan_2008.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1800" data-file-height="1205"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Inbound_Choppers_in_Afghanistan_2008.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>U.S. troops and Air Force choppers in Afghanistan, 2008
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In December 2001, after the Taliban government was overthrown, the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Interim_Administration" title="Afghan Interim Administration">Afghan Interim Administration</a> under <a href="/wiki/Hamid_Karzai" title="Hamid Karzai">Hamid Karzai</a> was formed. The <a href="/wiki/International_Security_Assistance_Force" title="International Security Assistance Force">International Security Assistance Force</a> (ISAF) was established by the <a href="/wiki/UN_Security_Council" class="mw-redirect" title="UN Security Council">UN Security Council</a> to help assist the <a href="/wiki/Karzai_administration" class="mw-redirect" title="Karzai administration">Karzai administration</a> and provide basic security.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[143]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[144]</a></sup> By this time, after two decades of war as well as an acute <a href="/wiki/Famine" title="Famine">famine</a> at the time, Afghanistan had one of the highest <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">infant</a> and child mortality rates in the world, the lowest life expectancy, much of the population were hungry,<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[145]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[146]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[147]</a></sup> and infrastructure was in ruins.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[148]</a></sup> Many foreign donors started providing aid and assistance to rebuild the war-torn country.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[149]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[150]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Taliban forces meanwhile began regrouping inside Pakistan, while more coalition troops entered Afghanistan to help the rebuilding process.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[151]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[152]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Taliban_insurgency" title="Taliban insurgency">Taliban began an insurgency</a> to regain control of Afghanistan. Over the next decade, ISAF and <a href="/wiki/Afghan_National_Army" title="Afghan National Army">Afghan troops</a> led many offensives against the Taliban, but failed to fully defeat them. Afghanistan remains one of the poorest countries in the world because of a lack of foreign investment, <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Afghanistan" title="Corruption in Afghanistan">government corruption</a>, and the Taliban insurgency.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[153]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[154]</a></sup> Meanwhile, Karzai attempted to unite the peoples of the country,<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[155]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_government" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan government">Afghan government</a> was able to build some democratic structures, adopting a constitution in 2004 with the name Islamic Republic of Afghanistan. Attempts were made, often with the support of foreign donor countries, to improve the country's economy, healthcare, education, transport, and agriculture. ISAF forces also began to train the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_National_Security_Forces" title="Afghan National Security Forces">Afghan National Security Forces</a>. Following 2002, nearly five million <a href="/wiki/Afghan_diaspora" title="Afghan diaspora">Afghans</a> were <a href="/wiki/Repatriated" class="mw-redirect" title="Repatriated">repatriated</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Adelman2016_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Adelman2016-158">[156]</a></sup> The number of NATO troops present in Afghanistan peaked at 140,000 in 2011,<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[157]</a></sup> dropping to about 16,000 in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[158]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In September 2014 <a href="/wiki/Ashraf_Ghani" title="Ashraf Ghani">Ashraf Ghani</a> became president after the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_presidential_election,_2014" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan presidential election, 2014">2014 presidential election</a> where for the first time in Afghanistan's history power was democratically transferred.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[159]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[160]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[161]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[162]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[163]</a></sup> On 28 December 2014, NATO formally ended ISAF combat operations in Afghanistan and transferred full security responsibility to the Afghan government. The NATO-led <a href="/wiki/Operation_Resolute_Support" class="mw-redirect" title="Operation Resolute Support">Operation Resolute Support</a> was formed the same day as a successor to ISAF.<sup id="cite_ref-2014APcessation_166-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2014APcessation-166">[164]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Guardian28_167-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian28-167">[165]</a></sup> Thousands of NATO troops remained in the country to train and advise Afghan government forces<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[166]</a></sup> and continue their fight against the Taliban.<sup id="cite_ref-soufangroup_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-soufangroup-169">[167]</a></sup> It was estimated in 2015 that "about 147,000 people have been killed in the Afghanistan war since 2001. More than 38,000 of those killed have been civilians".<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[168]</a></sup> A report titled <i>Body Count</i> concluded that 106,000â170,000 civilians have been killed as a result of the fighting in Afghanistan at the hands of all parties to the conflict.<sup id="cite_ref-IPPNW_171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IPPNW-171">[169]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Afghanistan" title="Geography of Afghanistan">Geography of Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Afghanistan_physical_en.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Afghanistan_physical_en.png/290px-Afghanistan_physical_en.png" decoding="async" width="290" height="227" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Afghanistan_physical_en.png/435px-Afghanistan_physical_en.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Afghanistan_physical_en.png/580px-Afghanistan_physical_en.png 2x" data-file-width="2079" data-file-height="1624"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Afghanistan_physical_en.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Topography
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p> Afghanistan is located in Southern-Central Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-South_Asia_172-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-South_Asia-172">[170]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-UNdata_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNdata-173">[171]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_174-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-174">[172]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[173]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[174]</a></sup> indeed the region particularly centered at Afghanistan is considered the "crossroads of Asia",<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[175]</a></sup> and the country has had the nickname Heart of Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[176]</a></sup> The renowned <a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a> poet <a href="/wiki/Allama_Iqbal" class="mw-redirect" title="Allama Iqbal">Allama Iqbal</a> once wrote about the country:<br>
       <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942"></p>
      <blockquote class="templatequote">
       <p>Asia is a body of water and earth, of which the Afghan nation is the heart. From its discord, the discord of Asia; and from its accord, the accord of Asia.</p>
      </blockquote> 
      <p>At over 652,230&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (251,830&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi),<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[177]</a></sup> Afghanistan is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">41st largest country</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[178]</a></sup> slightly bigger than France and smaller than Myanmar, and about the size of Texas in the United States. There is no coastline, as Afghanistan is <a href="/wiki/Landlocked" class="mw-redirect" title="Landlocked">landlocked</a>. It shares borders with Pakistan in the south and east (including Indian-claimed <a href="/wiki/Gilgit-Baltistan" title="Gilgit-Baltistan">Gilgit-Baltistan</a>); Iran in the west; Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, and Tajikistan in the north; and China in the far east.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[179]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The geography in Afghanistan is varied, but is mostly mountainous and rugged, with some unusual mountain ridges accompanied by plateaus and river basins.<sup id="cite_ref-auto7_182-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto7-182">[180]</a></sup> It is dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Kush" title="Hindu Kush">Hindu Kush</a> range, the western extension of the <a href="/wiki/Himalayas" title="Himalayas">Himalayas</a> that stretches to eastern <a href="/wiki/Tibet" title="Tibet">Tibet</a> via the <a href="/wiki/Pamir_Mountains" title="Pamir Mountains">Pamir Mountains</a> and <a href="/wiki/Karakoram_Mountains" class="mw-redirect" title="Karakoram Mountains">Karakoram Mountains</a> in Afghanistan's far north-east. Most of the highest points are in the east consisting of fertile mountain valleys. The Hindu Kush ends at the west-central highlands, creating plains in the north and southwest, namely the <a href="/wiki/Turkestan" title="Turkestan">Turkestan</a> Plains and the <a href="/wiki/Sistan_Basin" title="Sistan Basin">Sistan Basin</a>; these two regions consist of rolling grasslands and semi-deserts, and hot windy deserts, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[181]</a></sup> Forests exist in the corridor between <a href="/wiki/Nuristan" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuristan">Nuristan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paktika" class="mw-redirect" title="Paktika">Paktika</a> provinces,<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[182]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Tundra" title="Tundra">tundra</a> in the north-east. The country's highest point is <a href="/wiki/Noshaq" title="Noshaq">Noshaq</a>, at 7,492&nbsp;m (24,580&nbsp;ft) above sea level.<sup id="cite_ref-Factbook_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Factbook-10">[9]</a></sup> The lowest point lies in <a href="/wiki/Jowzjan_Province" title="Jowzjan Province">Jowzjan Province</a> along the Amu River bank, at 258&nbsp;m (846&nbsp;ft) above sea level. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:272px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Aerial_photograph_of_Kandahar_Province_in_2011.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Aerial_photograph_of_Kandahar_Province_in_2011.jpg/270px-Aerial_photograph_of_Kandahar_Province_in_2011.jpg" decoding="async" width="270" height="179" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Aerial_photograph_of_Kandahar_Province_in_2011.jpg/405px-Aerial_photograph_of_Kandahar_Province_in_2011.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Aerial_photograph_of_Kandahar_Province_in_2011.jpg/540px-Aerial_photograph_of_Kandahar_Province_in_2011.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2784" data-file-height="1848"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Aerial_photograph_of_Kandahar_Province_in_2011.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Arghandab_River" title="Arghandab River">Arghandab</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tarnak_River" title="Tarnak River">Tarnak</a> rivers pass from Kandahar.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Despite having numerous rivers and <a href="/wiki/List_of_dams_and_reservoirs_in_Afghanistan" title="List of dams and reservoirs in Afghanistan">reservoirs</a>, large parts of the country are dry. The <a href="/wiki/Endorheic" class="mw-redirect" title="Endorheic">endorheic</a> Sistan Basin is one of the driest regions in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[183]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Amu_Darya" title="Amu Darya">Amu Darya</a> rises at the north of the Hindu Kush, while the nearby <a href="/wiki/Hari_Rud" class="mw-redirect" title="Hari Rud">Hari Rud</a> flows west towards <a href="/wiki/Herat" title="Herat">Herat</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Arghandab_River" title="Arghandab River">Arghandab River</a> from the central region southwards. To the south and west of the Hindu Kush flow a number of streams that are tributaries of the <a href="/wiki/Indus_River" title="Indus River">Indus River</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-auto7_182-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto7-182">[180]</a></sup> such as the <a href="/wiki/Helmand_River" title="Helmand River">Helmand River</a>. One exception is the <a href="/wiki/Kabul_River" title="Kabul River">Kabul River</a> which flows in an easternly direction to the Indus ending at the Indian Ocean.<sup id="cite_ref-auto2_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-186">[184]</a></sup> Afghanistan receives heavy snow during the winter in the <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Kush" title="Hindu Kush">Hindu Kush</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pamir_Mountains" title="Pamir Mountains">Pamir Mountains</a>, and the melting snow in the spring season enters the <a href="/wiki/List_of_rivers_of_Afghanistan" title="List of rivers of Afghanistan">rivers, lakes, and streams</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[185]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[186]</a></sup> However, two-thirds of the country's water flows into the neighboring countries of <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Turkmenistan" title="Turkmenistan">Turkmenistan</a>. As reported in 2010, the state needs more than <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$2 billion</span> to rehabilitate its irrigation systems so that the water is properly managed.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[187]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The northeastern Hindu Kush <a href="/wiki/Mountain_range" title="Mountain range">mountain range</a>, in and around the <a href="/wiki/Badakhshan_Province" title="Badakhshan Province">Badakhshan Province</a> of Afghanistan, is in a <a href="/wiki/Natural_environment#Geological_activity" title="Natural environment">geologically active</a> area where earthquakes may occur almost every year.<sup id="cite_ref-crone2007_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-crone2007-190">[188]</a></sup> They can be deadly and destructive, causing <a href="/wiki/Landslide" title="Landslide">landslides</a> in some parts or <a href="/wiki/2009_Afghan_avalanches" title="2009 Afghan avalanches">avalanches</a> during the winter.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[189]</a></sup> The last strong earthquakes were in <a href="/wiki/February_1998_Afghanistan_earthquake" title="February 1998 Afghanistan earthquake">1998</a>, which killed about 6,000 people in Badakhshan near Tajikistan.<sup id="cite_ref-bbcquake2010_192-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbcquake2010-192">[190]</a></sup> This was followed by the <a href="/wiki/2002_Hindu_Kush_earthquakes" title="2002 Hindu Kush earthquakes">2002 Hindu Kush earthquakes</a> in which over 150 people were killed and over 1,000 injured. A <a href="/wiki/2010_Afghanistan_earthquake" title="2010 Afghanistan earthquake">2010 earthquake</a> left 11 Afghans dead, over 70 injured, and more than 2,000 houses destroyed. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_AFG_present.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Koppen-Geiger_Map_AFG_present.svg/220px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_AFG_present.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="114" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Koppen-Geiger_Map_AFG_present.svg/330px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_AFG_present.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Koppen-Geiger_Map_AFG_present.svg/440px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_AFG_present.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1643" data-file-height="850"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_AFG_present.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="KÃ¶ppen climate classification">KÃ¶ppen climate map</a> of Afghanistan<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[191]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Afghanistan has a <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">continental climate</a> with harsh winters in the <a href="/wiki/Hazarajat" title="Hazarajat">central highlands</a>, the glaciated northeast (around <a href="/wiki/Nuristan" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuristan">Nuristan</a>), and the <a href="/wiki/Wakhan_Corridor" title="Wakhan Corridor">Wakhan Corridor</a>, where the average temperature in January is below â15&nbsp;Â°C (5&nbsp;Â°F) and can reach â26&nbsp;Â°C (â15&nbsp;Â°F),<sup id="cite_ref-auto7_182-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto7-182">[180]</a></sup> and hot summers in the low-lying areas of the <a href="/wiki/Sistan_Basin" title="Sistan Basin">Sistan Basin</a> of the southwest, the <a href="/wiki/Jalalabad" title="Jalalabad">Jalalabad</a> basin in the east, and the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Turkestan" title="Afghan Turkestan">Turkestan</a> plains along the <a href="/wiki/Amu_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Amu River">Amu River</a> in the north, where temperatures average over 35&nbsp;Â°C (95&nbsp;Â°F) in July<sup id="cite_ref-Factbook_10-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Factbook-10">[9]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[192]</a></sup> and can go over 43&nbsp;Â°C (109&nbsp;Â°F).<sup id="cite_ref-auto7_182-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto7-182">[180]</a></sup> The country is generally <a href="/wiki/Arid" title="Arid">arid</a> in the summers, with most rainfall falling between December and April. The lower areas of northern and western Afghanistan are the driest, with precipitation more common in the east. Although proximate to India, Afghanistan is mostly outside the <a href="/wiki/Monsoon" title="Monsoon">monsoon</a> zone,<sup id="cite_ref-auto7_182-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto7-182">[180]</a></sup> except the <a href="/wiki/Nuristan_Province" title="Nuristan Province">Nuristan Province</a> which occasionally receives summer monsoon rain.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[193]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Afghanistan" title="Wildlife of Afghanistan">Wildlife of Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:358px;max-width:358px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:177px;max-width:177px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Schneeleopard-_P1020498.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Schneeleopard-_P1020498.jpg/175px-Schneeleopard-_P1020498.jpg" decoding="async" width="175" height="131" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Schneeleopard-_P1020498.jpg/263px-Schneeleopard-_P1020498.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Schneeleopard-_P1020498.jpg/350px-Schneeleopard-_P1020498.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1824" data-file-height="1368"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Snow leopard
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:177px;max-width:177px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Padre_Stambec_-_panoramio.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Padre_Stambec_-_panoramio.jpg/175px-Padre_Stambec_-_panoramio.jpg" decoding="async" width="175" height="117" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Padre_Stambec_-_panoramio.jpg/263px-Padre_Stambec_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Padre_Stambec_-_panoramio.jpg/350px-Padre_Stambec_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1366"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Ibex
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:177px;max-width:177px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Feuilles_de_pistachier.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Feuilles_de_pistachier.jpg/175px-Feuilles_de_pistachier.jpg" decoding="async" width="175" height="117" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Feuilles_de_pistachier.jpg/263px-Feuilles_de_pistachier.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Feuilles_de_pistachier.jpg/350px-Feuilles_de_pistachier.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3270" data-file-height="2177"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Pistachio tree
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:177px;max-width:177px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Locoweed_(5824275506).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Locoweed_%285824275506%29.jpg/175px-Locoweed_%285824275506%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="175" height="131" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Locoweed_%285824275506%29.jpg/263px-Locoweed_%285824275506%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Locoweed_%285824275506%29.jpg/350px-Locoweed_%285824275506%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="480"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Locoweed
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Several types of <a href="/wiki/Mammal" title="Mammal">mammals</a> exist throughout Afghanistan. <a href="/wiki/Snow_leopard" title="Snow leopard">Snow leopards</a>, <a href="/wiki/Siberian_tiger" title="Siberian tiger">Siberian tigers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brown_bear" title="Brown bear">brown bears</a> live in the high elevation <a href="/wiki/Alpine_tundra" title="Alpine tundra">alpine tundra</a> regions. The <a href="/wiki/Marco_Polo_sheep" title="Marco Polo sheep">Marco Polo sheep</a> exclusively live in the <a href="/wiki/Wakhan_Corridor" title="Wakhan Corridor">Wakhan Corridor</a> region of north-east Afghanistan. <a href="/wiki/Fox" title="Fox">Foxes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wolves" class="mw-redirect" title="Wolves">wolves</a>, <a href="/wiki/Otter" title="Otter">otters</a>, <a href="/wiki/Deer" title="Deer">deer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wild_sheep" class="mw-redirect" title="Wild sheep">wild sheep</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lynx" title="Lynx">lynx</a> and other big cats populate the mountain forest region of the east. In the semi-desert northern plains, wildlife include a variety of birds, <a href="/wiki/Hedgehog" title="Hedgehog">hedgehogs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gopher" title="Gopher">gophers</a>, and large carnivores such as <a href="/wiki/Jackal" title="Jackal">jackals</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hyena" title="Hyena">hyenas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto8_196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto8-196">[194]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Gazelle" title="Gazelle">Gazelles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wild_boar" title="Wild boar">wild pigs</a> and jackals populate the <a href="/wiki/Steppe" title="Steppe">steppe</a> plains of the south and west, while <a href="/wiki/Mongoose" title="Mongoose">mongoose</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cheetah" title="Cheetah">cheetahs</a> exist in the semi-desert south.<sup id="cite_ref-auto8_196-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto8-196">[194]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Marmot" title="Marmot">Marmots</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ibex" title="Ibex">ibex</a> also live in the high mountains of Afghanistan, and <a href="/wiki/Pheasant" title="Pheasant">pheasants</a> exist in some parts of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[195]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Afghan_hound" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan hound">Afghan hound</a> is a native breed of dog known for its fast speed and its long hair; it is relatively known in the west.<sup id="cite_ref-auto9_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto9-198">[196]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Endemic" class="mw-redirect" title="Endemic">Endemic</a> fauna of Afghanistan includes the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_flying_squirrel" title="Afghan flying squirrel">Afghan flying squirrel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afghan_snowfinch" title="Afghan snowfinch">Afghan snowfinch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afghanodon" title="Afghanodon">Afghanodon</a> (or the "<a href="/wiki/Paghman" title="Paghman">Paghman</a> mountain salamander"), <i><a href="/wiki/Stigmella_kasyi" title="Stigmella kasyi">Stigmella kasyi</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Vulcaniella_kabulensis" title="Vulcaniella kabulensis">Vulcaniella kabulensis</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Afghan_leopard_gecko" title="Afghan leopard gecko">Afghan leopard gecko</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Wheeleria_parviflorellus" title="Wheeleria parviflorellus">Wheeleria parviflorellus</a></i>, amongst others. Endemic flora include <i><a href="/wiki/Iris_afghanica" title="Iris afghanica">Iris afghanica</a></i>. Afghanistan has a wide variety of birds despite its relatively arid climate â an estimated 460 species of which 235 breed within.<sup id="cite_ref-auto9_198-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto9-198">[196]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The forest region of Afghanistan has vegetation such as <a href="/wiki/Pine_tree" class="mw-redirect" title="Pine tree">pine trees</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spruce_tree" class="mw-redirect" title="Spruce tree">spruce trees</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fir_tree" class="mw-redirect" title="Fir tree">fir trees</a> and <a href="/wiki/Larch" title="Larch">larches</a>, whereas the steppe grassland regions consist of <a href="/wiki/Broadleaf_tree" class="mw-redirect" title="Broadleaf tree">broadleaf trees</a>, short grass, <a href="/wiki/Perennial_plant" title="Perennial plant">perennial plants</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shrubland" title="Shrubland">shrublands</a>. The colder high elevation regions are composed of hardy grasses and small flowering plants.<sup id="cite_ref-auto8_196-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto8-196">[194]</a></sup> Several regions are designated <a href="/wiki/List_of_protected_areas_of_Afghanistan" title="List of protected areas of Afghanistan">protected areas</a>; there are three National Parks: <a href="/wiki/Band-e_Amir" class="mw-redirect" title="Band-e Amir">Band-e Amir</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wakhan_National_Park" title="Wakhan National Park">Wakhan</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuristan_National_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuristan National Park (page does not exist)">Nuristan</a>. Afghanistan had a 2018 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 8.85/10, ranking it 15th globally out of 172 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_199-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-199">[197]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Afghanistan" title="Demographics of Afghanistan">Demographics of Afghanistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Afghan_diaspora" title="Afghan diaspora">Afghan diaspora</a>
      </div> 
      <table class="toccolours" style="width:15em;border-top-width:0;border-spacing: 0;float:right;clear:right;margin:0.5em 0 1em 0.5em;">
       <caption style="border-top:1px #aaa solid;border-left:1px #aaa solid;border-right:1px #aaa solid;background-color:lavender;padding:0.25em;font-weight:bold">
        1950â2020
       </caption>
       <tbody>
        <tr style="font-size:95%">

        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>The population of Afghanistan was estimated at 32.9&nbsp;million as of 2019 by the Afghanistan Statistics and Information Authority,<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[200]</a></sup> whereas the UN estimates over 38.0&nbsp;million.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[201]</a></sup> About 23.9% of them are <a href="/wiki/Urban_area" title="Urban area">urbanite</a>, 71.4% live in rural areas, and the remaining 4.7% are nomadic.<sup id="cite_ref-https://www.worldometers.info/world-population/afghanistan-population/_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-https://www.worldometers.info/world-population/afghanistan-population/-204">[202]</a></sup> An additional 3&nbsp;million or so Afghans are temporarily housed in neighboring <a href="/wiki/Afghans_in_Pakistan" title="Afghans in Pakistan">Pakistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Afghans_in_Iran" title="Afghans in Iran">Iran</a>, most of whom were born and raised in those two countries. As of 2013, Afghanistan was the largest refugee-producing country in the world, a title held for 32 years. </p>
      <p>The current population growth rate is 2.37%,<sup id="cite_ref-Factbook_10-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Factbook-10">[9]</a></sup> one of the highest in the world outside of Africa. This population is expected to reach 82&nbsp;million by 2050 if current population trends continue.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[203]</a></sup> The population of Afghanistan increased steadily until the 1980s, when civil war caused millions to flee to other countries such as Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[204]</a></sup> Millions have since returned and the war conditions has meant a high fertility rate compared to global and regional trends.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[205]</a></sup> Afghanistan's healthcare has recovered since the turn of the century, causing falls in infant mortality and increases in life expectancy. This (along with other factors such as returning refugees) caused rapid population growth in the 2000s that has only recently started to slow down. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">Ethnic groups</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">

          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Baloch_people" title="Baloch people">Baloch</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:blue; width:2%; overflow: hidden;">
             â
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">2%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_Afghanistan#Ethnic_groups" title="Ethnic groups in Afghanistan">others</a> (<a href="/wiki/Pashayi_people" title="Pashayi people">Pashayi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nuristani_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuristani people">Nuristani</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pamiri_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Pamiri people">Pamiri</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Arabs_in_Afghanistan" title="History of Arabs in Afghanistan">Arab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gurjar#Afghanistan" title="Gurjar">Gurjars</a>, etc.)</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:red; width:4%; overflow: hidden;">
             â
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">4%</td> 
          </tr> 
         </tbody>
        </table> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>Afghanistan's population is divided into several <a href="/wiki/Ethnolinguistic" class="mw-redirect" title="Ethnolinguistic">ethnolinguistic</a> groups. The ethnicities are represented on the table on the right. The percentages given are estimates only, as accurate and current statistical data on ethnicity are not available.<sup id="cite_ref-Factbook_10-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Factbook-10">[9]</a></sup> Generally the four major ethnic groups are the <a href="/wiki/Pashtuns" title="Pashtuns">Pashtuns</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tajiks" title="Tajiks">Tajiks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hazaras" title="Hazaras">Hazaras</a> and <a href="/wiki/Uzbeks" title="Uzbeks">Uzbeks</a>. A further 10 other ethnic groups are recognized and each are represented in the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_National_Anthem" title="Afghan National Anthem">Afghan National Anthem</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[206]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Afghanistan" title="Languages of Afghanistan">Languages of Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;"> 
       <div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:auto; background: white;"> 
        <table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;"> 
         <tbody>
          <tr style="background:#ddd">
           <th style="text-align:center;" colspan="5">Spoken ability of different languages in Afghanistan<sup id="cite_ref-Factbook_10-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Factbook-10">[9]</a></sup></th>
          </tr> 
          <tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;"> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; text-align:left;"></td>

          </tr> 
          <tr>

            <div style="background:green; width:78%; overflow: hidden;">
             â

             â

          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Uzbek_language" title="Uzbek language">Uzbek</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:blue; width:10%; overflow: hidden;">

          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a></td>

            <div style="background:red; width:2%; overflow: hidden;">
             â
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">2%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Pashayi_languages" title="Pashayi languages">Pashayi</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:blue; width:1%; overflow: hidden;">
             â
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">1%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Nuristani_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuristani language">Nuristani</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:red; width:1%; overflow: hidden;">
             â
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">1%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:blue; width:1%; overflow: hidden;">
             â
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">1%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Balochi_language" title="Balochi language">Balochi</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:red; width:1%; overflow: hidden;">
             â
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">1%</td> 
          </tr> 
         </tbody>
        </table> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Dari" title="Dari">Dari</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pashto" title="Pashto">Pashto</a> are the <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official languages</a> of Afghanistan; <a href="/wiki/Bilingualism" class="mw-redirect" title="Bilingualism">bilingualism</a> is very common.<sup id="cite_ref-AO_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AO-1">[1]</a></sup> Dari, which is a variety of and mutually intelligible with <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a> (and very often called 'Farsi' by some Afghans like in <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a>) functions as the <a href="/wiki/Lingua_franca" title="Lingua franca">lingua franca</a> in Kabul as well as in much of the northern and northwestern parts of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-AO_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AO-1">[1]</a></sup> Pashto is the native tongue of the Pashtuns, although many of them are also fluent in Dari while some non-Pashtuns are fluent in Pashto. Despite the Pashtuns having been dominant in Afghan politics for centuries, Dari remained the preferred language for government and bureaucracy.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[207]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are a number of smaller regional languages, including <a href="/wiki/Uzbek_language" title="Uzbek language">Uzbek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkmen_language" title="Turkmen language">Turkmen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Balochi_language" title="Balochi language">Balochi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pashayi_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Pashayi language">Pashayi</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nuristani_languages" title="Nuristani languages">Nuristani</a>. </p>
      <p>When it comes to foreign languages among the populace, many are able to speak or understand <a href="/wiki/Hindustani_language" title="Hindustani language">Hindustani</a> (<a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a>-<a href="/wiki/Hindi" title="Hindi">Hindi</a>), partly due to returning Afghan refugees from Pakistan and the popularity of <a href="/wiki/Bollywood" title="Bollywood">Bollywood</a> films respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-auto3_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-210">[208]</a></sup> English is also understood by some of the population,<sup id="cite_ref-Afghan2018_211-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Afghan2018-211">[209]</a></sup> and has been gaining popularity as of the 2000s.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[210]</a></sup> Some Afghans retain some ability of Russian, which was taught to public schools during the 1980s.<sup id="cite_ref-auto3_210-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-210">[208]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Afghanistan" title="Religion in Afghanistan">Religion in Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;"> 
       <div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:auto; background: white;"> 
        <table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;"> 
         <tbody>
          <tr style="background:#ddd">
           <th style="text-align:center;" colspan="5"><a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Afghanistan" title="Religion in Afghanistan">Religion in Afghanistan</a><sup id="cite_ref-Pew_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pew-213">[211]</a></sup></th>
          </tr> 
          <tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;"> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; text-align:left;"></td> 
           <td style="width:100px; text-align:left;"></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;"></td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni Islam</a> </td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:green ; width:84.7%; overflow: hidden;">
             â
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">84.7%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam_in_Afghanistan" title="Shia Islam in Afghanistan">Shia Islam</a> </td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:lightgreen ; width:15%; overflow: hidden;">
             â
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">15%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Afghanistan#Minority_religious_groups" title="Religion in Afghanistan">others</a> </td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:orange ; width:0.3%; overflow: hidden;">
             â
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">0.3%</td> 
          </tr> 
         </tbody>
        </table> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>An estimated 99.7% of the Afghan population is Muslim<sup id="cite_ref-Factbook_10-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Factbook-10">[9]</a></sup> and most are thought to adhere to the <a href="/wiki/Sunni" class="mw-redirect" title="Sunni">Sunni</a> <a href="/wiki/Hanafi" title="Hanafi">Hanafi</a> school.<sup id="cite_ref-auto6_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto6-214">[212]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew Research Center</a>, as much as 90% are of the Sunni denomination, 7% <a href="/wiki/Shia" class="mw-redirect" title="Shia">Shia</a> and 3% <a href="/wiki/Non-denominational_Muslim" title="Non-denominational Muslim">non-denominational</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Pew_213-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pew-213">[211]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/CIA" class="mw-redirect" title="CIA">CIA</a> Factbook variously estimates up to 89.7% Sunni or up to 15% Shia.<sup id="cite_ref-Factbook_10-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Factbook-10">[9]</a></sup> Dr <a href="/wiki/Michael_Izady" class="mw-redirect" title="Michael Izady">Michael Izady</a> estimated 70% of the population to be followers of Sunni Islam, 25% <a href="/wiki/Imamiyyah" class="mw-redirect" title="Imamiyyah">Imami Shia Islam</a>, 4.5% <a href="/wiki/Isma%27ilism" title="Isma'ilism">Ismaili Shia Islam</a>, and 0.5% <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Afghanistan#Minority_religious_groups" title="Religion in Afghanistan">other religions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Izady_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Izady-215">[213]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Thousands of Afghan <a href="/wiki/Sikhism_in_Afghanistan" title="Sikhism in Afghanistan">Sikhs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Afghanistan" title="Hinduism in Afghanistan">Hindus</a> are also found in certain major cities (namely Kabul, Jalalabad, Ghazni, Kandahar)<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[214]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[215]</a></sup> accompanied by gurdwaras and mandirs.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[216]</a></sup> There was a small <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Afghanistan" title="History of the Jews in Afghanistan">Jewish community in Afghanistan</a> who had emigrated to Israel and the United States by the end of the twentieth century; at least one Jew, <a href="/wiki/Zablon_Simintov" title="Zablon Simintov">Zablon Simintov</a>, remains, who is the caretaker of the only remaining synagogue.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[217]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Christians" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan Christians">Afghan Christians</a>, who number 500â8,000, practice their faith secretly due to intense societal opposition, and there are no public churches.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[218]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[219]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanisation">Urbanisation</span></h3> 
      <p>As estimated by the CIA World Factbook, 26% of the population was urbanized as of 2020. This is one of the lowest figures in the world; in Asia it is only higher than <a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">Cambodia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lanka" title="Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a>. Urbanization has increased rapidly, particularly in the capital <a href="/wiki/Kabul" title="Kabul">Kabul</a>, due to returning refugees from Pakistan and Iran after 2001, internally displaced people, and rural migrants.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[220]</a></sup> Urbanization in Afghanistan has been noted to be different than traditional urbanization, in that it's centered on a few cities rather than evenly spread out nationwide.<sup id="cite_ref-auto5_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto5-223">[221]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The only city with over a million residents is its capital, Kabul, located in the east of the country. The other large cities are located generally in the "ring" around the Central Highlands, namely <a href="/wiki/Kandahar" title="Kandahar">Kandahar</a> in the south, <a href="/wiki/Herat" title="Herat">Herat</a> in the west, <a href="/wiki/Mazar-i-Sharif" title="Mazar-i-Sharif">Mazar-i-Sharif</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kunduz" title="Kunduz">Kunduz</a> in the north, and <a href="/wiki/Jalalabad" title="Jalalabad">Jalalabad</a> in the east.<sup id="cite_ref-https://www.worldometers.info/world-population/afghanistan-population/_204-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-https://www.worldometers.info/world-population/afghanistan-population/-204">[202]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table class="navbox"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr>

         <td rowspan="11" style="text-align: center"><a href="/wiki/File:Kabul_-_panoramio_-_davered1101.jpg" class="image" title="Kabul"><img alt="Kabul" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Kabul_-_panoramio_-_davered1101.jpg/120px-Kabul_-_panoramio_-_davered1101.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="90" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Kabul_-_panoramio_-_davered1101.jpg/180px-Kabul_-_panoramio_-_davered1101.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Kabul_-_panoramio_-_davered1101.jpg/240px-Kabul_-_panoramio_-_davered1101.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2608" data-file-height="1952"></a><br><a href="/wiki/Kabul" title="Kabul">Kabul</a><br><a href="/wiki/File:Aerial_view_of_a_section_of_Kandahar_in_2013.jpg" class="image" title="Kandahar"><img alt="Kandahar" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Aerial_view_of_a_section_of_Kandahar_in_2013.jpg/120px-Aerial_view_of_a_section_of_Kandahar_in_2013.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="80" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Aerial_view_of_a_section_of_Kandahar_in_2013.jpg/180px-Aerial_view_of_a_section_of_Kandahar_in_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Aerial_view_of_a_section_of_Kandahar_in_2013.jpg/240px-Aerial_view_of_a_section_of_Kandahar_in_2013.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2848"></a><br><a href="/wiki/Kandahar" title="Kandahar">Kandahar</a> </td> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">1</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Kabul" title="Kabul">Kabul</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Kabul_Province" title="Kabul Province">Kabul Province</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">4,273,200 </td> 
         <td rowspan="11" style="text-align: center"><a href="/wiki/File:View_of_Herat_in_2009.jpg" class="image" title="Herat"><img alt="Herat" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/View_of_Herat_in_2009.jpg/120px-View_of_Herat_in_2009.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="67" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/View_of_Herat_in_2009.jpg/180px-View_of_Herat_in_2009.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/View_of_Herat_in_2009.jpg/240px-View_of_Herat_in_2009.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1244" data-file-height="694"></a><br><a href="/wiki/Herat" title="Herat">Herat</a><br><a href="/wiki/File:Nowruz_in_northern_Afghanistan-2011.jpg" class="image" title="Mazar-i-Sharif"><img alt="Mazar-i-Sharif" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Nowruz_in_northern_Afghanistan-2011.jpg/120px-Nowruz_in_northern_Afghanistan-2011.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="90" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Nowruz_in_northern_Afghanistan-2011.jpg/180px-Nowruz_in_northern_Afghanistan-2011.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Nowruz_in_northern_Afghanistan-2011.jpg/240px-Nowruz_in_northern_Afghanistan-2011.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1874" data-file-height="1400"></a><br><a href="/wiki/Mazar-i-Sharif" title="Mazar-i-Sharif">Mazar-i-Sharif</a> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>

        </tr>

         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">6</td>
