      </table> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Governance">Governance</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Afghanistan" title="Politics of Afghanistan">Politics of Afghanistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Afghanistan" title="Constitution of Afghanistan">Constitution of Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:200229-D-AP390-1529_(49603221753).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/200229-D-AP390-1529_%2849603221753%29.jpg/200px-200229-D-AP390-1529_%2849603221753%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="133" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/200229-D-AP390-1529_%2849603221753%29.jpg/300px-200229-D-AP390-1529_%2849603221753%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/200229-D-AP390-1529_%2849603221753%29.jpg/400px-200229-D-AP390-1529_%2849603221753%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5568" data-file-height="3712"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:200229-D-AP390-1529_(49603221753).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Presidential_Palace,_Kabul" class="mw-redirect" title="Presidential Palace, Kabul">Arg (Presidential Palace)</a> in Kabul
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Afghanistan is an <a href="/wiki/Islamic_republic" title="Islamic republic">Islamic republic</a> consisting of three branches, the executive, legislative, and judicial. The nation is led by President <a href="/wiki/Ashraf_Ghani" title="Ashraf Ghani">Ashraf Ghani</a> with <a href="/wiki/Amrullah_Saleh" title="Amrullah Saleh">Amrullah Saleh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sarwar_Danish" title="Sarwar Danish">Sarwar Danish</a> as vice presidents. The <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_of_Afghanistan" class="mw-redirect" title="National Assembly of Afghanistan">National Assembly</a> is the legislature, a <a href="/wiki/Bicameral" class="mw-redirect" title="Bicameral">bicameral</a> body having two chambers, the <a href="/wiki/House_of_the_People_(Afghanistan)" title="House of the People (Afghanistan)">House of the People</a> and the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Elders" class="mw-redirect" title="House of Elders">House of Elders</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Supreme_Court" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan Supreme Court">Supreme Court</a> is led by <a href="/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_Afghanistan" title="Chief Justice of Afghanistan">Chief Justice</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Said_Yusuf_Halem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Said Yusuf Halem (page does not exist)">Said Yusuf Halem</a>, the former Deputy Minister of Justice for Legal Affairs.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[223]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[224]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to <a href="/wiki/Transparency_International" title="Transparency International">Transparency International</a>, Afghanistan remains in the top most corrupt countries list.<sup id="cite_ref-TI_227-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TI-227">[225]</a></sup> A January 2010 report published by the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Office_on_Drugs_and_Crime" title="United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime">United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime</a> revealed that bribery consumed an amount equal to 23% of the GDP of the nation.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[226]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 17 May 2020, President <a href="/wiki/Ashraf_Ghani" title="Ashraf Ghani">Ashraf Ghani</a> reached a power-sharing deal with his rival from presidential elections, <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_Abdullah" title="Abdullah Abdullah">Abdullah Abdullah</a>, deciding on who would manage the respected key ministries. The agreement ended months-long <a href="/wiki/Political_deadlock" class="mw-redirect" title="Political deadlock">political deadlock</a> in the country. It was agreed that while Ghani will lead Afghanistan as the president, Abdullah will oversee the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_peace_process" title="Afghan peace process">peace process</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Taliban" title="Taliban">Taliban</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[227]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[228]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Elections_and_parties">Elections and parties</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Afghanistan" title="Elections in Afghanistan">Elections in Afghanistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Afghanistan" title="List of political parties in Afghanistan">List of political parties in Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:President_Donald_J._Trump_and_President_Ashraf_Ghani_of_Afghanistan_at_the_United_Nations_General_Assembly_(36747065014).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/President_Donald_J._Trump_and_President_Ashraf_Ghani_of_Afghanistan_at_the_United_Nations_General_Assembly_%2836747065014%29.jpg/220px-President_Donald_J._Trump_and_President_Ashraf_Ghani_of_Afghanistan_at_the_United_Nations_General_Assembly_%2836747065014%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/President_Donald_J._Trump_and_President_Ashraf_Ghani_of_Afghanistan_at_the_United_Nations_General_Assembly_%2836747065014%29.jpg/330px-President_Donald_J._Trump_and_President_Ashraf_Ghani_of_Afghanistan_at_the_United_Nations_General_Assembly_%2836747065014%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/President_Donald_J._Trump_and_President_Ashraf_Ghani_of_Afghanistan_at_the_United_Nations_General_Assembly_%2836747065014%29.jpg/440px-President_Donald_J._Trump_and_President_Ashraf_Ghani_of_Afghanistan_at_the_United_Nations_General_Assembly_%2836747065014%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="800"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:President_Donald_J._Trump_and_President_Ashraf_Ghani_of_Afghanistan_at_the_United_Nations_General_Assembly_(36747065014).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>U.S. President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> with president of Afghanistan <a href="/wiki/Ashraf_Ghani" title="Ashraf Ghani">Ashraf Ghani</a> in 2017.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>One instrument of Afghan governance is the <i><a href="/wiki/Loya_jirga" title="Loya jirga">loya jirga</a></i> (grand assembly), a <a href="/wiki/Pashtun" class="mw-redirect" title="Pashtun">Pashtun</a> consultative meeting that is mainly organized for choosing a new <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>, adopting a new constitution, or to settle national or regional issue such as war.<sup id="cite_ref-news.bbc.co.uk_231-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-news.bbc.co.uk-231">[229]</a></sup> Loya jirgas have been held since at least 1747,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarfield2012295_232-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarfield2012295-232">[230]</a></sup> with the most recent one occurring in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[231]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Under the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Afghanistan" title="Constitution of Afghanistan">2004 constitution</a>, both presidential and parliamentary elections are to be held every five years. However, due to the disputed <a href="/wiki/2014_Afghan_presidential_election" title="2014 Afghan presidential election">2014 presidential election</a>, the scheduled 2015 parliamentary elections were delayed until <a href="/wiki/2018_Afghan_parliamentary_election" title="2018 Afghan parliamentary election">2018</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[232]</a></sup> Presidential elections use the <a href="/wiki/Two-round_system" title="Two-round system">two-round system</a>; if no candidate receives a majority of the vote in the first round, a second round will be held featuring the top two candidates. Parliamentary elections have only one round and are based on the <a href="/wiki/Single_non-transferable_vote" title="Single non-transferable vote">single non-transferable vote</a> system, which allows some candidates to be elected with as little as one percent of the vote.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[233]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Afghan_presidential_election,_2004" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan presidential election, 2004">2004 Afghan presidential election</a> was relatively peaceful, in which Hamid Karzai won in the first round with 55.4% of the votes. However, the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_presidential_election,_2009" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan presidential election, 2009">2009 presidential election</a> was characterized by lack of security, low voter turnout, and widespread electoral fraud, ending in Karzai's reelection.<sup id="cite_ref-Karzai_Gets_New_Term_as_Afghan_Runoff_is_Scrapped_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Karzai_Gets_New_Term_as_Afghan_Runoff_is_Scrapped-236">[234]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Afghan_presidential_election,_2014" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan presidential election, 2014">2014 presidential election</a> ended with Ashraf Ghani winning by 56.44% of the votes.<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[235]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Afghan_parliament_building_2015.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Afghan_parliament_building_2015.jpg/220px-Afghan_parliament_building_2015.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="139" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Afghan_parliament_building_2015.jpg/330px-Afghan_parliament_building_2015.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Afghan_parliament_building_2015.jpg/440px-Afghan_parliament_building_2015.jpg 2x" data-file-width="478" data-file-height="301"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Afghan_parliament_building_2015.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_of_Afghanistan" class="mw-redirect" title="National Assembly of Afghanistan">National Assembly of Afghanistan</a> in Kabul, the current site was built in 2015
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Political parties played a marginal role in post-2001 Afghan politics, in part due to Karzai's opposition to them.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarfield2012301_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarfield2012301-238">[236]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_parliamentary_election,_2005" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan parliamentary election, 2005">2005 parliamentary election</a>, the ballots did not show candidates' party affiliation, so the results were dictated by the personal prestige of the candidates.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarfield2012301_238-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarfield2012301-238">[236]</a></sup> Among the elected officials were a large mix of former mujahideen, <a href="/wiki/Islamic_fundamentalists" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamic fundamentalists">Islamic fundamentalists</a>, warlords, tribal nationalists, former communists, <a href="/wiki/Reformists" class="mw-redirect" title="Reformists">reformists</a>, urban professionals, <a href="/wiki/Royalism" class="mw-redirect" title="Royalism">royalists</a> and several former Taliban associates.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[237]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[238]</a></sup> In the same period, Afghanistan became the 30th highest nation in terms of female representation in the National Assembly.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[239]</a></sup> Parties became more influential after 2009, when a new law established more stringent requirements for party registration.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[240]</a></sup> Nearly a hundred new parties were registered after the law came into effect,<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[241]</a></sup> and party activity increased in the 2014 elections, but party influence remained limited.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[242]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Afghanistan" title="Provinces of Afghanistan">Provinces of Afghanistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Afghanistan" title="Districts of Afghanistan">Districts of Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Afghanistan is administratively divided into 34 provinces (<i><a href="/wiki/Wilayat" class="mw-redirect" title="Wilayat">wilayat</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[243]</a></sup> Each province is the size of a <a href="/wiki/U.S._county" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. county">U.S. county</a>, having a governor and a capital. The country is further divided into nearly 400 provincial <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Afghanistan" title="Districts of Afghanistan">districts</a>, each of which normally covers a city or several villages. Each district is represented by a district governor. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/List_of_current_governors_of_Afghanistan" class="mw-redirect" title="List of current governors of Afghanistan">provincial governors</a> are appointed by the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Afghanistan" title="President of Afghanistan">President of Afghanistan</a>, and the district governors are selected by the provincial governors.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[244]</a></sup> The provincial governors are representatives of the central government in Kabul and are responsible for all administrative and formal issues within their provinces. There are also provincial councils that are elected through direct and general elections for four years.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[245]</a></sup> The functions of provincial councils are to take part in provincial development planning and to participate in the monitoring and appraisal of other provincial governance institutions. </p>
      <p>According to article 140 of the constitution and the presidential decree on electoral law, mayors of cities should be elected through free and direct elections for a four-year term. In practice however, mayors are appointed by the government.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[246]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The following is a list of all the 34 provinces in alphabetical order: </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Afghanistan_provinces_numbered.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Afghanistan_provinces_numbered.png/350px-Afghanistan_provinces_numbered.png" decoding="async" width="350" height="269" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Afghanistan_provinces_numbered.png/525px-Afghanistan_provinces_numbered.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/44/Afghanistan_provinces_numbered.png 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="461"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Afghanistan_provinces_numbered.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Afghanistan is divided into <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Afghanistan" title="Provinces of Afghanistan">34 provinces</a>, which are further divided into a <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Afghanistan" title="Districts of Afghanistan">number of districts</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>

        <li><a href="/wiki/Kunar_Province" title="Kunar Province">Kunar</a></li>

        <li><a href="/wiki/Logar_Province" title="Logar Province">Logar</a></li>

        <li><a href="/wiki/Nuristan_Province" title="Nuristan Province">Nuristan</a></li> 
        <li><a href="/wiki/Oruzgan_Province" class="mw-redirect" title="Oruzgan Province">Oruzgan</a></li> 
        <li><a href="/wiki/Paktia_Province" title="Paktia Province">Paktia</a></li> 
        <li><a href="/wiki/Paktika_Province" title="Paktika Province">Paktika</a></li> 
        <li><a href="/wiki/Panjshir_Province" title="Panjshir Province">Panjshir</a></li> 
        <li><a href="/wiki/Parwan_Province" title="Parwan Province">Parwan</a></li> 
        <li><a href="/wiki/Samangan_Province" title="Samangan Province">Samangan</a></li> 
        <li><a href="/wiki/Sar-e_Pol_Province" title="Sar-e Pol Province">Sar-e Pol</a></li> 
        <li><a href="/wiki/Takhar_Province" title="Takhar Province">Takhar</a></li> 
        <li><a href="/wiki/Wardak_Province" class="mw-redirect" title="Wardak Province">Wardak</a></li> 
        <li><a href="/wiki/Zabul_Province" title="Zabul Province">Zabul</a></li>
       </ol> 
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Afghanistan" title="Foreign relations of Afghanistan">Foreign relations of Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Afghanistan became a member of the United Nations in 1946.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDupree1997642_249-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDupree1997642-249">[247]</a></sup> It enjoys cordial relations with a number of <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> and allied nations, particularly the <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="AfghanistanâUnited States relations">United States</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan%E2%80%93Canada_relations" title="AfghanistanâCanada relations">Canada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan%E2%80%93United_Kingdom_relations" title="AfghanistanâUnited Kingdom relations">United Kingdom</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan%E2%80%93Germany_relations" title="AfghanistanâGermany relations">Germany</a>, Australia, and <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan%E2%80%93Turkey_relations" title="AfghanistanâTurkey relations">Turkey</a>. In 2012, the United States and Afghanistan signed their <a href="/wiki/U.S.%E2%80%93Afghanistan_Strategic_Partnership_Agreement" title="U.S.âAfghanistan Strategic Partnership Agreement">Strategic Partnership Agreement</a> in which Afghanistan became a <a href="/wiki/Major_non-NATO_ally" title="Major non-NATO ally">major non-NATO ally</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[248]</a></sup> Afghanistan has historically had strong relations with Germany, one of the first countries to recognize Afghanistan's independence in 1919; the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, which provided much aid and military training for Afghanistan's forces and includes the signing of a Treaty of Friendship in 1921 and 1978; and <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan%E2%80%93India_relations" title="AfghanistanâIndia relations">India</a>, with which a friendship treaty was signed in 1950.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[249]</a></sup> Relations with <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan%E2%80%93Pakistan_relations" title="AfghanistanâPakistan relations">Pakistan</a> have often been tense for various reasons such as the <a href="/wiki/Durand_Line" title="Durand Line">Durand Line</a> border issue and alleged Pakistani involvement in Afghan insurgent groups. Afghanistan also has diplomatic relations with neighboring <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan%E2%80%93China_relations" title="AfghanistanâChina relations">China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan%E2%80%93Iran_relations" title="AfghanistanâIran relations">Iran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan%E2%80%93Tajikistan_relations" title="AfghanistanâTajikistan relations">Tajikistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Turkmenistan#Afghanistan" title="Foreign relations of Turkmenistan">Turkmenistan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Uzbekistan" title="Foreign relations of Uzbekistan">Uzbekistan</a>, including with regional states such as <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan%E2%80%93Bangladesh_relations" title="AfghanistanâBangladesh relations">Bangladesh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan%E2%80%93Japan_relations" title="AfghanistanâJapan relations">Japan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Kazakhstan" title="Foreign relations of Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Nepal" title="Foreign relations of Nepal">Nepal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan%E2%80%93Russia_relations" title="AfghanistanâRussia relations">Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan%E2%80%93South_Korea_relations" title="AfghanistanâSouth Korea relations">South Korea</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan%E2%80%93United_Arab_Emirates_relations" title="AfghanistanâUnited Arab Emirates relations">UAE</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Afghanistan)" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Afghanistan)">Afghan Ministry of Foreign Affairs</a> continues to develop <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Afghanistan" title="Foreign relations of Afghanistan">diplomatic relations</a> with other countries around the world. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Assistance_Mission_in_Afghanistan" title="United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan">United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan</a> (UNAMA) was established in 2002 to help the country recover from decades of war.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[250]</a></sup> Today, several NATO member states deploy about 17,000 troops in Afghanistan as part of the <a href="/wiki/Resolute_Support_Mission" title="Resolute Support Mission">Resolute Support Mission</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-NATO_253-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NATO-253">[251]</a></sup> Its main purpose is to <a href="/wiki/NATO_Training_Mission-Afghanistan" title="NATO Training Mission-Afghanistan">train the Afghan National Security Forces</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:First_set_of_Afghan_UH-60A_Black_Hawks.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/First_set_of_Afghan_UH-60A_Black_Hawks.jpg/220px-First_set_of_Afghan_UH-60A_Black_Hawks.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="139" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/First_set_of_Afghan_UH-60A_Black_Hawks.jpg/330px-First_set_of_Afghan_UH-60A_Black_Hawks.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/First_set_of_Afghan_UH-60A_Black_Hawks.jpg/440px-First_set_of_Afghan_UH-60A_Black_Hawks.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5187" data-file-height="3282"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:First_set_of_Afghan_UH-60A_Black_Hawks.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Sikorsky_UH-60_Black_Hawk" title="Sikorsky UH-60 Black Hawk">Black Hawks</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Air_Force" title="Afghan Air Force">Afghan Air Force</a> at <a href="/wiki/Kandahar_Airfield" class="mw-redirect" title="Kandahar Airfield">Kandahar Airfield</a>. As a <a href="/wiki/Major_non-NATO_ally" title="Major non-NATO ally">major non-NATO ally</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Armed_Forces" title="Afghan Armed Forces">Afghan Armed Forces</a> receive most of their equipment and <a href="/wiki/Resolute_Support_Mission" title="Resolute Support Mission">training</a> from the United States.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Armed_Forces" title="Afghan Armed Forces">Afghan Armed Forces</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Armed_Forces" title="Afghan Armed Forces">Afghan Armed Forces</a> are under the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defense_(Afghanistan)" title="Ministry of Defense (Afghanistan)">Ministry of Defense</a>, which includes the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Air_Force" title="Afghan Air Force">Afghan Air Force</a> (AAF) and the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_National_Army" title="Afghan National Army">Afghan National Army</a> (ANA). The <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Defense_University" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan Defense University">Afghan Defense University</a> houses various educational establishments for the Afghan Armed Forces, including the <a href="/wiki/National_Military_Academy_of_Afghanistan" title="National Military Academy of Afghanistan">National Military Academy of Afghanistan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[252]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_enforcement">Law enforcement</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Afghanistan" title="Law enforcement in Afghanistan">Law enforcement in Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:ANP_trucks_in_Kunar.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/ANP_trucks_in_Kunar.jpg/220px-ANP_trucks_in_Kunar.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/ANP_trucks_in_Kunar.jpg/330px-ANP_trucks_in_Kunar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/ANP_trucks_in_Kunar.jpg/440px-ANP_trucks_in_Kunar.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5616" data-file-height="3744"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:ANP_trucks_in_Kunar.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Afghan_National_Police" title="Afghan National Police">Afghan National Police</a> (ANP) in <a href="/wiki/Kunar_Province" title="Kunar Province">Kunar Province</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Law enforcement in Afghanistan is the responsibility of the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_National_Police" title="Afghan National Police">Afghan National Police</a> (ANP), which is part of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Interior_Affairs_(Afghanistan)" title="Ministry of Interior Affairs (Afghanistan)">Ministry of Interior Affairs</a>. The ANP consists of two primary branches, the Afghan Uniformed Police and the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Border_Police" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan Border Police">Afghan Border Police</a>. The mission of the Uniformed Police is to ensure security within Afghanistan, prevent crime, and protect property. The Border Police is responsible for securing and maintaining the nation's borders with neighboring states as well as all international airports within the country.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[253]</a></sup> Afghanistan's <a href="/wiki/Intelligence_agency" title="Intelligence agency">intelligence agency</a>, the <a href="/wiki/National_Directorate_of_Security" title="National Directorate of Security">National Directorate of Security</a> (NDS), assists the ANP with security matters.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[254]</a></sup> Despite that, </p>
      <p>All parts of Afghanistan are considered dangerous due to militant activities and terrorism-related incidents. Kidnapping for ransom and robberies are common in major cities. Every year hundreds of <a href="/wiki/List_of_Afghan_security_forces_fatality_reports_in_Afghanistan" title="List of Afghan security forces fatality reports in Afghanistan">Afghan police are killed</a> in the line of duty.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">[255]</a></sup> Afghanistan is also the world's leading <a href="/wiki/Opium_production_in_Afghanistan" title="Opium production in Afghanistan">producer of opium</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[256]</a></sup> Afghanistan's <a href="/wiki/Opium_poppy" class="mw-redirect" title="Opium poppy">opium poppy</a> harvest produces more than 90% of illicit heroin globally, and more than 95% of the European supply.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[257]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[258]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Ministry_of_Counter_Narcotics" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan Ministry of Counter Narcotics">Afghan Ministry of Counter Narcotics</a> is responsible for the monitoring and eradication of the illegal drug business. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">Human rights</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Afghanistan" title="Human rights in Afghanistan">Human rights in Afghanistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Women_in_Afghanistan" title="Women in Afghanistan">Women in Afghanistan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Afghanistan" title="LGBT rights in Afghanistan">LGBT rights in Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_expression" class="mw-redirect" title="Freedom of expression">Freedom of expression</a> and the press is permitted and promoted in the current 2004 constitution, so long as it does not threaten national or religious integrity or does not <a href="/wiki/Defame" class="mw-redirect" title="Defame">defame</a> individuals. In 2019, <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">Reporters Without Borders</a> listed the media environment of Afghanistan as 121st out of 179 on its <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">Press Freedom Index</a>, with 1st being most free.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[259]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">[260]</a></sup> However many issues regarding human rights exist contrary to the law, often committed by local tribes, lawmakers and hardline clerics. Journalists in Afghanistan face threat from both the security forces and insurgents.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">[261]</a></sup> The Afghan Journalists Safety Committee (AJSC) claimed in 2017 that the Afghan government accounted for 46% of the attacks on Afghans journalists, while insurgents were responsible for rest of the attacks.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[262]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to <a href="/wiki/Global_Rights" title="Global Rights">Global Rights</a>, almost 90% of women in Afghanistan have experienced physical abuse, sexual abuse, psychological abuse or forced marriage. The perpetrators of these crimes are the families of the victim.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-265">[263]</a></sup> A 2009 proposal for a law against the violence of women could only be passed through a presidential decree.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_265-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-265">[263]</a></sup> In 2012, Afghanistan recorded 240 cases of <a href="/wiki/Honor_killing" title="Honor killing">honor killing</a>, but the total number is believed to be much higher. Of the reported honor killings, 21% were committed by the victims' husbands, 7% by their brothers, 4% by their fathers, and the rest by other relatives.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[264]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[265]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Homosexuality is <a href="/wiki/Taboo" title="Taboo">taboo</a> in Afghan society;<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[266]</a></sup> according to the Penal Code, homosexual intimacy is punished by up to a year in prison.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[267]</a></sup> With implementing <a href="/wiki/Sharia_law" class="mw-redirect" title="Sharia law">Sharia law</a> offenders can be <a href="/wiki/Death_penalty_for_homosexuality" class="mw-redirect" title="Death penalty for homosexuality">punished by death</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[268]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[269]</a></sup> However an ancient tradition involving male homosexual acts between youngsters and older men (typically wealthy or elite people) called <i><a href="/wiki/Bacha_bazi" title="Bacha bazi">bacha bazi</a></i> persists. Despite being illegal, the people engaging in the act are not often punished. </p>
      <p>On August 14, 2020, <a href="/wiki/UN_Human_Rights_Council" class="mw-redirect" title="UN Human Rights Council">UN Human Rights Council</a> experts issued a joint statement urging Afghanistan officials to prevent the killings of <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_defenders" class="mw-redirect" title="Human rights defenders">human rights defenders</a> as there have been nine deaths of human rights defenders since January 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[270]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Afghanistan" title="Economy of Afghanistan">Economy of Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Afghan_pomegranate_processing.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Afghan_pomegranate_processing.jpg/220px-Afghan_pomegranate_processing.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Afghan_pomegranate_processing.jpg/330px-Afghan_pomegranate_processing.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Afghan_pomegranate_processing.jpg/440px-Afghan_pomegranate_processing.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="1500"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Afghan_pomegranate_processing.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Workers processing <a href="/wiki/Pomegranate_production_in_Afghanistan" title="Pomegranate production in Afghanistan">pomegranates</a> (<i>anaar</i>), which Afghanistan is famous for in Asia
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Afghanistan's nominal GDP was $21.7&nbsp;billion in 2018, or $72.9&nbsp;billion by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> (PPP).<sup id="cite_ref-imf2_12-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-12">[11]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita">GDP per capita</a> is $2,024 (PPP).<sup id="cite_ref-imf2_12-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-12">[11]</a></sup> Despite having $1&nbsp;trillion or more in mineral deposits,<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[271]</a></sup> it remains one of the world's <a href="/wiki/Least_developed_countries" title="Least developed countries">least developed countries</a>. Afghanistan's rough physical geography and its landlocked status has been cited as reasons why the country has always been among the least developed in the modern era â a factor where progress is also slowed by contemporary conflict and political instability.<sup id="cite_ref-auto7_182-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto7-182">[180]</a></sup> The country imports over $7&nbsp;billion worth of goods but exports only $784&nbsp;million, mainly fruits and <a href="/wiki/Nut_(fruit)" title="Nut (fruit)">nuts</a>. It has $2.8&nbsp;billion in <a href="/wiki/External_debt" title="External debt">external debt</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Factbook_10-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Factbook-10">[9]</a></sup> The service sector contributed the most to the GDP (55.9%) followed by agriculture (23%) and industry (21.1%).<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[272]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Afghan_women_at_a_textile_factory_in_Kabul.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Afghan_women_at_a_textile_factory_in_Kabul.jpg/220px-Afghan_women_at_a_textile_factory_in_Kabul.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="137" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Afghan_women_at_a_textile_factory_in_Kabul.jpg/330px-Afghan_women_at_a_textile_factory_in_Kabul.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Afghan_women_at_a_textile_factory_in_Kabul.jpg/440px-Afghan_women_at_a_textile_factory_in_Kabul.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3022" data-file-height="1877"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Afghan_women_at_a_textile_factory_in_Kabul.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Afghan women at a textile factory in Kabul
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>While the nation's current account deficit is largely financed with donor money, only a small portion is provided directly to the government budget. The rest is provided to non-budgetary expenditure and donor-designated projects through the United Nations system and non-governmental organizations.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[273]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Da_Afghanistan_Bank" title="Da Afghanistan Bank">Da Afghanistan Bank</a> serves as the central bank of the nation<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[274]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_afghani" title="Afghan afghani">Afghani</a> (AFN) is the national currency, with an exchange rate of about 75 Afghanis to 1 US dollar.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[275]</a></sup> A number of local and foreign banks operate in the country, including the <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan_International_Bank" title="Afghanistan International Bank">Afghanistan International Bank</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_Kabul_Bank" title="New Kabul Bank">New Kabul Bank</a>, <a href="/wiki/Azizi_Bank" title="Azizi Bank">Azizi Bank</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pashtany_Bank" title="Pashtany Bank">Pashtany Bank</a>, <a href="/wiki/Standard_Chartered_Bank" class="mw-redirect" title="Standard Chartered Bank">Standard Chartered Bank</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/First_MicroFinance_Bank-Afghanistan" class="mw-redirect" title="First MicroFinance Bank-Afghanistan">First Micro Finance Bank</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Afghan_carpets_being_sold.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Afghan_carpets_being_sold.jpg/220px-Afghan_carpets_being_sold.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="110" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Afghan_carpets_being_sold.jpg/330px-Afghan_carpets_being_sold.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Afghan_carpets_being_sold.jpg/440px-Afghan_carpets_being_sold.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="801"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Afghan_carpets_being_sold.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Afghan_rugs" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan rugs">Afghan rugs</a> are one of Afghanistan's main exports
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>One of the main drivers for the current economic recovery is the return of over 5&nbsp;million <a href="/wiki/Afghan_diaspora" title="Afghan diaspora">expatriates</a>, who brought with them entrepreneurship and wealth-creating skills as well as much needed funds to start up businesses. Many Afghans are now involved in construction, which is one of the largest industries in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[276]</a></sup> Some of the major national construction projects include the <span class="nowrap">$35 billion</span> New Kabul City next to the capital, the Aino Mena project in Kandahar, and the <a href="/wiki/Ghazi_Amanullah_Khan_Town" class="mw-redirect" title="Ghazi Amanullah Khan Town">Ghazi Amanullah Khan Town</a> near Jalalabad.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[277]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[278]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[279]</a></sup> Similar development projects have also begun in <a href="/wiki/Herat" title="Herat">Herat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mazar-e-Sharif" class="mw-redirect" title="Mazar-e-Sharif">Mazar-e-Sharif</a>, and other cities.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[280]</a></sup> An estimated 400,000 people enter the labor market each year.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[281]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Several small companies and factories began operating in different parts of the country, which not only provide revenues to the government but also create new jobs. Improvements to the business environment have resulted in more than $1.5&nbsp;billion in <a href="/wiki/Telecommunication" title="Telecommunication">telecom</a> investment and created more than 100,000 jobs since 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[282]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Afghan_rug" title="Afghan rug">Afghan rugs</a> are becoming popular again, allowing many carpet dealers around the country to hire more workers; in 2016â17 it was the fourth most exported group of items.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">[283]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Afghanistan is a member of <a href="/wiki/WTO" class="mw-redirect" title="WTO">WTO</a>, <a href="/wiki/SAARC" class="mw-redirect" title="SAARC">SAARC</a>, <a href="/wiki/Economic_Cooperation_Organization" title="Economic Cooperation Organization">ECO</a>, and <a href="/wiki/OIC" class="mw-redirect" title="OIC">OIC</a>. It holds an observer status in <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Shanghai Cooperation Organisation">SCO</a>. In 2018, a majority of imports come from either Iran, China, Pakistan and Kazakhstan, while 84% of exports are to Pakistan and India.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[284]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture">Agriculture</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Afghan_countryside.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Afghan_countryside.jpg/220px-Afghan_countryside.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="115" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Afghan_countryside.jpg/330px-Afghan_countryside.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Afghan_countryside.jpg/440px-Afghan_countryside.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4531" data-file-height="2362"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Afghan_countryside.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Agriculture is a dominant economic sector
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Agricultural production is the backbone of Afghanistan's economy<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[285]</a></sup> and has traditionally dominated the economy, employing about 40% of the workforce as of 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[286]</a></sup> The country is known for producing <a href="/wiki/Pomegranate_production_in_Afghanistan" title="Pomegranate production in Afghanistan">pomegranates</a>, grapes, apricots, melons, and several other fresh and dry fruits. It is also known as the world's largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Opium_production_in_Afghanistan" title="Opium production in Afghanistan">opium</a> â as much as 16% or more of the nation's economy is derived from the cultivation and sale of opium.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">[287]</a></sup> It is also one of the world's top producers of <a href="/wiki/Cannabis" title="Cannabis">cannabis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[288]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Afghan_Saffron.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Afghan_Saffron.jpg/220px-Afghan_Saffron.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Afghan_Saffron.jpg/330px-Afghan_Saffron.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Afghan_Saffron.jpg/440px-Afghan_Saffron.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4501" data-file-height="3001"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Afghan_Saffron.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Afghan <a href="/wiki/Saffron" title="Saffron">saffron</a> has been recognized as the world's best
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Saffron" title="Saffron">Saffron</a>, the most expensive spice, grows in Afghanistan, particularly <a href="/wiki/Herat_Province" title="Herat Province">Herat Province</a>. In recent years, there has been an uptick in saffron production, which authorities and farmers are trying to replace poppy cultivation. Between 2012 and 2019, the saffron cultivated and produced in Afghanistan was consecutively ranked the world's best by the International Taste and Quality Institute.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[289]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[290]</a></sup> Production hit record high in 2019 (19,469&nbsp;kg of saffron), and one kilogram is sold domestically between $634 and $1147.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[291]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mining">Mining</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mining_in_Afghanistan" title="Mining in Afghanistan">Mining in Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Lapis_Lazuli_from_Afganistan.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Lapis_Lazuli_from_Afganistan.jpg/170px-Lapis_Lazuli_from_Afganistan.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="228" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Lapis_Lazuli_from_Afganistan.jpg/255px-Lapis_Lazuli_from_Afganistan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Lapis_Lazuli_from_Afganistan.jpg/340px-Lapis_Lazuli_from_Afganistan.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1936" data-file-height="2592"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Lapis_Lazuli_from_Afganistan.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Lapis_lazuli" title="Lapis lazuli">Lapis lazuli</a> stones
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The country's natural resources include: coal, copper, iron ore, <a href="/wiki/Lithium" title="Lithium">lithium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uranium" title="Uranium">uranium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rare_earth_element" class="mw-redirect" title="Rare earth element">rare earth elements</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chromite" title="Chromite">chromite</a>, gold, <a href="/wiki/Zinc" title="Zinc">zinc</a>, <a href="/wiki/Talc" title="Talc">talc</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barite" class="mw-redirect" title="Barite">barite</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sulfur" title="Sulfur">sulfur</a>, lead, <a href="/wiki/Marble" title="Marble">marble</a>, precious and <a href="/wiki/Semi-precious_stones" class="mw-redirect" title="Semi-precious stones">semi-precious stones</a>, natural gas, and petroleum, among other things.<sup id="cite_ref-peters2007_294-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-peters2007-294">[292]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bgs_295-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bgs-295">[293]</a></sup> In 2010, US and Afghan government officials estimated that untapped mineral deposits located in 2007 by the <a href="/wiki/US_Geological_Survey" class="mw-redirect" title="US Geological Survey">US Geological Survey</a> are worth at least <span class="nowrap">$1 trillion</span>.<sup id="cite_ref-bbcminerals_296-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbcminerals-296">[294]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Michael_E._O%27Hanlon" title="Michael E. O'Hanlon">Michael E. O'Hanlon</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Brookings_Institution" title="Brookings Institution">Brookings Institution</a> estimated that if Afghanistan generates about $10&nbsp;billion per year from its <a href="/wiki/Mining_in_Afghanistan" title="Mining in Afghanistan">mineral deposits</a>, its <a href="/wiki/Gross_national_product" class="mw-redirect" title="Gross national product">gross national product</a> would double and provide long-term funding for Afghan security forces and other critical needs.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[295]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/United_States_Geological_Survey" title="United States Geological Survey">United States Geological Survey</a> (USGS) estimated in 2006 that northern Afghanistan has an average 460&nbsp;million&nbsp;m<sup>3</sup> (2.9&nbsp;billion&nbsp;bbl) of <a href="/wiki/Crude_oil" class="mw-redirect" title="Crude oil">crude oil</a>, 440&nbsp;billion&nbsp;m<sup>3</sup> (15.7&nbsp;trillion&nbsp;cu&nbsp;ft) of natural gas, and 67&nbsp;billion&nbsp;L (562&nbsp;million&nbsp;US&nbsp;bbl) of <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas_liquids" class="mw-redirect" title="Natural gas liquids">natural gas liquids</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-klett2006_298-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-klett2006-298">[296]</a></sup> In 2011, Afghanistan signed an oil exploration contract with <a href="/wiki/China_National_Petroleum_Corporation" title="China National Petroleum Corporation">China National Petroleum Corporation</a> (CNPC) for the development of three oil fields along the Amu Darya river in the north.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[297]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The country has significant amounts of <a href="/wiki/Lithium" title="Lithium">lithium</a>, copper, gold, coal, iron ore, and other <a href="/wiki/Minerals" class="mw-redirect" title="Minerals">minerals</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-peters2007_294-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-peters2007-294">[292]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bgs_295-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bgs-295">[293]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Afghanistan's_Mineral_Fortune_300-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Afghanistan's_Mineral_Fortune-300">[298]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Khanashin" title="Khanashin">Khanashin</a> <a href="/wiki/Carbonatite" title="Carbonatite">carbonatite</a> in Helmand Province contains 1,000,000 tonnes (980,000 <a href="/wiki/Long_ton" title="Long ton">long tons</a>; 1,100,000 <a href="/wiki/Short_ton" title="Short ton">short tons</a>) of <a href="/wiki/Rare_earth_element" class="mw-redirect" title="Rare earth element">rare earth elements</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-tucker2011_301-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tucker2011-301">[299]</a></sup> In 2007, a 30-year lease was granted for the <a href="/wiki/Mes_Aynak#Copper_Mine" title="Mes Aynak">Aynak</a> copper mine to the <a href="/wiki/China_Metallurgical_Group" class="mw-redirect" title="China Metallurgical Group">China Metallurgical Group</a> for $3&nbsp;billion,<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[300]</a></sup> making it the biggest foreign investment and private business venture in Afghanistan's history.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[301]</a></sup> The state-run <a href="/wiki/Steel_Authority_of_India" title="Steel Authority of India">Steel Authority of India</a> won the mining rights to develop the huge <a href="/wiki/Hajigak_Pass" title="Hajigak Pass">Hajigak</a> iron ore deposit in central Afghanistan.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[302]</a></sup> Government officials estimate that 30% of the country's untapped mineral deposits are worth at least <span class="nowrap">$1 trillion</span>.<sup id="cite_ref-bbcminerals_296-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbcminerals-296">[294]</a></sup> One official asserted that "this will become the backbone of the Afghan economy" and a Pentagon memo stated that Afghanistan could become the "Saudi Arabia of lithium".<sup id="cite_ref-risen2010_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-risen2010-305">[303]</a></sup> In a 2011 news story, the <i><a href="/wiki/The_Christian_Science_Monitor" title="The Christian Science Monitor">CSM</a></i> reported, "The United States and other Western nations that have borne the brunt of the cost of the Afghan war have been conspicuously absent from the bidding process on Afghanistan's mineral deposits, leaving it mostly to regional powers."<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[304]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Access to <a href="/wiki/Biocapacity" title="Biocapacity">biocapacity</a> in Afghanistan is lower than world average. In 2016, Afghanistan had 0.43 global hectares<sup id="cite_ref-footprintdata_307-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-footprintdata-307">[305]</a></sup> of biocapacity per person within its territory, much less than the world average of 1.6 global hectares per person.<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">[306]</a></sup> In 2016 Afghanistan used 0.73 global hectares of biocapacity per person - their <a href="/wiki/Ecological_footprint" title="Ecological footprint">ecological footprint</a> of consumption. This means they use just under double as much biocapacity as Afghanistan contains. As a result, Afghanistan is running a biocapacity deficit.<sup id="cite_ref-footprintdata_307-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-footprintdata-307">[305]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h2> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Afghanistan_electricity_production.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Afghanistan_electricity_production.svg/220px-Afghanistan_electricity_production.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="181" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Afghanistan_electricity_production.svg/330px-Afghanistan_electricity_production.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Afghanistan_electricity_production.svg/440px-Afghanistan_electricity_production.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="765" data-file-height="630"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Afghanistan_electricity_production.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Afghanistan electricity production and net imports 1980-2019
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kajaki_Dam_and_spillway_in_2012.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Kajaki_Dam_and_spillway_in_2012.jpg/220px-Kajaki_Dam_and_spillway_in_2012.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Kajaki_Dam_and_spillway_in_2012.jpg/330px-Kajaki_Dam_and_spillway_in_2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Kajaki_Dam_and_spillway_in_2012.jpg/440px-Kajaki_Dam_and_spillway_in_2012.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3150" data-file-height="2100"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kajaki_Dam_and_spillway_in_2012.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Kajaki_Dam" title="Kajaki Dam">Kajaki Dam</a> in Helmand Province produces over 52 megawatts of electricity
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Afghanistan" title="Energy in Afghanistan">Energy in Afghanistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_Afghanistan" title="Renewable energy in Afghanistan">Renewable energy in Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <p>According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>, 98% of the rural population have access to electricity in 2018, up from 28% in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">[307]</a></sup> Overall the figure stands at 98.7%.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[308]</a></sup> As of 2016, Afghanistan produces 1,400 <a href="/wiki/Megawatt" class="mw-redirect" title="Megawatt">megawatts</a> of power, but still imports the majority of electricity via transmission lines from Iran and the Central Asian states.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[309]</a></sup> The majority of electricity production is via <a href="/wiki/Hydropower" title="Hydropower">hydropower</a>, helped by the amount of rivers and streams that flow from the mountains.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[310]</a></sup> However electricity is not always reliable and blackouts happen, including in Kabul.<sup id="cite_ref-auto1_313-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-313">[311]</a></sup> In recent years an increasing number of <a href="/wiki/Solar_power" title="Solar power">solar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Biomass" title="Biomass">biomass</a> and wind power plants have been constructed.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[312]</a></sup> Currently under development are the <a href="/wiki/CASA-1000" title="CASA-1000">CASA-1000</a> project which will transmit electricity from Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan, and the <a href="/wiki/Turkmenistan-Afghanistan-Pakistan-India_pipeline" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkmenistan-Afghanistan-Pakistan-India pipeline">Turkmenistan-Afghanistan-Pakistan-India</a> (TAPI) gas pipeline.<sup id="cite_ref-auto1_313-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-313">[311]</a></sup> Power is managed by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Da_Afghanistan_Breshna_Sherkat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Da Afghanistan Breshna Sherkat (page does not exist)">Da Afghanistan Breshna Sherkat</a> (DABS, Afghanistan Electricity Company). </p>
      <p>Important dams include the <a href="/wiki/Kajaki_Dam" title="Kajaki Dam">Kajaki Dam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dahla_Dam" title="Dahla Dam">Dahla Dam</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Sardeh_Band_Dam" title="Sardeh Band Dam">Sardeh Band Dam</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto2_186-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-186">[184]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Afghanistan" title="Tourism in Afghanistan">Tourism in Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Contrasts_(4292970991).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Contrasts_%284292970991%29.jpg/220px-Contrasts_%284292970991%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Contrasts_%284292970991%29.jpg/330px-Contrasts_%284292970991%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Contrasts_%284292970991%29.jpg/440px-Contrasts_%284292970991%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3872" data-file-height="2592"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Contrasts_(4292970991).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Band-e_Amir_National_Park" title="Band-e Amir National Park">Band-e Amir National Park</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Tourism is a small industry in Afghanistan due to security issues. Nevertheless, some 20,000 foreign tourists visit the country annually as of 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">[313]</a></sup> In particular an important region for domestic and international tourism is the picturesque <a href="/wiki/Bamyan" title="Bamyan">Bamyan</a> Valley, which includes lakes, canyons and historical sites, helped by the fact it is in a safe area away from insurgent activity.<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">[314]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">[315]</a></sup> Smaller numbers visit and trek in regions such as the <a href="/wiki/Wakhan" title="Wakhan">Wakhan</a> Valley, which is also one of the world's most remote communities.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[316]</a></sup> From the late 1960s onwards, Afghanistan was a popular stop on the famous <a href="/wiki/Hippie_trail" title="Hippie trail">hippie trail</a>, attracting many Europeans and Americans. Coming from Iran, the trail traveled through various Afghan provinces and cities including <a href="/wiki/Herat" title="Herat">Herat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kandahar" title="Kandahar">Kandahar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kabul" title="Kabul">Kabul</a> before crossing to northern Pakistan, northern India, and <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[317]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[318]</a></sup> Tourism peaked in 1977, the year before the start of political instability and armed conflict.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[319]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Jam_afghanistan_ghorprovince_islamic_architecture.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Jam_afghanistan_ghorprovince_islamic_architecture.jpg/170px-Jam_afghanistan_ghorprovince_islamic_architecture.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="226" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Jam_afghanistan_ghorprovince_islamic_architecture.jpg/255px-Jam_afghanistan_ghorprovince_islamic_architecture.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Jam_afghanistan_ghorprovince_islamic_architecture.jpg/340px-Jam_afghanistan_ghorprovince_islamic_architecture.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="1065"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Jam_afghanistan_ghorprovince_islamic_architecture.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Minaret_of_Jam" title="Minaret of Jam">Minaret of Jam</a> is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, currently under threat by erosion and flooding
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The city of <a href="/wiki/Ghazni" title="Ghazni">Ghazni</a> has significant history and historical sites, and together with <a href="/wiki/Bamyan" title="Bamyan">Bamyan</a> city have in recent years been voted Islamic Cultural Capital and South Asia Cultural Capital respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">[320]</a></sup> The cities of <a href="/wiki/Herat" title="Herat">Herat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kandahar" title="Kandahar">Kandahar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Balkh" title="Balkh">Balkh</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Zaranj" title="Zaranj">Zaranj</a> are also very historic. The <a href="/wiki/Minaret_of_Jam" title="Minaret of Jam">Minaret of Jam</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Hari_River,_Afghanistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Hari River, Afghanistan">Hari River</a> valley is a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_site" class="mw-redirect" title="UNESCO World Heritage site">UNESCO World Heritage site</a>. A cloak reputedly worn by Islam's prophet <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a> is kept inside the <a href="/wiki/Shrine_of_the_Cloak" class="mw-redirect" title="Shrine of the Cloak">Shrine of the Cloak</a> in Kandahar, a city founded by <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a> and the first capital of Afghanistan. The <a href="/wiki/Citadel_of_Alexander" class="mw-redirect" title="Citadel of Alexander">citadel of Alexander</a> in the western city of Herat has been renovated in recent years and is a popular attraction. In the north of the country is the <a href="/wiki/Shrine_of_Ali" class="mw-redirect" title="Shrine of Ali">Shrine of Ali</a>, believed by many to be the location where <a href="/wiki/Ali" title="Ali">Ali</a> was buried.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDupree1997115_323-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDupree1997115-323">[321]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_Afghanistan" title="National Museum of Afghanistan">National Museum of Afghanistan</a> is located in Kabul and hosts a large number of Buddhist, <a href="/wiki/Bactria" title="Bactria">Bactrian</a> Greek and early Islamic antiquities; the museum suffered greatly by civil war but has been slowly restoring since the early 2000s.<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">[322]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Communication">Communication</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Communications_in_Afghanistan" title="Communications in Afghanistan">Communications in Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Telecommunication services in Afghanistan are provided by <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Telecom" title="Afghan Telecom">Afghan Telecom</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Wireless" title="Afghan Wireless">Afghan Wireless</a>, <a href="/wiki/Etisalat" title="Etisalat">Etisalat</a>, <a href="/wiki/MTN_Group" title="MTN Group">MTN Group</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Roshan_(telco)" title="Roshan (telco)">Roshan</a>. The country uses its own space <a href="/wiki/Satellite" title="Satellite">satellite</a> called <a href="/wiki/Afghansat_1" title="Afghansat 1">Afghansat 1</a>, which provides services to millions of phone, internet, and television subscribers. By 2001 following years of civil war, telecommunications was virtually a non-existent sector, but by 2016 it had grown to a $2&nbsp;billion industry, with 22&nbsp;million mobile phone subscribers and 5&nbsp;million internet users. The sector employs at least 120,000 people nationwide.<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">[323]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Afghanistan" title="Transport in Afghanistan">Transport in Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Afghanistan" title="List of airports in Afghanistan">List of airports in Afghanistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Afghanistan" title="Rail transport in Afghanistan">Rail transport in Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Horse_carriage,_Herat,_Afghanistan.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Horse_carriage%2C_Herat%2C_Afghanistan.jpg/220px-Horse_carriage%2C_Herat%2C_Afghanistan.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Horse_carriage%2C_Herat%2C_Afghanistan.jpg/330px-Horse_carriage%2C_Herat%2C_Afghanistan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Horse_carriage%2C_Herat%2C_Afghanistan.jpg/440px-Horse_carriage%2C_Herat%2C_Afghanistan.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1365"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Horse_carriage,_Herat,_Afghanistan.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Horse carts are still used for carrying goods in some places
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Due to Afghanistan's geography, transport between various parts of the country have historically been difficult. The backbone of Afghanistan's road network is <a href="/wiki/Highway_1_(Afghanistan)" title="Highway 1 (Afghanistan)">Highway 1</a>, often called the "Ring Road", which extends for 2,210 kilometers (1,370&nbsp;mi) and connects five major cities: Kabul, Ghazni, Kandahar, Herat and Mazar-i-Sharif,<sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">[324]</a></sup> with spurs to Kunduz and Jalalabad and various border crossings, while skirting around the mountains of the Hindu Kush.<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">[325]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Ring Road is crucially important for domestic and international trade and the economy.<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">[326]</a></sup> A key portion of the Ring Road is the <a href="/wiki/Salang_Tunnel" title="Salang Tunnel">Salang Tunnel</a>, completed in 1964, which facilitates travel through the Hindu Kush mountain range and connects northern and southern Afghanistan.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">[327]</a></sup> It is the only land route that connects Central Asia to the <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">[328]</a></sup> Several mountain passes allow travel between the Hindu Kush in other areas. Serious traffic accidents are common on Afghan roads and highways, particularly on the <a href="/wiki/Kabul%E2%80%93Kandahar_Highway" title="KabulâKandahar Highway">KabulâKandahar</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Kabul%E2%80%93Jalalabad_Road" title="KabulâJalalabad Road">KabulâJalalabad Road</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">[329]</a></sup> Traveling by bus in Afghanistan remains dangerous due to militant activities.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">[330]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ariana_Afghan_A310-300_F-GEMO.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Ariana_Afghan_A310-300_F-GEMO.jpg/220px-Ariana_Afghan_A310-300_F-GEMO.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="139" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Ariana_Afghan_A310-300_F-GEMO.jpg/330px-Ariana_Afghan_A310-300_F-GEMO.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Ariana_Afghan_A310-300_F-GEMO.jpg/440px-Ariana_Afghan_A310-300_F-GEMO.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1214" data-file-height="768"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ariana_Afghan_A310-300_F-GEMO.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>An <a href="/wiki/Ariana_Afghan_Airlines" title="Ariana Afghan Airlines">Ariana Afghan Airlines</a> <a href="/wiki/Airbus_A310" title="Airbus A310">Airbus A310</a> in 2006
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Air transport in Afghanistan is provided by the national carrier, <a href="/wiki/Ariana_Afghan_Airlines" title="Ariana Afghan Airlines">Ariana Afghan Airlines</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-EU_To_Impose_Ban_on_Afghan_Planes_333-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU_To_Impose_Ban_on_Afghan_Planes-333">[331]</a></sup> and by the private company <a href="/wiki/Kam_Air" title="Kam Air">Kam Air</a>. Airlines from a number of countries also provide flights in and out of the country. These include <a href="/wiki/Air_India" title="Air India">Air India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emirates_(airline)" title="Emirates (airline)">Emirates</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gulf_Air" title="Gulf Air">Gulf Air</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iran_Aseman_Airlines" title="Iran Aseman Airlines">Iran Aseman Airlines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_International_Airlines" title="Pakistan International Airlines">Pakistan International Airlines</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Airlines" title="Turkish Airlines">Turkish Airlines</a>. The country has four international airports: <a href="/wiki/Hamid_Karzai_International_Airport" title="Hamid Karzai International Airport">Hamid Karzai International Airport</a> (formerly Kabul International Airport), <a href="/wiki/Kandahar_International_Airport" title="Kandahar International Airport">Kandahar International Airport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Herat_International_Airport" title="Herat International Airport">Herat International Airport</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mazar-e_Sharif_International_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Mazar-e Sharif International Airport">Mazar-e Sharif International Airport</a>. Including domestic airports, there are 43.<sup id="cite_ref-Factbook_10-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Factbook-10">[9]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bagram_Air_Base" class="mw-redirect" title="Bagram Air Base">Bagram Air Base</a> is a major military airfield. </p>
      <p>The country has three rail links: one, a 75-kilometer (47&nbsp;mi) line from <a href="/wiki/Mazar-i-Sharif" title="Mazar-i-Sharif">Mazar-i-Sharif</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan%E2%80%93Uzbekistan_Friendship_Bridge" title="AfghanistanâUzbekistan Friendship Bridge">Uzbekistan border</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[332]</a></sup> a 10-kilometer (6.2&nbsp;mi) long line from <a href="/wiki/Toraghundi" class="mw-redirect" title="Toraghundi">Toraghundi</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Turkmenistan" title="Turkmenistan">Turkmenistan</a> border (where it continues as part of <a href="/wiki/Turkmen_Railways" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkmen Railways">Turkmen Railways</a>); and a short link from <a href="/wiki/Aqina" title="Aqina">Aqina</a> across the Turkmen border to <a href="/wiki/Kerki" title="Kerki">Kerki</a>, which is planned to be extended further across Afghanistan.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">[333]</a></sup> These lines are used for freight only and there is no passenger service. A rail line between <a href="/wiki/Khaf,_Iran" title="Khaf, Iran">Khaf</a>, Iran and <a href="/wiki/Herat" title="Herat">Herat</a>, western Afghanistan, intended for both freight and passengers, is under construction as of 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">[334]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[335]</a></sup> About 125 kilometers (78&nbsp;mi) of the line will lie on the Afghan side.<sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338">[336]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">[337]</a></sup> There are various proposals for the construction of additional rail lines in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">[338]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Private vehicle ownership has increased substantially since the early 2000s. Taxis are yellow in color and consist of both cars and <a href="/wiki/Auto_rickshaw" title="Auto rickshaw">auto rickshaws</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[339]</a></sup> In rural Afghanistan, villagers often use <a href="/wiki/Donkey" title="Donkey">donkeys</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mule" title="Mule">mules</a> or <a href="/wiki/Horse" title="Horse">horses</a> to transport or carry goods. <a href="/wiki/Camel" title="Camel">Camels</a> are primarily used by the <a href="/wiki/Kochi" title="Kochi">Kochi</a> nomads.<sup id="cite_ref-auto9_198-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto9-198">[196]</a></sup> Bicycles are popular throughout Afghanistan.<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">[340]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Afghanistan" title="Education in Afghanistan">Education in Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:UNESCO_Institute_of_Statistics_Afghanistan_Literacy_Rate_population_plus15_1980-2018.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/UNESCO_Institute_of_Statistics_Afghanistan_Literacy_Rate_population_plus15_1980-2018.png/250px-UNESCO_Institute_of_Statistics_Afghanistan_Literacy_Rate_population_plus15_1980-2018.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="159" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/UNESCO_Institute_of_Statistics_Afghanistan_Literacy_Rate_population_plus15_1980-2018.png/375px-UNESCO_Institute_of_Statistics_Afghanistan_Literacy_Rate_population_plus15_1980-2018.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/UNESCO_Institute_of_Statistics_Afghanistan_Literacy_Rate_population_plus15_1980-2018.png/500px-UNESCO_Institute_of_Statistics_Afghanistan_Literacy_Rate_population_plus15_1980-2018.png 2x" data-file-width="504" data-file-height="320"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:UNESCO_Institute_of_Statistics_Afghanistan_Literacy_Rate_population_plus15_1980-2018.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
