         </div>UNESCO Institute of Statistics Afghanistan Literacy Rate population plus15 1980â2018
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Schoolgirls_in_Bamozai.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Schoolgirls_in_Bamozai.JPG/220px-Schoolgirls_in_Bamozai.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Schoolgirls_in_Bamozai.JPG/330px-Schoolgirls_in_Bamozai.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Schoolgirls_in_Bamozai.JPG/440px-Schoolgirls_in_Bamozai.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3008" data-file-height="2000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Schoolgirls_in_Bamozai.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>School children in <a href="/wiki/Ghazni_Province" title="Ghazni Province">Ghazni Province</a> â the number of children attending school at primary level has increased from 5% in 2000 to 57% in 2018
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Education_in_Afghanistan" title="Education in Afghanistan">Education in Afghanistan</a> includes <a href="/wiki/K%E2%80%9312" title="Kâ12">Kâ12</a> and higher education, which is overseen by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Afghanistan)" title="Ministry of Education (Afghanistan)">Ministry of Education</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Higher_Education_(Afghanistan)" title="Ministry of Higher Education (Afghanistan)">Ministry of Higher Education</a>. There are over 16,000 schools in the country and roughly 9&nbsp;million students. Of this, about 60% are males and 40% females. Over 174,000 students are enrolled in different <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Afghanistan" title="List of universities in Afghanistan">universities around the country</a>. About 21% of these are females.<sup id="cite_ref-USAID-Education_343-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USAID-Education-343">[341]</a></sup> Former Education Minister <a href="/wiki/Ghulam_Farooq_Wardak" title="Ghulam Farooq Wardak">Ghulam Farooq Wardak</a> had stated that construction of 8,000 schools is required for the remaining children who are deprived of <a href="/wiki/Formal_learning" title="Formal learning">formal learning</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Wardak_seeks_$3b_in_aid_for_school_buildings_344-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wardak_seeks_$3b_in_aid_for_school_buildings-344">[342]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The top universities in Afghanistan are the <a href="/wiki/American_University_of_Afghanistan" title="American University of Afghanistan">American University of Afghanistan</a> (AUAF) followed by <a href="/wiki/Kabul_University" title="Kabul University">Kabul University</a> (KU), both of which are located in Kabul. The <a href="/wiki/National_Military_Academy_of_Afghanistan" title="National Military Academy of Afghanistan">National Military Academy of Afghanistan</a>, modeled after the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Military_Academy" title="United States Military Academy">United States Military Academy</a> at West Point, is a four-year military development institution dedicated to graduating officers for the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Armed_Forces" title="Afghan Armed Forces">Afghan Armed Forces</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Defense_University" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan Defense University">Afghan Defense University</a> was constructed near <a href="/wiki/Qargha" class="mw-redirect" title="Qargha">Qargha</a> in Kabul. Major universities outside of Kabul include <a href="/wiki/Kandahar_University" title="Kandahar University">Kandahar University</a> in the south, <a href="/wiki/Herat_University" title="Herat University">Herat University</a> in the northwest, <a href="/wiki/Balkh_University" title="Balkh University">Balkh University</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kunduz_University" title="Kunduz University">Kunduz University</a> in the north, <a href="/wiki/Nangarhar_University" title="Nangarhar University">Nangarhar University</a> and <a href="/wiki/Khost_University" class="mw-redirect" title="Khost University">Khost University</a> in the east. The United States is building six faculties of education and five provincial teacher training colleges around the country, two large secondary schools in Kabul, and one school in Jalalabad.<sup id="cite_ref-USAID-Education_343-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USAID-Education-343">[341]</a></sup> Kabul University was founded in 1932 and is a respected institute that played a significant part in the country's education;<sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">[343]</a></sup> from the 1960s the Kabul University was also a hotbed of radical political ideologies such as Marxism and Islamism, which played major parts in society, politics and the war that began in 1978.<sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">[344]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As of 2018 the literacy rate of the population age 15 and older is 43.02% (males 55.48% and females 29.81%).<sup id="cite_ref-UNESCO_UIS_Afghanistan_347-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNESCO_UIS_Afghanistan-347">[345]</a></sup> The Afghan National Security Forces are provided with mandatory literacy courses.<sup id="cite_ref-autogeneratedmil_348-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogeneratedmil-348">[346]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Afghanistan" title="Health in Afghanistan">Health in Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>, Afghanistan is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">15th least developed country in the world</a>. The average <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy" title="List of countries by life expectancy">life expectancy</a> is estimated to be around 60 years.<sup id="cite_ref-WHO_349-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WHO-349">[347]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-uis.unesco.org_350-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-uis.unesco.org-350">[348]</a></sup> The country's <a href="/wiki/Maternal_mortality" class="mw-redirect" title="Maternal mortality">maternal mortality</a> rate is 396 deaths/100,000 live births and its <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">infant mortality</a> rate is 66<sup id="cite_ref-uis.unesco.org_350-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-uis.unesco.org-350">[348]</a></sup> to 112.8 deaths in every 1,000 live births.<sup id="cite_ref-Factbook_10-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Factbook-10">[9]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Public_Health_(Afghanistan)" title="Ministry of Public Health (Afghanistan)">Ministry of Public Health</a> plans to cut the infant mortality rate to 400 for every 100,000 live births before 2020. The country has more than 3,000 <a href="/wiki/Midwifery" title="Midwifery">midwives</a>, with an additional 300 to 400 being trained each year.<sup id="cite_ref-csm_351-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-csm-351">[349]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are over 100 <a href="/wiki/Hospitals_in_Afghanistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Hospitals in Afghanistan">hospitals in Afghanistan</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">[350]</a></sup> with the most advanced treatments being available in Kabul. The <a href="/wiki/French_Medical_Institute_for_Children" title="French Medical Institute for Children">French Medical Institute for Children</a> and <a href="/wiki/Indira_Gandhi_Children%27s_Hospital" title="Indira Gandhi Children's Hospital">Indira Gandhi Children's Hospital</a> in Kabul are the leading <a href="/wiki/Children%27s_hospital" title="Children's hospital">children's hospitals</a> in the country. Some of the other leading hospitals in Kabul include the <a href="/wiki/Jamhuriat_Hospital" title="Jamhuriat Hospital">Jamhuriat Hospital</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jinnah_Hospital_(Kabul)" class="mw-redirect" title="Jinnah Hospital (Kabul)">Jinnah Hospital</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">[351]</a></sup> In spite of all this, many Afghans travel to Pakistan and India for advanced treatment. </p>
      <p>It was reported in 2006 that nearly 60% of the Afghan population lives within a two-hour walk of the nearest health facility.<sup id="cite_ref-USAID-Health_354-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USAID-Health-354">[352]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Disability" title="Disability">Disability</a> rate is also high in Afghanistan due to the decades of war.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[353]</a></sup> It was reported recently that about 80,000 people are missing limbs.<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">[354]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">[355]</a></sup> Non-governmental charities such as <a href="/wiki/Save_the_Children" title="Save the Children">Save the Children</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mahboba%27s_Promise" title="Mahboba's Promise">Mahboba's Promise</a> assist orphans in association with governmental structures.<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">[356]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Demographic_and_Health_Surveys" title="Demographic and Health Surveys">Demographic and Health Surveys</a> is working with the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Health_Management_Research" title="Indian Institute of Health Management Research">Indian Institute of Health Management Research</a> and others to conduct a survey in Afghanistan focusing on <a href="/wiki/Maternal_death" title="Maternal death">maternal death</a>, among other things.<sup id="cite_ref-MEASUREDHS_359-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MEASUREDHS-359">[357]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Afghanistan" title="Culture of Afghanistan">Culture of Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:CH-NB_-_Afghanistan,_Kulm_(Khulm,_Kholm)-_Menschen_-_Annemarie_Schwarzenbach_-_SLA-Schwarzenbach-A-5-21-110.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/CH-NB_-_Afghanistan%2C_Kulm_%28Khulm%2C_Kholm%29-_Menschen_-_Annemarie_Schwarzenbach_-_SLA-Schwarzenbach-A-5-21-110.jpg/220px-CH-NB_-_Afghanistan%2C_Kulm_%28Khulm%2C_Kholm%29-_Menschen_-_Annemarie_Schwarzenbach_-_SLA-Schwarzenbach-A-5-21-110.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="176" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/CH-NB_-_Afghanistan%2C_Kulm_%28Khulm%2C_Kholm%29-_Menschen_-_Annemarie_Schwarzenbach_-_SLA-Schwarzenbach-A-5-21-110.jpg/330px-CH-NB_-_Afghanistan%2C_Kulm_%28Khulm%2C_Kholm%29-_Menschen_-_Annemarie_Schwarzenbach_-_SLA-Schwarzenbach-A-5-21-110.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/CH-NB_-_Afghanistan%2C_Kulm_%28Khulm%2C_Kholm%29-_Menschen_-_Annemarie_Schwarzenbach_-_SLA-Schwarzenbach-A-5-21-110.jpg/440px-CH-NB_-_Afghanistan%2C_Kulm_%28Khulm%2C_Kholm%29-_Menschen_-_Annemarie_Schwarzenbach_-_SLA-Schwarzenbach-A-5-21-110.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5038" data-file-height="4032"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:CH-NB_-_Afghanistan,_Kulm_(Khulm,_Kholm)-_Menschen_-_Annemarie_Schwarzenbach_-_SLA-Schwarzenbach-A-5-21-110.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>An Afghan family near <a href="/wiki/Kholm,_Afghanistan" title="Kholm, Afghanistan">Kholm</a>, 1939 â most Afghans are tribal
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Since antiquity, Afghanistan has been part of what is now referred to as Central Asia â politically, economically, and culturally.<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">[358]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Afghanistan is a predominantly tribal society, with different regions of the country having their own cultures as a result of differing ethnicities and geographic obstacles that makes much of the country remote.<sup id="cite_ref-auto7_182-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto7-182">[180]</a></sup> Family is the mainstay of Afghan society and families are often headed by a <a href="/wiki/Patriarch" title="Patriarch">patriarch</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_361-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-361">[359]</a></sup> In the southern and eastern region, the people live according to the <a href="/wiki/Pashtun_culture" title="Pashtun culture">Pashtun culture</a> by following <a href="/wiki/Pashtunwali" title="Pashtunwali">Pashtunwali</a> (the Pashtun way).<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">[360]</a></sup> Key tenets of Pashtunwali include <a href="/wiki/Melmastia" class="mw-redirect" title="Melmastia">hospitality</a>, the provision of <a href="/wiki/Nanawatai" title="Nanawatai">sanctuary</a> to those seeking refuge, and revenge for the shedding of blood.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDupree1997126_363-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDupree1997126-363">[361]</a></sup> The Pashtuns (and <a href="/wiki/Baloch_people" title="Baloch people">Baloch</a>) are largely connected to the culture of South Asia. The remaining Afghans are culturally <a href="/wiki/Persianization" title="Persianization">Persian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">Turkic</a>. Some non-Pashtuns who live in proximity with Pashtuns have adopted Pashtunwali in a process called <a href="/wiki/Pashtunization" title="Pashtunization">Pashtunization</a>, while some Pashtuns have been <a href="/wiki/Persianization" title="Persianization">Persianized</a>. Those who have lived in Pakistan and Iran over the last 30 years have been further influenced by the cultures of those neighboring nations. The Afghan people are known to be strongly religious.<sup id="cite_ref-auto6_214-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto6-214">[212]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Afghans, particularly Pashtuns, are noted for their tribal solidarity and high regard for personal honor.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarfield201259_364-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarfield201259-364">[362]</a></sup> One writer considers the tribal system to be the best way of organizing large groups of people in a country that is geographically difficult, and in a society that, from a materialistic point of view, has an uncomplicated lifestyle.<sup id="cite_ref-Heathcote_365-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Heathcote-365">[363]</a></sup> There are various <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_Afghanistan" title="Ethnic groups in Afghanistan">Afghan tribes</a>, and an estimated 2â3&nbsp;million <a href="/wiki/Kochi_people" title="Kochi people">nomads</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">[364]</a></sup> Afghan culture is deeply <a href="/wiki/Islamic_culture" title="Islamic culture">Islamic</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarfield201240â41_367-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarfield201240â41-367">[365]</a></sup> but pre-Islamic practices persist.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDupree1997104_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDupree1997104-368">[366]</a></sup> One example is <i><a href="/wiki/Bacha_bazi" title="Bacha bazi">bacha bazi</a></i>, a term for activities involving sexual relations between older men and younger adolescent men, or boys.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_Rustam_Qobil_369-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Rustam_Qobil-369">[367]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Child_marriage_in_Afghanistan" title="Child marriage in Afghanistan">Child marriage</a> is prevalent in Afghanistan;<sup id="cite_ref-Medica_Mondiale_370-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Medica_Mondiale-370">[368]</a></sup> the legal age for marriage is 16.<sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">[369]</a></sup> The most preferred marriage in Afghan society is to one's <a href="/wiki/Parallel_cousin" class="mw-redirect" title="Parallel cousin">parallel cousin</a>, and the groom is often expected to pay a <a href="/wiki/Bride_price" title="Bride price">bride price</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDupree1997122,_198_372-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDupree1997122,_198-372">[370]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kuchi_Village.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Kuchi_Village.jpg/220px-Kuchi_Village.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Kuchi_Village.jpg/330px-Kuchi_Village.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Kuchi_Village.jpg/440px-Kuchi_Village.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3110" data-file-height="2332"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kuchi_Village.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A house occupied by nomadic <i>kochi</i> people in <a href="/wiki/Nangarhar_Province" title="Nangarhar Province">Nangarhar Province</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In the villages, families typically occupy <a href="/wiki/Mudbrick" title="Mudbrick">mudbrick</a> houses, or compounds with mudbrick or <a href="/wiki/Stone_wall" title="Stone wall">stone walled</a> houses. Villages typically have a headman (<i>malik</i>), a master for water disribution (<i>mirab</i>) and a religious teacher (<i>mullah</i>). Men would typically work on the fields, joined by women during harvest.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_361-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-361">[359]</a></sup> About 15% of the population are <a href="/wiki/Nomadic" class="mw-redirect" title="Nomadic">nomadic</a>, locally called <i><a href="/wiki/Kochi" title="Kochi">kochis</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto7_182-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto7-182">[180]</a></sup> When nomads pass villages they often buy supplies such as tea, wheat and <a href="/wiki/Kerosene" title="Kerosene">kerosene</a> from the villagers; villagers buy <a href="/wiki/Wool" title="Wool">wool</a> and milk from the nomads.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_361-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-361">[359]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Old_men_of_Herat,_Afghanistan.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Old_men_of_Herat%2C_Afghanistan.jpg/220px-Old_men_of_Herat%2C_Afghanistan.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Old_men_of_Herat%2C_Afghanistan.jpg/330px-Old_men_of_Herat%2C_Afghanistan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Old_men_of_Herat%2C_Afghanistan.jpg/440px-Old_men_of_Herat%2C_Afghanistan.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1365"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Old_men_of_Herat,_Afghanistan.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Old men in <a href="/wiki/Herat" title="Herat">Herat</a> wearing <i>perahan tunban</i> with a turban (<i>lungi</i>)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Afghan_clothing" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan clothing">Afghan clothing</a> for both men and women typically consists of various forms of <a href="/wiki/Shalwar_kameez" title="Shalwar kameez">shalwar kameez</a>, especially <i><a href="/wiki/Perahan_tunban" class="mw-redirect" title="Perahan tunban">perahan tunban</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Khet_partug" class="mw-redirect" title="Khet partug">khet partug</a></i>. Women would normally wear a <i><a href="/wiki/Chador" title="Chador">chador</a></i> for head covering; some women, typically from highly conservative communities, wear the <i><a href="/wiki/Burqa" title="Burqa">burqa</a></i>, a full body covering. These were worn by some women of the Pashtun community well before Islam came to the region, but the <a href="/wiki/Taliban" title="Taliban">Taliban</a> enforced this dress on women when they were in power.<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">[371]</a></sup> Another popular dress is the <i><a href="/wiki/Chapan" title="Chapan">chapan</a></i> which acts as a coat. The <i><a href="/wiki/Karakul_(hat)" title="Karakul (hat)">karakul</a></i> is a hat made from the fur of a specific regional breed of sheep. It was favored by former kings of Afghanistan and became known to much of the world in the 21st century when it was constantly worn by President <a href="/wiki/Hamid_Karzai" title="Hamid Karzai">Hamid Karzai</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[372]</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Pakol" title="Pakol">pakol</a></i> is another traditional hat originating from the far east of the country; it was popularly worn by the guerilla leader <a href="/wiki/Ahmad_Shah_Massoud" title="Ahmad Shah Massoud">Ahmad Shah Massoud</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[373]</a></sup> The <i>Mazari hat</i> originates from northern Afghanistan.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">[374]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Afghanistan" title="Architecture of Afghanistan">Architecture of Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The nation has a complex history that has survived either in its current cultures or in the form of various languages and monuments. Afghanistan contains many remnants from all ages, including <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Greek</a> and <a href="/wiki/Buddhist" class="mw-redirect" title="Buddhist">Buddhist</a> stupas, monasteries, monuments, temples and Islamic minarets. Among the most well known are the <a href="/wiki/Great_Mosque_of_Herat" title="Great Mosque of Herat">Great Mosque of Herat</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Blue_Mosque_(Mazar-i-Sharif)" title="Blue Mosque (Mazar-i-Sharif)">Blue Mosque</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Minaret_of_Jam" title="Minaret of Jam">Minaret of Jam</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Chil_Zena" title="Chil Zena">Chil Zena</a>, the Qala-i Bost in <a href="/wiki/Lashkargah" title="Lashkargah">Lashkargah</a>, the ancient Greek city of <a href="/wiki/Ai-Khanoum" title="Ai-Khanoum">Ai-Khanoum</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[375]</a></sup> However, many of its historic monuments have been damaged in modern times due to the civil wars.<sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">[376]</a></sup> The two famous <a href="/wiki/Buddhas_of_Bamiyan" title="Buddhas of Bamiyan">Buddhas of Bamiyan</a> were destroyed by the Taliban, who regarded them as <a href="/wiki/Idolatrous" class="mw-redirect" title="Idolatrous">idolatrous</a>. Despite that, archaeologists are still finding Buddhist relics in different parts of the country, some of them dating back to the 2nd century.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[377]</a></sup> As there was no colonialism in the modern era in Afghanistan, European-style architecture is rare; most notably the Victory Arch at <a href="/wiki/Paghman" title="Paghman">Paghman</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Darul_Aman_Palace" title="Darul Aman Palace">Darul Aman Palace</a> in Kabul, were built in this style in the 1920s by the Afghans themselves. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Art_and_ceramics">Art and ceramics</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Afghan_art" title="Afghan art">Afghan art</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Afghan_carpet.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Afghan_carpet.JPG/170px-Afghan_carpet.JPG" decoding="async" width="170" height="192" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Afghan_carpet.JPG/255px-Afghan_carpet.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Afghan_carpet.JPG/340px-Afghan_carpet.JPG 2x" data-file-width="415" data-file-height="468"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Afghan_carpet.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>An <a href="/wiki/Afghan_rug" title="Afghan rug">Afghan rug</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Carpet <a href="/wiki/Weaving" title="Weaving">weaving</a> is an ancient practice in Afghanistan, and many of these are still <a href="/wiki/Handicraft" title="Handicraft">handmade</a> by tribal and nomadic people today.<sup id="cite_ref-auto5_223-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto5-223">[221]</a></sup> Carpets have been produced in the region for thousands of years and traditionally done by women.<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">[378]</a></sup> Some crafters express their feelings through the designs of rugs; for example after the outbreak of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet-Afghan_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet-Afghan War">Soviet-Afghan War</a>, "<a href="/wiki/War_rugs" title="War rugs">war rugs</a>" were created with designs representing pain and misery caused by the conflict.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">[379]</a></sup> Every province has its own specific characteristics in making rugs.<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">[380]</a></sup> In some of the Turkic-populated areas in the north-west, bride and wedding ceremony prices are driven by the bride's weaving skills.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">[381]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Pottery" title="Pottery">Pottery</a> has been crafted in Afghanistan for millennia. The village of <a href="/wiki/Istalif" title="Istalif">Istalif</a>, north of Kabul, is in particular a major center, known for its unique turquoise and green pottery,<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">[382]</a></sup> and their methods of crafting have remained the same for centuries.<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">[383]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">[384]</a></sup> Much of <i><a href="/wiki/Lapis_lazuli" title="Lapis lazuli">lapis lazuli</a></i> stones were earthed in modern-day Afghanistan which were used in <a href="/wiki/Chinese_porcelain" class="mw-redirect" title="Chinese porcelain">Chinese porcelain</a> as <a href="/wiki/Cobalt_blue" title="Cobalt blue">cobalt blue</a>, later used in ancient <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">[385]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The lands of Afghanistan have a long history of art, with the world's earliest known usage of <a href="/wiki/Oil_painting" title="Oil painting">oil painting</a> found in cave murals in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">[386]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">[387]</a></sup> A notable art style that developed in Afghanistan and eastern Pakistan is <a href="/wiki/Gandhara_Art" class="mw-redirect" title="Gandhara Art">Gandhara Art</a>, produced by a fusion of <a href="/wiki/Greco-Roman" class="mw-redirect" title="Greco-Roman">Greco-Roman</a> art and <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_art" title="Buddhist art">Buddhist art</a> between the 1st and 7th centuries CE.<sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">[388]</a></sup> Later eras saw increased use of the <a href="/wiki/Persian_miniature" title="Persian miniature">Persian miniature</a> style, with <a href="/wiki/Kamaleddin_Behzad" class="mw-redirect" title="Kamaleddin Behzad">Kamaleddin Behzad</a> of <a href="/wiki/Herat" title="Herat">Herat</a> being one of the most notable miniature artists of the <a href="/wiki/Timurid_dynasty" title="Timurid dynasty">Timurid</a> and early <a href="/wiki/Safavid" class="mw-redirect" title="Safavid">Safavid</a> periods. Since the 1900s, the nation began to use Western techniques in art. <a href="/wiki/Abdul_Ghafoor_Breshna" title="Abdul Ghafoor Breshna">Abdul Ghafoor Breshna</a> was a prominent Afghan painter and sketch artist from Kabul during the 20th century. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media_and_entertainment">Media and entertainment</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Afghanistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Media of Afghanistan">Media of Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Afghanistan has around 350 <a href="/wiki/List_of_radio_stations_in_Afghanistan" title="List of radio stations in Afghanistan">radio stations</a> and over 200 television stations.<sup id="cite_ref-TOLO-2019_391-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TOLO-2019-391">[389]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Radio_Television_Afghanistan" title="Radio Television Afghanistan">Radio Television Afghanistan</a>, originating from 1925, is the state public broadcaster. Television programs began airing in the 1970s and today there are many private television channels such as <a href="/wiki/TOLO_(TV_channel)" title="TOLO (TV channel)">TOLO</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shamshad_TV" title="Shamshad TV">Shamshad TV</a>. The first Afghan newspaper was published in 1873,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDupree1997405_392-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDupree1997405-392">[390]</a></sup> and there are hundreds of print outlets today.<sup id="cite_ref-TOLO-2019_391-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TOLO-2019-391">[389]</a></sup> By the 1920s, <a href="/wiki/Radio_Kabul" title="Radio Kabul">Radio Kabul</a> was broadcasting local radio services.<sup id="cite_ref-Whitlock2003_393-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Whitlock2003-393">[391]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Voice_of_America" title="Voice of America">Voice of America</a>, <a href="/wiki/BBC_World_Service" title="BBC World Service">BBC</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Radio_Free_Europe/Radio_Liberty" title="Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty">Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty</a> (RFE/RL) broadcast in both of Afghanistan's official languages on radio.<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">[392]</a></sup> Press restrictions have been gradually relaxed and private media diversified since 2002, after more than two decades of tight controls. </p>
      <p>Afghans have long been accustomed to watching Indian <a href="/wiki/Bollywood" title="Bollywood">Bollywood</a> films and listening to its <a href="/wiki/Filmi" title="Filmi">filmi</a> songs.<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">[393]</a></sup> It has been claimed that Afghanistan is among the biggest markets for the Hindi film industry.<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">[394]</a></sup> The stereotypes of <a href="/wiki/Afghans_in_India" title="Afghans in India">Afghans in India</a> (<i>Kabuliwala</i> or <i>Pathani</i>) has also been represented in some Bollywood films by actors.<sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397">[395]</a></sup> Many Bollywood film stars have roots in Afghanistan, including <a href="/wiki/Salman_Khan" title="Salman Khan">Salman Khan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saif_Ali_Khan" title="Saif Ali Khan">Saif Ali Khan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shah_Rukh_Khan" title="Shah Rukh Khan">Shah Rukh Khan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aamir_Khan" title="Aamir Khan">Aamir Khan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Feroz_Khan_(Indian_actor)" class="mw-redirect" title="Feroz Khan (Indian actor)">Feroz Khan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kader_Khan" title="Kader Khan">Kader Khan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Naseeruddin_Shah" title="Naseeruddin Shah">Naseeruddin Shah</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zarine_Khan" class="mw-redirect" title="Zarine Khan">Zarine Khan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Celina_Jaitly" title="Celina Jaitly">Celina Jaitly</a>, and a number of others. Several Bollywood films have been shot inside Afghanistan, including <i><a href="/wiki/Dharmatma" title="Dharmatma">Dharmatma</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Khuda_Gawah" title="Khuda Gawah">Khuda Gawah</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Escape_from_Taliban" title="Escape from Taliban">Escape from Taliban</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Kabul_Express" title="Kabul Express">Kabul Express</a></i>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Afghanistan" title="Music of Afghanistan">Music of Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Afghan_rubab.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Afghan_rubab.jpg/220px-Afghan_rubab.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="157" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Afghan_rubab.jpg/330px-Afghan_rubab.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Afghan_rubab.jpg/440px-Afghan_rubab.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1350" data-file-height="965"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Afghan_rubab.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The Afghan <a href="/wiki/Rubab_(instrument)" title="Rubab (instrument)">rubab</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Afghan classical music has close historical links with <a href="/wiki/Indian_classical_music" title="Indian classical music">Indian classical music</a> and use the same Hindustani terminology and theories like <a href="/wiki/Raga" title="Raga">raga</a>. Genres of this style of music include <a href="/wiki/Ghazal" title="Ghazal">ghazal</a> (poetic music) and instruments such as the Indian <a href="/wiki/Tabla" title="Tabla">tabla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sitar" title="Sitar">sitar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Harmonium" class="mw-redirect" title="Harmonium">harmonium</a>, and local instruments like <a href="/wiki/Zerbaghali" title="Zerbaghali">zerbaghali</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Dayereh" title="Dayereh">dayereh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tanbur" title="Tanbur">tanbur</a> which are also known in Central Asia, the Caucusus and the Middle East. The <a href="/wiki/Rubab_(instrument)" title="Rubab (instrument)">rubab</a> is the country's national instrument and precurses the Indian <a href="/wiki/Sarod" title="Sarod">sarod</a> instrument. Some of the famous artists of classical music include <a href="/wiki/Ustad_Sarahang" class="mw-redirect" title="Ustad Sarahang">Ustad Sarahang</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abdul_Rahim_Sarban" title="Abdul Rahim Sarban">Sarban</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto4_398-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-398">[396]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Pop music developed in the 1950s through <a href="/wiki/Radio_Kabul" title="Radio Kabul">Radio Kabul</a> and was influential in social change. During this time female artists also started appearing, at first <a href="/wiki/Mermon_Parwin" title="Mermon Parwin">Mermon Parwin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto4_398-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-398">[396]</a></sup> Perhaps the most famous artist of this genre was <a href="/wiki/Ahmad_Zahir" title="Ahmad Zahir">Ahmad Zahir</a>, who synthesized many genres and continues to be renowned for his voice and rich lyrics long after his death in 1979.<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">[397]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto4_398-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-398">[396]</a></sup> Other notable masters of traditional or popular Afghan music include <a href="/wiki/Nashenas" title="Nashenas">Nashenas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ubaidullah_Jan" title="Ubaidullah Jan">Ubaidullah Jan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mahwash" title="Mahwash">Mahwash</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ahmad_Wali" title="Ahmad Wali">Ahmad Wali</a>, <a href="/wiki/Farhad_Darya" title="Farhad Darya">Farhad Darya</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Naghma" title="Naghma">Naghma</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400">[398]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Attan" title="Attan">Attan</a> is the national dance of Afghanistan, a group dance popularly performed by Afghans of all backgrounds.<sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401">[399]</a></sup> The dance is considered part of Afghan identity.<sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402">[400]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Afghan_cuisine" title="Afghan cuisine">Afghan cuisine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Afghan_cuisine.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Afghan_cuisine.jpg/250px-Afghan_cuisine.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="225" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Afghan_cuisine.jpg/375px-Afghan_cuisine.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Afghan_cuisine.jpg/500px-Afghan_cuisine.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="920"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Afghan_cuisine.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Some of the popular Afghan dishes
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Afghan cuisine is largely based upon the nation's chief crops, such as wheat, maize, <a href="/wiki/Barley" title="Barley">barley</a> and rice. Accompanying these staples are native fruits and vegetables as well as dairy products such as milk, <a href="/wiki/Yogurt" title="Yogurt">yogurt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Whey" title="Whey">whey</a>. <a href="/wiki/Kabuli_palaw" title="Kabuli palaw">Kabuli palaw</a> is the <a href="/wiki/National_dish" title="National dish">national dish</a> of Afghanistan.<sup id="cite_ref-foodrepublic_403-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-foodrepublic-403">[401]</a></sup> The nation's culinary specialties reflect its ethnic and geographic diversity.<sup id="cite_ref-Brittin_404-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brittin-404">[402]</a></sup> Afghanistan is known for its high quality <a href="/wiki/Pomegranate_production_in_Afghanistan" title="Pomegranate production in Afghanistan">pomegranates</a>, grapes, and sweet melons.<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">[403]</a></sup> Tea is a favorite drink among Afghans, and they typically eat <a href="/wiki/Naan" title="Naan">naan</a> breads, yoghurts, rice and meat in a typical diet.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_361-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-361">[359]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Poetry_of_Afghanistan" title="Poetry of Afghanistan">Poetry of Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Classic <a href="/wiki/Persian_literature" title="Persian literature">Persian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pashto_poetry" class="mw-redirect" title="Pashto poetry">Pashto poetry</a> are a cherished part of Afghan culture. Poetry has always been one of the major educational pillars in the region, to the level that it has integrated itself into culture.<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">[404]</a></sup> One of the poetic styles is called <a href="/wiki/Landay_(poetry)" title="Landay (poetry)">landay</a>. A popular theme in Afghan folklore and mythology are <a href="/wiki/Dev_(mythology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Dev (mythology)">devs</a>, monstrous creatures.<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">[405]</a></sup> Thursdays are traditionally "poetry night" in the city of <a href="/wiki/Herat" title="Herat">Herat</a> when men, women and children gather and recite both ancient and modern poems.<sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">[406]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Afghan region has produced countless Persian-speaking poets and writers from the Middle Ages to the present day, among which three mystical authors are considered true national glories (although claimed with equal ardor by Iran), namely: <a href="/wiki/Khwaja_Abdullah_Ansari" title="Khwaja Abdullah Ansari">Khwaja Abdullah Ansari</a> of Herat, a great mystic and <a href="/wiki/Sufi" class="mw-redirect" title="Sufi">Sufi</a> saint in the 11th century, <a href="/wiki/Sanai" title="Sanai">Sanai</a> of Ghazni, author of mystical poems in the 12th century, and, finally, <a href="/wiki/Rumi" title="Rumi">Rumi</a> of Balkh, in the 13th century, considered the persophonist throughout the world as the greatest mystical poet of the entire Muslim world. The Afghan Pashto literature, although quantitatively remarkable and in great growth in the last century, has always had an essentially local meaning and importance, feeling the influence of both Persian literature and the contiguous literatures of India. Both main literatures, from the second half of the nineteenth century, have shown themselves to be sensitive to genres (novel, theater), movements and stylistic features imported from Europe. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Khushal_Khan_Khattak" class="mw-redirect" title="Khushal Khan Khattak">Khushal Khan Khattak</a> of the 17th century is considered the national poet. Other notable poets include <a href="/wiki/Rabi%27a_Balkhi" class="mw-redirect" title="Rabi'a Balkhi">Rabi'a Balkhi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jami" title="Jami">Jami</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rahman_Baba" title="Rahman Baba">Rahman Baba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khalilullah_Khalili" title="Khalilullah Khalili">Khalilullah Khalili</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Parween_Pazhwak" title="Parween Pazhwak">Parween Pazhwak</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">[407]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Holidays_and_festivals">Holidays and festivals</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:%D9%87%D9%81%D8%AA_%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%88%D9%87.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/%D9%87%D9%81%D8%AA_%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%88%D9%87.jpg/220px-%D9%87%D9%81%D8%AA_%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%88%D9%87.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="293" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/%D9%87%D9%81%D8%AA_%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%88%D9%87.jpg/330px-%D9%87%D9%81%D8%AA_%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%88%D9%87.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/%D9%87%D9%81%D8%AA_%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%88%D9%87.jpg/440px-%D9%87%D9%81%D8%AA_%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%88%D9%87.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3024" data-file-height="4032"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:%D9%87%D9%81%D8%AA_%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%88%D9%87.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Haft Mewa (Seven Fruit Syrup) is popularly consumed during Nowruz in Afghanistan
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Afghanistan's official New Year starts with <a href="/wiki/Nowruz" title="Nowruz">Nowruz</a>, an ancient tradition that started as a <a href="/wiki/Zoroastrian" class="mw-redirect" title="Zoroastrian">Zoroastrian</a> celebration in present-day Iran, and with which it shares the annual celebration along with several other countries. It occurs every year at the <a href="/wiki/March_equinox" title="March equinox">vernal equinox</a>. <a href="/wiki/Nauruz_in_Afghanistan" title="Nauruz in Afghanistan">In Afghanistan</a>, Nowruz is typically celebrated with music and dance, as well as holding <a href="/wiki/Buzkashi" title="Buzkashi">buzkashi</a> tournaments.<sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">[408]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Yald%C4%81" class="mw-redirect" title="YaldÄ">YaldÄ</a>, another nationally celebrated ancient tradition,<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">[409]</a></sup> commemorates the ancient goddess <a href="/wiki/Mithra" title="Mithra">Mithra</a> and marks the longest night of the year on the eve of the <a href="/wiki/Winter_solstice" title="Winter solstice">winter solstice</a> (<i lang="fa-Latn" title="Persian-language romanization">Äelle ye zemestÄn</i>; usually falling on 20 or 21 December),<sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">[410]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">[411]</a></sup> during which families gather together to recite poetry and eat fruitsâparticularly the red fruits watermelon and <a href="/wiki/Pomegranate" title="Pomegranate">pomegranate</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Mixed_nuts" title="Mixed nuts">mixed nuts</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">[412]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">[413]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Religious festivals are also celebrated; as a predominantly Muslim country, Islamic events and festivals such as <a href="/wiki/Ramadan" title="Ramadan">Ramadan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eid_al-Fitr" title="Eid al-Fitr">Eid al-Fitr</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ashura" title="Ashura">Ashura</a> are widely celebrated annually in Afghanistan. The Sikh festival of <a href="/wiki/Vaisakhi" title="Vaisakhi">Vaisakhi</a> is celebrated by the Sikh community<sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">[414]</a></sup> and the Hindu festival <a href="/wiki/Diwali" title="Diwali">Diwali</a> by the Hindu community.<sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">[415]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Afghan_Independence_Day" title="Afghan Independence Day">National Independence Day</a> is celebrated on 19 August to mark the <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Afghan_Treaty_of_1919" title="Anglo-Afghan Treaty of 1919">Anglo-Afghan Treaty of 1919</a> under King <a href="/wiki/Amanullah_Khan" title="Amanullah Khan">Amanullah Khan</a> and the country's full independence.<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">[416]</a></sup> Several international celebrations are also officially held in Afghanistan, such as <a href="/wiki/International_Workers%27_Day" title="International Workers' Day">International Workers' Day</a> and <a href="/wiki/International_Women%27s_Day" title="International Women's Day">International Women's Day</a>. Some regional festivals include the Pamir Festival, which celebrates the culture of the <a href="/wiki/Wakhi_people" title="Wakhi people">Wakhi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kyrgyz_people" title="Kyrgyz people">Kyrgyz</a> peoples, the Red Flower Festival (during Nowruz) in <a href="/wiki/Mazar-i-Sharif" title="Mazar-i-Sharif">Mazar-i-Sharif</a> and the Damboora Festival in <a href="/wiki/Bamyan_Province" title="Bamyan Province">Bamyan Province</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Afghanistan" title="Sport in Afghanistan">Sport in Afghanistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Buzkashi_game_in_Afghanistan.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Buzkashi_game_in_Afghanistan.jpg/220px-Buzkashi_game_in_Afghanistan.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Buzkashi_game_in_Afghanistan.jpg/330px-Buzkashi_game_in_Afghanistan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Buzkashi_game_in_Afghanistan.jpg/440px-Buzkashi_game_in_Afghanistan.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2881" data-file-height="1921"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Buzkashi_game_in_Afghanistan.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The ancient national sport of Afghanistan, <a href="/wiki/Buzkashi" title="Buzkashi">Buzkashi</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Sport in Afghanistan is managed by the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Sports_Federation" title="Afghan Sports Federation">Afghan Sports Federation</a>. <a href="/wiki/Cricket" title="Cricket">Cricket</a> and association football are the two most popular sports in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419">[417]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420">[418]</a></sup> The Afghan Sports Federation promotes cricket, association football, <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">basketball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">volleyball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Golf" title="Golf">golf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Team_handball" class="mw-redirect" title="Team handball">handball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">boxing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taekwondo" title="Taekwondo">taekwondo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Olympic_weightlifting" title="Olympic weightlifting">weightlifting</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bodybuilding" title="Bodybuilding">bodybuilding</a>, <a href="/wiki/Track_and_field" title="Track and field">track and field</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ice_skating" title="Ice skating">skating</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bowling" title="Bowling">bowling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Snooker" title="Snooker">snooker</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">chess</a>, and other sports. </p>
      <p>Afghanistan's sports teams are increasingly celebrating titles at international events. Its <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan_national_basketball_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghanistan national basketball team">basketball team</a> won the first team sports title at the <a href="/wiki/2010_South_Asian_Games" title="2010 South Asian Games">2010 South Asian Games</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">[419]</a></sup> Later that year, the country's <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan_national_cricket_team" title="Afghanistan national cricket team">cricket team</a> followed as it won the <a href="/wiki/2009%E2%80%9310_ICC_Intercontinental_Cup" title="2009â10 ICC Intercontinental Cup">2009â10 ICC Intercontinental Cup</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ICUP2009-10_422-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ICUP2009-10-422">[420]</a></sup> In 2012, the country's <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan_national_3x3_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghanistan national 3x3 team">3x3 basketball team</a> won the gold medal at the <a href="/wiki/3-on-3_basketball_at_the_2012_Asian_Beach_Games" class="mw-redirect" title="3-on-3 basketball at the 2012 Asian Beach Games">2012 Asian Beach Games</a>. In 2013, Afghanistan's <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan_national_football_team" title="Afghanistan national football team">football team</a> followed as it won the <a href="/wiki/SAFF_Championship" title="SAFF Championship">SAFF Championship</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-SAFF2013_423-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SAFF2013-423">[421]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Afghan_national_cricket_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan national cricket team">Afghan national cricket team</a>, which was formed in 2001, participated in the <a href="/wiki/2009_ICC_World_Cup_Qualifier" class="mw-redirect" title="2009 ICC World Cup Qualifier">2009 ICC World Cup Qualifier</a>, <a href="/wiki/2010_ICC_World_Cricket_League_Division_One" title="2010 ICC World Cricket League Division One">2010 ICC World Cricket League Division One</a> and the <a href="/wiki/2010_ICC_World_Twenty20" title="2010 ICC World Twenty20">2010 ICC World Twenty20</a>. It won the <a href="/wiki/ACC_Twenty20_Cup" title="ACC Twenty20 Cup">ACC Twenty20 Cup</a> in 2007, 2009, 2011 and 2013. The team eventually made it and played in the <a href="/wiki/2015_Cricket_World_Cup" title="2015 Cricket World Cup">2015 Cricket World Cup</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">[422]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan_Cricket_Board" title="Afghanistan Cricket Board">Afghanistan Cricket Board</a> (ACB) is the official governing body of the sport and is headquartered in Kabul. The <a href="/wiki/Alokozay_Kabul_International_Cricket_Ground" title="Alokozay Kabul International Cricket Ground">Alokozay Kabul International Cricket Ground</a> serves as the nation's main cricket stadium. There are several other stadiums throughout the country, including the <a href="/wiki/Ghazi_Amanullah_Khan_International_Cricket_Stadium" class="mw-redirect" title="Ghazi Amanullah Khan International Cricket Stadium">Ghazi Amanullah Khan International Cricket Stadium</a> near <a href="/wiki/Jalalabad" title="Jalalabad">Jalalabad</a>. Domestically, cricket is played between teams from different provinces. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan_national_football_team" title="Afghanistan national football team">Afghanistan national football team</a> has been competing in international <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a> since 1941.<sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">[423]</a></sup> The national team plays its home games at the <a href="/wiki/Ghazi_Stadium" title="Ghazi Stadium">Ghazi Stadium</a> in Kabul, while <a href="/wiki/Football_in_Afghanistan" title="Football in Afghanistan">football in Afghanistan</a> is governed by the <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan_Football_Federation" title="Afghanistan Football Federation">Afghanistan Football Federation</a>. The national team has never competed or qualified for the <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">FIFA World Cup</a> but has recently won an international football trophy in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-SAFF2013_423-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SAFF2013-423">[421]</a></sup> The country also has a national team in the sport of futsal, a 5-a-side variation of football. </p>
      <p>The traditional and the national sport of Afghanistan is <a href="/wiki/Buzkashi" title="Buzkashi">buzkashi</a>, mainly popular in the north, but also having a following in other parts of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">[424]</a></sup> It is similar to <a href="/wiki/Polo" title="Polo">polo</a>, played by horsemen in two teams, each trying to grab and hold a goat carcass.<sup id="cite_ref-twsj_427-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-twsj-427">[425]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Hound" title="Afghan Hound">Afghan Hound</a> (a type of running dog) originated in Afghanistan and was formerly used in <a href="/wiki/Wolf_hunting_with_dogs" title="Wolf hunting with dogs">wolf hunting</a>. In 2002, traveler <a href="/wiki/Rory_Stewart" title="Rory Stewart">Rory Stewart</a> reported that dogs were still used for wolf hunting in remote areas.<sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428">[426]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2> 
      <ul>
       <li><a href="/wiki/Index_of_Afghanistan-related_articles" title="Index of Afghanistan-related articles">Index of Afghanistan-related articles</a></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Afghanistan" title="Outline of Afghanistan">Outline of Afghanistan</a></li>
      </ul> 
      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style>
      <div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha"> 
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">
        <ol class="references"> 
         <li id="cite_note-Demonym-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Demonym_7-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Incorrect names that have been used as demonyms are <b>Afghani</b><sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> and <b>Afghanistani</b>.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-fn1-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-fn1_16-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The phoneme <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/f/</span> Ù occurs only in loanwords in Pashto, it tends to be replaced with <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/p/</span> Ù¾. <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[b]</span> is also an allophone of <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/p/</span> before voiced consonants; <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[v]</span> is an allophone of <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/f/</span> before voiced consonants in loanwords.</span> </li> 
        </ol>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1011085734">

         <li id="cite_note-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-19">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-20"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-20">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMalloryAdams1997" class="citation book cs1">Mallory, J.P.; Adams, Douglas Q. (1997). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=tzU3RIV2BWIC"><i>Encyclopedia of Indo-European Culture</i></a> (illustrated&nbsp;ed.).          <li id="cite_note-21"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-21">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation book cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=LclscNCTz9oC&amp;pg=PA52"><i>The Far East and Australasia 2003</i></a>. Psychology Press. 14 June 2002. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781857431339" title="Special:BookSources/9781857431339"><bdi>9781857431339</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Far+East+and+Australasia+2003&amp;rft.pub=Psychology+Press&amp;rft.date=2002-06-14&amp;rft.isbn=9781857431339&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DLclscNCTz9oC%26pg%3DPA52&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAfghanistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-cap1-22"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-cap1_22-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cap1_22-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFQassem2016" class="citation book cs1">Qassem, Ahmad Shayeq (16 March 2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=oAzACwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PT41"><i>Afghanistan's Political Stability: A Dream Unrealised</i></a>. Routledge. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781317184591" title="Special:BookSources/9781317184591"><bdi>9781317184591</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Afghanistan%27s+Political+Stability%3A+A+Dream+Unrealised&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2016-03-16&amp;rft.isbn=9781317184591&amp;rft.aulast=Qassem&amp;rft.aufirst=Ahmad+Shayeq&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DoAzACwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPT41&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAfghanistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-23"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-23">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFTomsen2014" class="citation cs2">Tomsen, Peter (2014), <i>The Wars of Afghanistan</i>, pp.&nbsp;41â2, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1610392624" title="Special:BookSources/978-1610392624"><bdi>978-1610392624</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Wars+of+Afghanistan&amp;rft.pages=41-2&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=978-1610392624&amp;rft.aulast=Tomsen&amp;rft.aufirst=Peter&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAfghanistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-24">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFRashid2000" class="citation cs2">Rashid, Ahmed (2000), <i>Taliban</i>, p.&nbsp;187, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-86064-417-1" title="Special:BookSources/1-86064-417-1"><bdi>1-86064-417-1</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Taliban&amp;rft.pages=187&amp;rft.date=2000&amp;rft.isbn=1-86064-417-1&amp;rft.aulast=Rashid&amp;rft.aufirst=Ahmed&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAfghanistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-25">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><i>"The name Afghan has evidently been derived from Asvakan, the Assakenoi of Arrian... "</i> (Megasthenes and Arrian, p 180. See also: Alexander's Invasion of India, p 38; J.W. McCrindle).</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-26"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-26">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><i>"Even the name Afghan is Aryan being derived from Asvakayana, an important clan of the Asvakas or horsemen who must have derived this title from their handling of celebrated breeds of horses"</i> (See: Imprints of Indian Thought and Culture abroad, p 124, Vivekananda Kendra Prakashan).</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-27"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-27">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">cf: <i>"Their name (Afghan) means "cavalier" being derived from the <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>, </i>Asva<i>, or </i>Asvaka<i>, a horse, and shows that their country must have been noted in ancient times, as it is at the present day, for its superior breed of horses. Asvaka was an important tribe settled north to Kabul river, which offered a gallant resistance but ineffectual resistance to the arms of Alexander "</i>(Ref: Scottish Geographical Magazine, 1999, p 275, Royal Scottish Geographical Society).</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-28"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-28">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><i>"Afghans are Assakani of the <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">Greeks</a>; this word being the <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> <a href="/wiki/Ashvaka" class="mw-redirect" title="Ashvaka">Ashvaka</a> meaning 'horsemen' " </i> (Ref: Sva, 1915, p 113, Christopher Molesworth Birdwood).</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-29"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-29">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Cf: <i>"The name represents Sanskrit Asvaka in the sense of a </i>cavalier<i>, and this reappears scarcely modified in the Assakani or Assakeni of the historians of the expedition of <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander</a>" </i> (Hobson-Jobson: A Glossary of Colloquial <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Indian" title="Anglo-Indian">Anglo-Indian</a> words and phrases, and of kindred terms, etymological..by Henry Yule, AD Burnell).</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-30"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-30">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMajumdar1977" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Ramesh_Chandra_Majumdar" class="mw-redirect" title="Ramesh Chandra Majumdar">Majumdar, Ramesh Chandra</a> (1977) [1952]. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=XNxiN5tzKOgC&amp;pg=PA99"><i>Ancient India</i></a> (Reprinted&nbsp;ed.). Motilal Banarsidass. p.&nbsp;99. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-8-12080-436-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-8-12080-436-4"><bdi>978-8-12080-436-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Ancient+India&amp;rft.pages=99&amp;rft.edition=Reprinted&amp;rft.pub=Motilal+Banarsidass&amp;rft.date=1977&amp;rft.isbn=978-8-12080-436-4&amp;rft.aulast=Majumdar&amp;rft.aufirst=Ramesh+Chandra&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DXNxiN5tzKOgC%26pg%3DPA99&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAfghanistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-36"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-36">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFGeorge_Erdosy1995" class="citation book cs1">George Erdosy (1995). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=A6ZRShEIFwMC"><i>The Indo-Aryans of Ancient South Asia: Language, Material Culture and Ethnicity</i></a>. p.&nbsp;321. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/3110144476" title="Special:BookSources/3110144476"><bdi>3110144476</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Indo-Aryans+of+Ancient+South+Asia%3A+Language%2C+Material+Culture+and+Ethnicity&amp;rft.pages=321&amp;rft.date=1995&amp;rft.isbn=3110144476&amp;rft.au=George+Erdosy&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DA6ZRShEIFwMC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAfghanistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarfield2012255-37"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarfield2012255_37-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFBarfield2012">Barfield 2012</a>, p.&nbsp;255.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-38"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-38">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFNordland2017" class="citation news cs1">Nordland, Rod (29 August 2017). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/29/world/asia/afghanistan-graveyard-empires-historical-pictures.html">"The Empire Stopper"</a>. <i>The New York Times</i>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0362-4331">0362-4331</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20181205023840/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/29/world/asia/afghanistan-graveyard-empires-historical-pictures.html">Archived</a> from the original on 5 December 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-Chahryar-76"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Chahryar_76-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-562k-101"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-562k_101-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-Kakar-102"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Kakar_102-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFKakar1997" class="citation book cs1">Kakar, Mohammed (3 March 1997). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://publishing.cdlib.org/ucpressebooks/view?docId=ft7b69p12h;brand=ucpress"><i>The Soviet Invasion and the Afghan Response, 1979â1982</i></a>. University of California Press. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780520208933" title="Special:BookSources/9780520208933"><bdi>9780520208933</bdi></a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170106175142/http://publishing.cdlib.org/ucpressebooks/view?docId=ft7b69p12h;brand=ucpress">Archived</a> from the original on 6 January 2017<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">7 January</span> 2017</span>. <q>The Afghans are among the latest victims of genocide by a superpower. Large numbers of Afghans were killed to suppress resistance to the army of the Soviet Union, which wished to vindicate its client regime and realize its goal in Afghanistan.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Soviet+Invasion+and+the+Afghan+Response%2C+1979%E2%80%931982&amp;rft.pub=University+of+California+Press&amp;rft.date=1997-03-03&amp;rft.isbn=9780520208933&amp;rft.aulast=Kakar&amp;rft.aufirst=Mohammed&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fpublishing.cdlib.org%2Fucpressebooks%2Fview%3FdocId%3Dft7b69p12h%3Bbrand%3Ducpress&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAfghanistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-103"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-103">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFKlass1994" class="citation book cs1">Klass, Rosanne (1994). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=I2chrSJCW54C&amp;pg=PA129"><i>The Widening Circle of Genocide</i></a>. Transaction Publishers. p.&nbsp;129. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4128-3965-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4128-3965-5"><bdi>978-1-4128-3965-5</bdi></a>. <q>During the intervening fourteen years of Communist rule, an estimated 1.5 to 2 million Afghan civilians were killed by Soviet forces and their proxies- the four Communist regimes in Kabul, and the East Germans, Bulgarians, Czechs, Cubans, Palestinians, Indians and others who assisted them. These were not battle casualties or the unavoidable civilian victims of warfare. Soviet and local Communist forces seldom attacked the scattered guerilla bands of the Afghan Resistance except, in a few strategic locales like the Panjsher valley. Instead they deliberately targeted the civilian population, primarily in the rural areas.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Widening+Circle+of+Genocide&amp;rft.pages=129&amp;rft.pub=Transaction+Publishers&amp;rft.date=1994&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4128-3965-5&amp;rft.aulast=Klass&amp;rft.aufirst=Rosanne&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DI2chrSJCW54C%26pg%3DPA129&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAfghanistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Reisman-104"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Reisman_104-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFReismanNorchi" class="citation web cs1">Reisman, W. Michael; Norchi, Charles H. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.paulbogdanor.com/left/afghan/genocide.pdf">"Genocide and the Soviet Occupation of Afghanistan"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20161026182528/http://www.paulbogdanor.com/left/afghan/genocide.pdf">Archived</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> from the original on 26 October 2016<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">7 January</span> 2017</span>. <q>According to widely reported accounts, substantial programmes of depopulation have been conducted in these Afghan provinces: Ghazni, Nagarhar, Lagham, Qandahar, Zabul, Badakhshan, Lowgar, Paktia, Paktika and Kunar...There is considerable evidence that genocide has been committed against the Afghan people by the combined forces of the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan and the Soviet Union.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Genocide+and+the+Soviet+Occupation+of+Afghanistan&amp;rft.aulast=Reisman&amp;rft.aufirst=W.+Michael&amp;rft.au=Norchi%2C+Charles+H.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.paulbogdanor.com%2Fleft%2Fafghan%2Fgenocide.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAfghanistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-105"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-105">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFGoodson2001" class="citation book cs1">Goodson, Larry P. (2001). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/afghanistansendl00good"><i>Afghanistan's Endless War: State Failure, Regional Politics, and the Rise of the Taliban</i></a></span>. University of Washington Press. p.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/afghanistansendl00good/page/5">5</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-295-98050-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-295-98050-8"><bdi>978-0-295-98050-8</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Afghanistan%27s+Endless+War%3A+State+Failure%2C+Regional+Politics%2C+and+the+Rise+of+the+Taliban&amp;rft.pages=5&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Washington+Press&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-295-98050-8&amp;rft.aulast=Goodson&amp;rft.aufirst=Larry+P.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fafghanistansendl00good&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAfghanistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Soviet-war-video-106"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Soviet-war-video_106-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130729082646/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vYUzL1qhltA">"Soldiers of God: Cold War (Part 1/5)"</a>. CNN. 1998. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vYUzL1qhltA">the original</a> on 29 July 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-Skain-126"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Skain_126-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSkain2002" class="citation book cs1">Skain, Rosemarie (2002). <i>The women of Afghanistan under the Taliban</i>.
